Subject: Math
Text: Develop the concept of slope as rate of change and determine slopes from graphs, tables, and algebraic representations;

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret the meaning of slope and intercepts in situations using data, symbolic representations, or graphs;

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate, describe, and predict the effects of changes in m and b on the graph of y = mx + b;

Subject: Math
Text: Graph and write equations of lines given characteristics such as two points, a point and a slope, or a slope and y-intercept;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the intercepts of the graphs of linear functions and zeros of linear functions from graphs, tables, and algebraic representations;

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret and predict the effects of changing slope and y-intercept in applied situations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Relate direct variation to linear functions and solve problems involving proportional change.

Subject: Math
Text: Linear functions. The student formulates equations and inequalities based on linear functions, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze situations involving linear functions and formulate linear equations or inequalities to solve problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate methods for solving linear equations and inequalities using concrete models, graphs, and the properties of equality, select a method, and solve the equations and inequalities; and

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to linear equations and inequalities.

Subject: Math
Text: Linear functions. The student formulates systems of linear equations from problem situations, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze situations and formulate systems of linear equations in two unknowns to solve problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Solve systems of linear equations using concrete models, graphs, tables, and algebraic methods; and

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to systems of linear equations.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and other nonlinear functions. The student understands that the graphs of quadratic functions are affected by the parameters of the function and can interpret and describe the effects of changes in the parameters of quadratic functions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the domain and range for quadratic functions in given situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate, describe, and predict the effects of changes in a on the graph of y = ax2 + c;

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate, describe, and predict the effects of changes in c on the graph of y = ax2 + c; and

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze graphs of quadratic functions and draw conclusions.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and other nonlinear functions. The student understands there is more than one way to solve a quadratic equation and solves them using appropriate methods. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Solve quadratic equations using concrete models, tables, graphs, and algebraic methods; and

Subject: Math
Text: Make connections among the solutions (roots) of quadratic equations, the zeros of their related functions, and the horizontal intercepts (x-intercepts) of the graph of the function.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and other nonlinear functions. The student understands there are situations modeled by functions that are neither linear nor quadratic and models the situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns to generate the laws of exponents and apply them in problem-solving situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze data and represent situations involving inverse variation using concrete models, tables, graphs, or algebraic methods; and

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze data and represent situations involving exponential growth and decay using concrete models, tables, graphs, or algebraic methods.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student uses properties and attributes of functions and applies functions to problem situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Identify the mathematical domains and ranges of functions and determine reasonable domain and range values for continuous and discrete situations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Collect and organize data, make and interpret scatterplots, fit the graph of a function to the data, interpret the results, and proceed to model, predict, and make decisions and critical judgments.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student understands the importance of the skills required to manipulate symbols in order to solve problems and uses the necessary algebraic skills required to simplify algebraic expressions and solve equations and inequalities in problem situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use tools including factoring and properties of exponents to simplify expressions and to transform and solve equations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use complex numbers to describe the solutions of quadratic equations.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student formulates systems of equations and inequalities from problem situations, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze situations and formulate systems of equations in two or more unknowns or inequalities in two unknowns to solve problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Use algebraic methods, graphs, tables, or matrices, to solve systems of equations or inequalities; and

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to systems of equations or inequalities for given contexts.

Subject: Math
Text: Algebra and geometry. The student connects algebraic and geometric representations of functions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and sketch graphs of parent functions, including linear (f (x) = x), quadratic (f (x) = x2), exponential (f (x) = ax), and logarithmic (f (x) = logax) functions, absolute value of x (f (x) = |x|), square root of x (f (x) = ‰ö_x), and reciprocal of x (f (x) = 1/x);

Subject: Math
Text: Extend parent functions with parameters such as a in f (x) = a/x and describe the effects of the parameter changes on the graph of parent functions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and analyze the relationship between a function and its inverse.

Subject: Math
Text: Algebra and geometry. The student knows the relationship between the geometric and algebraic descriptions of conic sections. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe a conic section as the intersection of a plane and a cone;

Subject: Math
Text: Sketch graphs of conic sections to relate simple parameter changes in the equation to corresponding changes in the graph;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify symmetries from graphs of conic sections;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify the conic section from a given equation; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use the method of completing the square.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and square root functions. The student understands that quadratic functions can be represented in different ways and translates among their various representations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the reasonable domain and range values of quadratic functions, as well as interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to quadratic equations and inequalities;

Subject: Math
Text: Relate representations of quadratic functions, such as algebraic, tabular, graphical, and verbal descriptions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Determine a quadratic function from its roots (real and complex) or a graph.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and square root functions. The student interprets and describes the effects of changes in the parameters of quadratic functions in applied and mathematical situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use characteristics of the quadratic parent function to sketch the related graphs and connect between the y = ax2 + bx + c and the y = a (x - h)2 + k symbolic representations of quadratic functions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use the parent function to investigate, describe, and predict the effects of changes in a, h, and k on the graphs of y = a (x - h)2 + k form of a function in applied and purely mathematical situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and square root functions. The student formulates equations and inequalities based on quadratic functions, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze situations involving quadratic functions and formulate quadratic equations or inequalities to solve problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze and interpret the solutions of quadratic equations using discriminants and solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and translate between algebraic and graphical solutions of quadratic equations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Solve quadratic equations and inequalities using graphs, tables, and algebraic methods.

Subject: Math
Text: Quadratic and square root functions. The student formulates equations and inequalities based on square root functions, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use the parent function to investigate, describe, and predict the effects of parameter changes on the graphs of square root functions and describe limitations on the domains and ranges;

Subject: Math
Text: Relate representations of square root functions, such as algebraic, tabular, graphical, and verbal descriptions;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the reasonable domain and range values of square root functions, as well as interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to square root equations and inequalities;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine solutions of square root equations using graphs, tables, and algebraic methods;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine solutions of square root inequalities using graphs and tables;

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze situations modeled by square root functions, formulate equations or inequalities, select a method, and solve problems; and

Subject: Math
Text: Connect inverses of square root functions with quadratic functions.

Subject: Math
Text: Rational functions. The student formulates equations and inequalities based on rational functions, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use quotients of polynomials to describe the graphs of rational functions, predict the effects of parameter changes, describe limitations on the domains and ranges, and examine asymptotic behavior;

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze various representations of rational functions with respect to problem situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the reasonable domain and range values of rational functions, as well as interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to rational equations and inequalities;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the solutions of rational equations using graphs, tables, and algebraic methods;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine solutions of rational inequalities using graphs and tables;

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze a situation modeled by a rational function, formulate an equation or inequality composed of a linear or quadratic function, and solve the problem; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use functions to model and make predictions in problem situations involving direct and inverse variation.

Subject: Math
Text: Exponential and logarithmic functions. The student formulates equations and inequalities based on exponential and logarithmic functions, uses a variety of methods to solve them, and analyzes the solutions in terms of the situation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Develop the definition of logarithms by exploring and describing the relationship between exponential functions and their inverses;

Subject: Math
Text: Use the parent functions to investigate, describe, and predict the effects of parameter changes on the graphs of exponential and logarithmic functions, describe limitations on the domains and ranges, and examine asymptotic behavior;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the reasonable domain and range values of exponential and logarithmic functions, as well as interpret and determine the reasonableness of solutions to exponential and logarithmic equations and inequalities;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine solutions of exponential and logarithmic equations using graphs, tables, and algebraic methods;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine solutions of exponential and logarithmic inequalities using graphs and tables; and

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze a situation modeled by an exponential function, formulate an equation or inequality, and solve the problem.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses scientific methods and equipment during laboratory and field investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the following definition of science: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

Subject: Science
Text: Know scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology

Subject: Science
Text: Collect and organize qualitative and quantitative data and make measurements with accuracy and precision using tools such as calculators, spreadsheet software, data-collecting probes, computers, standard laboratory glassware, microscopes, various prepared slides, stereoscopes, metric rulers, electronic balances, gel electrophoresis apparatuses, micropipettors, hand lenses, Celsius thermometers, hot plates, lab notebooks or journals, timing devices, cameras, Petri dishes, lab incubators, dissection equipment, meter sticks, and models, diagrams, or samples of biological specimens or structures

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

Subject: Science
Text: Draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services

Subject: Science
Text: Evaluate the impact of scientific research on society and the environment

Subject: Science
Text: Evaluate models according to their limitations in representing biological objects or events

Subject: Science
Text: Research and describe the history of biology and contributions of scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that cells are the basic structures of all living things with specialized parts that perform specific functions and that viruses are different from cells.

Subject: Science
Text: Compare and contrast prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and explain cellular processes, including homeostasis, energy conversions, transport of molecules, and synthesis of new molecules

Subject: Science
Text: Compare the structures of viruses to cells, describe viral reproduction, and describe the role of viruses in causing diseases such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and influenza.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows how an organism grows and the importance of cell differentiation.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the stages of the cell cycle, including deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) replication and mitosis, and the importance of the cell cycle to the growth of organisms

Subject: Science
Text: Examine specialized cells, including roots, stems, and leaves of plants; and animal cells such as blood, muscle, and epithelium

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the roles of DNA, ribonucleic acid (RNA), and environmental factors in cell differentiation

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that disruptions of the cell cycle lead to diseases such as cancer.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows the mechanisms of genetics, including the role of nucleic acids and the principles of Mendelian Genetics.

Subject: Science
Text: Identify components of DNA, and describe how information for specifying the traits of an organism is carried in the DNA

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that components that make up the genetic code are common to all organisms

Subject: Science
Text: Explain the purpose and process of transcription and translation using models of DNA and RNA

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that gene expression is a regulated process

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and illustrate changes in DNA and evaluate the significance of these changes

Subject: Science
Text: Predict possible outcomes of various genetic combinations such as monohybrid crosses, dihybrid crosses and non-Mendelian inheritance

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize the significance of meiosis to sexual reproduction

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how techniques such as DNA fingerprinting, genetic modifications, and chromosomal analysis are used to study the genomes of organisms.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows evolutionary theory is a scientific explanation for the unity and diversity of life.

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate how evidence of common ancestry among groups is provided by the fossil record, biogeography, and homologies, including anatomical, molecular, and developmental

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate scientific explanations concerning any data of sudden appearance, stasis, and sequential nature of groups in the fossil record

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate how natural selection produces change in populations, not individuals;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate how the elements of natural selection, including inherited variation, the potential of a population to produce more offspring than can survive, and a finite supply of environmental resources, result in differential reproductive success

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate the relationship of natural selection to adaptation and to the development of diversity in and among species

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate the effects of other evolutionary mechanisms, including genetic drift, gene flow, mutation, and recombination

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate scientific explanations concerning the complexity of the cell.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that taxonomy is a branching classification based on the shared characteristics of organisms and can change as new discoveries are made.

Subject: Science
Text: Define taxonomy and recognize the importance of a standardized taxonomic system to the scientific community

Subject: Science
Text: Categorize organisms using a hierarchical classification system based on similarities and differences shared among groups

Subject: Science
Text: Compare characteristics of taxonomic groups, including archaea, bacteria, protists, fungi, plants, and animals.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows the significance of various molecules involved in metabolic processes and energy conversions that occur in living organisms.

Subject: Science
Text: Compare the structures and functions of different types of biomolecules, including carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids

Subject: Science
Text: Compare the reactants and products of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in terms of energy and matter

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and investigate the role of enzymes

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and evaluate the evidence regarding formation of simple organic molecules and their organization into long complex molecules having information such as the DNA molecule for self-replicating life.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that biological systems are composed of multiple levels.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the interactions that occur among systems that perform the functions of regulation, nutrient absorption, reproduction, and defense from injury or illness in animals;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the interactions that occur among systems that perform the functions of transport, reproduction, and response in plants

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze the levels of organization in biological systems and relate the levels to each other and to the whole system.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that biological systems work to achieve and maintain balance.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the role of internal feedback mechanisms in the maintenance of homeostasis

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and analyze how organisms, populations, and communities respond to external factors

Subject: Science
Text: Summarize the role of microorganisms in both maintaining and disrupting the health of both organisms and ecosystems

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how events and processes that occur during ecological succession can change populations and species diversity.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that interdependence and interactions occur within an environmental system.

Subject: Science
Text: Interpret relationships, including predation, parasitism, commensalism, mutualism, and competition among organisms

Subject: Science
Text: Compare variations and adaptations of organisms in different ecosystems;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze the flow of matter and energy through trophic levels using various models, including food chains, food webs, and ecological pyramids;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that long-term survival of species is dependent on changing resource bases that are limited;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the flow of matter through the carbon and nitrogen cycles and explain the consequences of disrupting these cycles

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how environmental change can impact ecosystem stability.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations, including the appropriate use of safety showers, eyewash fountains, safety goggles, and fire extinguishers

Subject: Science
Text: Know specific hazards of chemical substances such as flammability, corrosiveness, and radioactivity as summarized on the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS)

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses scientific methods to solve investigative questions.

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the following definition of science: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

Subject: Science
Text: Know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories

Subject: Science
Text: Know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement investigative procedures, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology, including graphing calculators, computers and probes, sufficient scientific glassware such as beakers, Erlenmeyer flasks, pipettes, graduated cylinders, volumetric flasks, safety goggles, and burettes, electronic balances, and an adequate supply of consumable chemicals

Subject: Science
Text: Collect data and make measurements with accuracy and precision

Subject: Science
Text: Express and manipulate chemical quantities using scientific conventions and mathematical procedures, including dimensional analysis, scientific notation, and significant figures

Subject: Science
Text: Organize, analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphs, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials

Subject: Science
Text: Draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services

Subject: Science
Text: Evaluate the impact of research on scientific thought, society, and the environment

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the connection between chemistry and future careers

Subject: Science
Text: Research and describe the history of chemistry and contributions of scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows the characteristics of matter and can analyze the relationships between chemical and physical changes and properties.

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between physical and chemical changes and properties

Subject: Science
Text: Identify extensive and intensive properties

Subject: Science
Text: Compare solids, liquids, and gases in terms of compressibility, structure, shape, and volume;

Subject: Science
Text: Classify matter as pure substances or mixtures through investigation of their properties.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student understands the historical development of the Periodic Table and can apply its predictive power.

Subject: Science
Text: Explain the use of chemical and physical properties in the historical development of the Periodic Table;

Subject: Science
Text: Use the Periodic Table to identify and explain the properties of chemical families, including alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, halogens, noble gases, and transition metals;

Subject: Science
Text: Use the Periodic Table to identify and explain periodic trends, including atomic and ionic radii, electronegativity, and ionization energy.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows and understands the historical development of atomic theory.

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the experimental design and conclusions used in the development of modern atomic theory, including Dalton's Postulates, Thomson's discovery of electron properties, Rutherford's nuclear atom, and Bohr's nuclear atom

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the electromagnetic spectrum and the mathematical relationships between energy, frequency, and wavelength of light

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate the wavelength, frequency, and energy of light using Planck's constant and the speed of light

Subject: Science
Text: Use isotopic composition to calculate average atomic mass of an element

Subject: Science
Text: Express the arrangement of electrons in atoms through electron configurations and Lewis valence electron dot structures.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows how atoms form ionic, metallic, and covalent bonds.

Subject: Science
Text: Name ionic compounds containing main group or transition metals, covalent compounds, acids, and bases, using International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature rules

Subject: Science
Text: Write the chemical formulas of common polyatomic ions, ionic compounds containing main group or transition metals, covalent compounds, acids, and bases;

Subject: Science
Text: Construct electron dot formulas to illustrate ionic and covalent bonds

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the nature of metallic bonding and apply the theory to explain metallic properties such as thermal and electrical conductivity, malleability, and ductility

Subject: Science
Text: Predict molecular structure for molecules with linear, trigonal planar, or tetrahedral electron pair geometries using Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student can quantify the changes that occur during chemical reactions.

Subject: Science
Text: Define and use the concept of a mole

Subject: Science
Text: Use the mole concept to calculate the number of atoms, ions, or molecules in a sample of material

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate percent composition and empirical and molecular formulas

Subject: Science
Text: Use the law of conservation of mass to write and balance chemical equations

Subject: Science
Text: Perform stoichiometric calculations, including determination of mass relationships between reactants and products, calculation of limiting reagents, and percent yield.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student understands the principles of ideal gas behavior, kinetic molecular theory, and the conditions that influence the behavior of gases.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and calculate the relations between volume, pressure, number of moles, and temperature for an ideal gas as described by Boyle's law, Charles' law, Avogadro's law, Dalton's law of partial pressure, and the ideal gas law

Subject: Science
Text: Perform stoichiometric calculations, including determination of mass and volume relationships between reactants and products for reactions involving gases

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the postulates of kinetic molecular theory.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student understands and can apply the factors that influence the behavior of solutions.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the unique role of water in chemical and biological systems

Subject: Science
Text: Develop and use general rules regarding solubility through investigations with aqueous solutions

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate the concentration of solutions in units of molarity

Subject: Science
Text: Use molarity to calculate the dilutions of solutions

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between types of solutions such as electrolytes and nonelectrolytes and unsaturated, saturated, and supersaturated solutions

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate factors that influence solubilities and rates of dissolution such as temperature, agitation, and surface area

Subject: Science
Text: Define acids and bases and distinguish between Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions and predict products in acid base reactions that form water

Subject: Science
Text: Understand and differentiate among acid-base reactions, precipitation reactions, and oxidation-reduction reactions

Subject: Science
Text: Define pH and use the hydrogen or hydroxide ion concentrations to calculate the pH of a solution

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between degrees of dissociation for strong and weak acids and bases.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student understands the energy changes that occur in chemical reactions.

Subject: Science
Text: Understand energy and its forms, including kinetic, potential, chemical, and thermal energies

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the law of conservation of energy and the processes of heat transfer

Subject: Science
Text: Use thermochemical equations to calculate energy changes that occur in chemical reactions and classify reactions as exothermic or endothermic

Subject: Science
Text: Perform calculations involving heat, mass, temperature change, and specific heat

Subject: Science
Text: Use calorimetry to calculate the heat of a chemical process.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student understands the basic processes of nuclear chemistry.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the characteristics of alpha, beta, and gamma radiation

Subject: Science
Text: Describe radioactive decay process in terms of balanced nuclear equations

Subject: Science
Text: Compare fission and fusion reactions

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the concepts of scarcity and opportunity costs. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain why scarcity and choice are basic economic problems faced by every society;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe how societies answer the basic economic questions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the economic factors of production; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Interpret a production-possibilities curve and explain the concepts of opportunity costs and scarcity.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the interaction of supply, demand, and price. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the effect of changes in price on the quantity demanded and quantity supplied;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the non-price determinants that create changes in supply and demand, which result in a new equilibrium price; and
Keywords: consumer income, future  price, subsides, technology,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Interpret a supply-and-demand graph using supply-and-demand schedules.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the reasons for international trade and its importance to the United States and the global economy. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the concepts of absolute and comparative advantages;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Apply the concept of comparative advantage to explain why and how countries trade; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the impact of U.S. imports and exports on the United States and its trading partners.
Keywords: Mexico, China, Japan, India, Brazil, Specialization,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the issues of free trade and the effects of trade barriers. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the effects of free trade and trade barriers on economic activities;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the benefits and costs of participation in international free-trade agreements; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the effects of changes in exchange rates on imports and exports.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands free enterprise, socialist, and communist economic systems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the basic characteristics of economic systems, including property rights, incentives, economic freedom, competition, and the role of government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the free enterprise system, socialism, and communism using the basic characteristics of economic systems;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine current examples of free enterprise, socialist, and communist economic systems;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand that the terms free enterprise, free market, and capitalism are synonymous terms to describe the U.S. economic system; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the importance of various economic philosophers, including Friedrich Hayek, Milton Friedman, John Maynard Keynes, and Adam Smith, and their impact on the U.S. free enterprise system.
Keywords: Austrian Economics, trickle down economics, supply side economics, Laissez-faire, Wealth of Nations,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the basic characteristics and benefits of a free enterprise system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the basic characteristics of the U.S. free enterprise system, including private property, incentives, economic freedom, competition, and the limited role of government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the benefits of the U.S. free enterprise system, including individual freedom of consumers and producers, variety of goods, responsive prices, investment opportunities, and the creation of wealth;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze recent changes in the basic characteristics of the U.S. economy; and
Keywords: outsourcing, trade deficit, tax cuts, deregulation,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the costs and benefits of U.S. economic policies related to the economic goals of economic growth, stability, full employment, freedom, security, equity (equal opportunity versus equal outcome), and efficiency.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the right to own, use, and dispose of private property. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the costs and benefits of the purchase, use, or disposal of personal and business property; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and evaluate examples of restrictions that the government places on the use of business and individual property.
Keywords: zoning laws, ordinances, saftey, historical buildings,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the circular-flow model of the economy. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Interpret the roles of resource owners and firms in a circular-flow model of the economy and provide real-world examples to illustrate elements of the model;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how government actions affect the circular-flow model; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how the circular-flow model is affected by the rest of the world.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands types of market structures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe characteristics and give examples of pure competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and monopoly; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and evaluate ordinances and regulations that apply to the establishment and operation of various types of businesses.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands key economic measurements. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Interpret economic data, including unemployment rate, gross domestic product, gross domestic product per capita as a measure of national wealth, and rate of inflation; and
Keywords: GDP, PPP, GDP per capita, Exchange rate,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze business cycles using key economic indicators.
Keywords: Inflation, Unemployment, retail sales, Housing starts,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands key components of economic growth. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze how productivity relates to growth;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze how technology relates to growth; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze how trade relates to growth.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the role of money in an economy. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the functions of money;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the characteristics of money, including commodity money, fiat money, and representative money; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine the positive and negative aspects of barter, currency, credit cards, and debit cards.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the role of the Federal Reserve System in establishing monetary policy. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the structure of the Federal Reserve System;
Keywords: Board of Governors, federal Reserve Act 1913, FOMC, Banks,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the three basic tools used to implement U.S. monetary policy, including reserve requirements, the discount rate and the federal funds rate target, and open-market operations;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how the actions of the Federal Reserve System affect the nation's money supply; and
Keywords: Reserve Requirement, Open Market transactions, Discount Rate,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the decline in value of the U.S. dollar, including the abandonment of the gold standard.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the role that the government plays in the U.S. free enterprise system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify economic concepts in the U.S. Constitution, including property rights and taxation;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the role of government in the U.S. free enterprise system and the changes in that role over time; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate government rules and regulations in the U.S. free enterprise system.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the economic impact of fiscal policy decisions at the local, state, and national levels. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify types of taxes at the local, state, and national levels and the economic importance of each;
Keywords: progressive tax, regressive tax, Proportional tax, Tariff,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the categories of revenues and expenditures in the U.S. federal budget; and
Keywords: income tax, social security tax, corporate tax, defense, domestic, federal payment for individuals,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the impact of fiscal policy decisions on the economy.
Keywords: expansionary fiscal policy, contractionary fiscal policy, demand side, supply side,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Personal financial literacy. The student understands types of business ownership. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the characteristics of sole proprietorships, partnerships, and corporations;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the advantages and disadvantages of sole proprietorships, partnerships, and corporations;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the economic rights and responsibilities of businesses, including those involved in starting a small business; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how corporations raise money through stocks and bonds.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Personal financial literacy. The student understands the role of financial markets/institutions in saving, borrowing, and capital formation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the functions of financial institutions and how they affect households and businesses;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how the amount of savings in an economy is the basis of capital formation;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the role of interest and risk in allocating savings to its most productive use; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine the types of accounts available to consumers from financial institutions and the risks, monetary costs, and benefits of maintaining these accounts.
Keywords: Savings account, Checking Account, IRA Accounts, Mutual Funds,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Personal financial literacy. The student understands the role of individuals in financial markets. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Assess ways to be a wise investor in the stock market and in other personal investment options;
Keywords: interest income, dividend income, market price, Decline in market value,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how to begin a savings program;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine investment options available in a personal retirement plan;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Demonstrate how to maintain a checking account, including reconciling a bank statement;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the types of loans available to consumers;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the responsibilities and obligations of borrowing money; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Develop strategies to become a low-risk borrower by improving one's personal credit score.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Personal financial literacy. The student applies critical-thinking skills to analyze the costs and benefits of personal financial decisions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine ways to avoid and eliminate credit card debt;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the costs and benefits of declaring personal bankruptcy;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the costs and benefits of buying insurance; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the costs and benefits of charitable giving.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Personal financial literacy. The student understands how to provide for basic needs while living within a budget. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the costs and benefits of renting a home;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the costs and benefits of buying a home; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Assess the financial aspects of making the transition from renting to home ownership.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired from a variety of valid sources, including electronic technology. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze economic information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing, contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations and predictions, and drawing inferences and conclusions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create economic models, including production-possibilities curves, circular-flow charts, and supply-and-demand graphs, to analyze economic concepts or issues;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain a point of view on an economic issue;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze and evaluate the validity of economic information from primary and secondary sources for bias, propaganda, point of view, and frame of reference;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate economic data using charts, tables, graphs, and maps; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use appropriate mathematical skills to interpret economic information.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use economic-related terminology correctly;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use standard grammar, spelling, sentence structure, and punctuation;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Transfer information from one medium to another, including written to visual and statistical to written or visual, using computer software as appropriate;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create written, oral, and visual presentations of economic information; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Attribute ideas and information to source materials and authors.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others, in a variety of settings. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading Skills/Print Awareness. Students understand how English is written and printed.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize that spoken words can be represented by print for communication

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify upper- and lower-case letters;
Keywords: capitalization, alphabet art, books, chants, find letters in written and printed text, flashcards,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrate the one-to-one correspondence between a spoken word and a printed word in text
Keywords: alphabet, voice-print matching, word dots, finger reading,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize the difference between a letter and a printed word

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize that sentences are comprised of words separated by spaces and demonstrate the awareness of word boundaries (e.g., through kinesthetic or tactile actions such as clapping and jumping

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Hold a book right side up, turn its pages correctly, and know that reading moves from top to bottom and left to right

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify different parts of a book (e.g., front and back covers, title page).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading Skills/Phonological Awareness. Students display phonological awareness.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify a sentence made up of a group of words

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify syllables in spoken words

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Orally generate rhymes in response to spoken words (e.g., What rhymes with hat?)
Keywords: rhyming words, single sounds, blend and segment syllables,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish orally presented rhyming pairs of words from non-rhyming pairs
Keywords: two words rhyme, three words rhyme,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize spoken alliteration or groups of words that begin with the same spoken onset or initial sound

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Blend spoken onsets and rimes to form simple words (e.g., onset/c/ and rime/at/ make cat)
Keywords: segment onset and rime, blend onset and rime, beginning sounds,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Blend spoken phonemes to form one-syllable words (e.g.,/m/ ƒ/a/ ƒ/n/ says man

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Isolate the initial sound in one-syllable spoken words

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Segment spoken one-syllable words into two to three phonemes (e.g., dog:/d/ ƒ/o/ ƒ/g/)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading Skills/Phonics. Students use the relationships between letters and sounds, spelling patterns, and morphological analysis to decode written English.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the common sounds that letters represent

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use knowledge of letter-sound relationships to decode regular words in text and independent of content (e.g., VC, CVC, CCVC, and CVCC words)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize that new words are created when letters are changed, added, or deleted

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and read at least 25 high-frequency words from a commonly used list

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading/Strategies. Students comprehend a variety of texts drawing on useful strategies as needed

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Predict what might happen next in text based on the cover, title, and illustrations

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Ask and respond to questions about texts read aloud
Keywords: story map, who what where when, plot setting characters, text to self, world,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it correctly when reading and writing.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and use words that name actions, directions, positions, sequences, and locations

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize that compound words are made up of shorter words

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and sort pictures of objects into conceptual categories (e.g., colors, shapes, textures)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a picture dictionary to find words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify elements of a story including setting, character, and key events

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Discuss the big idea (theme) of a well-known folktale or fable and connect it to personal experience;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize sensory details
Keywords: smell, sound, look, taste, touch, feel, infer,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize recurring phrases and characters in traditional fairy tales, lullabies, and folktales from various cultures.
Keywords: once upon a time, compare and contrast, ideas, characters, events,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to respond to rhythm and rhyme in poetry through identifying a regular beat and similarities in word sounds.
Keywords: rhyming words and patterns, alliteration, word families, chants, fingerplays,nursery rhymes, choral reading,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Retell a main event from a story read aloud
Keywords: beginning, middle, end, cause and effect,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe characters in a story and the reasons for their actions.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to identify the topic of an informational text heard.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text, and provide evidence from text to support their understanding.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the topic and details in expository text heard or read, referring to the words and/or illustrations;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Retell important facts in a text, heard or read;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Discuss the ways authors group information in text;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use titles and illustrations to make predictions about text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow pictorial directions (e.g., recipes, science experiments);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the meaning of specific signs (e.g., traffic signs, warning signs).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify different forms of media (e.g., advertisements, newspapers, radio programs);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify techniques used in media (e.g., sound, movement)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by generating ideas for writing through class discussion

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by sequencing the action or details in the story;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts by adding details or sentences;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts by leaving spaces between letters and words

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Share writing with others

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Dictate or write sentences to tell a story and put the sentences in chronological sequence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write short poems.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to dictate or write information for lists, captions, or invitations.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Understand and use the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking (with adult assistance):

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Past and future tenses when speaking;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Nouns (singular/plural)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Descriptive words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Prepositions and simple prepositional phrases appropriately when speaking or writing (e.g., in, on, under, over);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Pronouns (e.g., I, me);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Speak in complete sentences to communicate;
Keywords: peers, teacher, question and answer books, Are you my mother?,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use complete simple sentences

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions.
Keywords: D'nealian, Zaner-Bloser Script, Cursive, block pring,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Form upper- and lower-case letters legibly using the basic conventions of print (left-to-right and top-to-bottom progression)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Capitalize the first letter in a sentence

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use punctuation at the end of a sentence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use phonological knowledge to match sounds to letters

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use letter-sound correspondences to spell consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words (e.g., cut);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write one's own name.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Research Plan. Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Ask questions about topics of class-wide interest;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Decide what sources or people in the classroom, school, library, or home can answer these questions

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Gathering Sources. Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather.
Keywords: internet, books, word wall, bulletin board, expert,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Gather evidence from provided text sources

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use pictures in conjunction with writing when documenting research.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen attentively by facing speakers and asking questions to clarify information
Keywords: conversation, read aloud, shared reading, follow direction,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow oral directions that involve a short related sequence of actions

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to share information and ideas by speaking audibly and clearly using the conventions of language.
Keywords: speaking in complete sentences, responding appropriately to questions, eye contact, etiquette,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to follow agreed-upon rules for discussion, including taking turns and speaking one at a time.
Keywords: class rules, class meetings, raise hands, consistency,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading Skills/Print Awareness. Students understand how English is written and printed.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize that spoken words are represented in written English by specific sequences of letters
Keywords: interactive wrting, reading books poetry, word walls, labels signs,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify upper- and lower-case letters

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Sequence the letters of the alphabet

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize the distinguishing features of a sentence (e.g., capitalization of first word, ending punctuation)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Read texts by moving from top to bottom of the page and tracking words from left to right with return sweep;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the information that different parts of a book provide (e.g., title, author, illustrator, table of contents).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading Skills/Phonological Awareness. Students display phonological awareness.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Orally generate a series of original rhyming words using a variety of phonograms (e.g., -ake, -ant, -ain) and consonant blends (e.g., bl, st, tr);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish between long- and short-vowel sounds in spoken one-syllable words (e.g., bit/bite)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize the change in a spoken word when a specified phoneme is added, changed, or removed (e.g.,/b/l/o/w/ to/g/l/o/w/);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Blend spoken phonemes to form one- and two-syllable words, including consonant blends (e.g., spr);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Isolate initial, medial, and final sounds in one-syllable spoken words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Segment spoken one-syllable words of three to five phonemes into individual phonemes (e.g., splat =/s/p/l/a/t/).ment spoken one-syllable words of three to five phonemes into individual phonemes (e.g., splat =/s/p/l/a/t/).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading Skills/Phonics. Students use the relationships between letters and sounds, spelling patterns, and morphological analysis to decode written English. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Decode words in context and in isolation by applying common letter-sound correspondences,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Single letters (consonants) including b, c=/k/, c=/s/, d, f, g=/g/ (hard), g=/j/ (soft), h, j, k, l, m, n, p, qu=/kw/, r, s=/s/, s=/z/, t, v, w, x=/ks/, y, and z;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Single letters (vowels) including short a, short e, short i, short o, short u, long a (a-e), long e (e), long i (i-e), long o (o-e), long u (u-e), y=long e, and y=long i;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Consonant blends (e.g., bl, st)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Consonant digraphs including ch, tch, sh, th=as in thing, wh, ng, ck, kn, -dge, and ph

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Vowel digraphs including oo as in foot, oo as in moon, ea as in eat, ea as in bread, ee, ow as in how, ow as in snow, ou as in out, ay,ai, aw, au, ew, oa, ie as in chief, ie as in pie, and -igh

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Vowel diphthongs including oy, oi, ou, and ow;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Combine sounds from letters and common spelling patterns (e.g., consonant blends, long- and short-vowel patterns) to create recognizable words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use common syllabication patterns to decode words,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Closed syllable (CVC) (e.g., mat, rab-bit);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Open syllable (CV) (e.g., he, ba-by);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Final stable syllable (e.g., ap-ple, a-ble)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Vowel-consonant-silent e words (VCe) (e.g., kite, hide)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Vowel digraphs and diphthongs (e.g., boy-hood, oat-meal)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: R-controlled vowel sounds (e.g., tar); including er, ir, ur, ar, and or);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Decode words with common spelling patterns (e.g., -ink, -onk, -ick);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Read base words with inflectional endings (e.g., plurals, past tenses);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use knowledge of the meaning of base words to identify and read common compound words (e.g., football, popcorn, daydream)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and read contractions (e.g., isn't, can't)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and read at least 100 high-frequency words from a commonly used list;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Monitor accuracy of decoding

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Beginning Reading/Strategies. Students comprehend a variety of texts drawing on useful strategies as needed

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Confirm predictions about what will happen next in text by reading the part that tells

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Ask relevant questions, seek clarification, and locate facts and details about stories and other texts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Establish purpose for reading selected texts and monitor comprehension, making corrections and adjustments when that understanding breaks down (e.g., identifying clues, using background knowledge, generating questions, re-reading a portion aloud).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Fluency. Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Students are expected to read aloud grade-level appropriate text with fluency (rate, accuracy, expression, appropriate phrasing) and comprehension.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify words that name actions (verbs) and words that name persons, places, or things (nouns)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of compound words using knowledge of the meaning of their individual component words (e.g., lunchtime)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine what words mean from how they are used in a sentence, either heard or read

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and sort words into conceptual categories (e.g., opposites, living things);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Alphabetize a series of words to the first or second letter and use a dictionary to find words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding.
Keywords: read for pleasure, acquire info, distinguish between genre, story, poem, info,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Connect the meaning of a well-known story or fable to personal experiences;
Keywords: infer main idea, cause and effect, make prediction, draw conclusion,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the function of recurring phrases (e.g., Once upon a time or They lived happily ever after) in traditional folk- and fairy tales.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to respond to and use rhythm, rhyme, and alliteration in poetry.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe the plot (problem and solution) and retell a story's beginning, middle, and end with attention to the sequence of events;
Keywords: act out, important event, sequence order,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe characters in a story and the reasons for their actions and feelings.
Keywords: analyze characterizatoin, character traits, feelings, relationships, changes,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and respond by providing evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to determine whether a story is true or a fantasy and explain why.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to recognize sensory details in literary text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Text/Independent Reading. Students read independently for sustained periods of time and produce evidence of their reading. Students are expected to read independently for a sustained period of time.
