Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to identify what the author is trying to persuade the reader to think or do.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow and explain a set of written multi-step directions

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Locate and use specific information in graphic features of text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Understand how communication changes when moving from one genre of media to another
Keywords: print to visual, movie to book,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain how various design techniques used in media influence the message (e.g., shape, color, sound);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare various written conventions used for digital media (e.g., language in an informal e-mail vs. language in a web-based news article).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting a genre appropriate for conveying the intended meaning to an audience and generating ideas through a range of strategies (e.g., brainstorming, graphic organizers, logs, journals)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by categorizing ideas and organizing them into paragraphs

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts for coherence, organization, use of simple and compound sentences, and audience

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling using a teacher-developed rubric;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Publish written work for a specific audience

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write imaginative stories that build the plot to a climax and contain details about the characters and setting;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write poems that convey sensory details using the conventions of poetry (e.g., rhyme, meter, patterns of verse).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing. Students write about their own experiences. Students are expected to write about important personal experiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Create brief compositions that

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Establish a central idea in a topic sentence

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Include supporting sentences with simple facts, details, and explanations

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Contain a concluding statement

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write letters whose language is tailored to the audience and purpose (e.g., a thank you note to a friend) and that use appropriate conventions (e.g., date, salutation, closing)
Keywords: express, discover, record, develop, reflect on ideas,, problem solve,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write responses to literary or expository texts that demonstrate an understanding of the text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write persuasive essays for appropriate audiences that establish a position and use supporting details.
Keywords: express, discover, record, develop, reflect on ideas,, problem solve,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Verbs (past, present, and future)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Nouns (singular/plural, common/proper)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adjectives (e.g., descriptive: wooden, rectangular; limiting: this, that; articles: a, an, the)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adverbs (e.g., time: before, next; manner: carefully, beautifully)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Prepositions and prepositional phrases

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Possessive pronouns (e.g., his, hers, theirs)

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Coordinating conjunctions (e.g., and, or, but);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Time-order transition words and transitions that indicate a conclusion

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use the complete subject and the complete predicate in a sentence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use complete simple and compound sentences with correct subject-verb agreement

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write legibly in cursive script with spacing between words in a sentence
Keywords: pencil grip, paper position, correct letter formation, size, spacing,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use capitalization for

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Geographical names and places

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Historical periods

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Official titles of people

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize and use punctuation marks including

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Apostrophes in contractions and possessives

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Commas in series and dates
Keywords: day, year, letter greeting, compound sentences, separate 2 adjective,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use correct mechanics including paragraph indentations

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use knowledge of letter sounds, word parts, word segmentation, and syllabication to spell;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell words with more advanced orthographic patterns and rules

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell high-frequency and compound words from a commonly used list;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell words with common syllable constructions (e.g., closed, open, final stable syllable);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell single syllable homophones (e.g., bear/bare; week/weak; road/rode);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell complex contractions (e.g., should've, won't); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use print and electronic resources to find and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Research Plan. Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Generate research topics from personal interests or by brainstorming with others, narrow to one topic, and formulate open-ended questions about the major research topic; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Generate a research plan for gathering relevant information (e.g., surveys, interviews, encyclopedias) about the major research question.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Gathering Sources. Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow the research plan to collect information from multiple sources of information, both oral and written, including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Student-initiated surveys, on-site inspections, and interviews;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Data from experts, reference texts, and online searches; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Visual sources of information (e.g., maps, timelines, graphs) where appropriate;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use skimming and scanning techniques to identify data by looking at text features (e.g., bold print, captions, key words, italics);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Take simple notes and sort evidence into provided categories or an organizer;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the author, title, publisher, and publication year of sources; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between paraphrasing and plagiarism and identify the importance of citing valid and reliable sources.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Synthesizing Information. Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information. Students are expected to improve the focus of research as a result of consulting expert sources (e.g., reference librarians and local experts on the topic).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Organizing and Presenting Ideas. Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of the research and their audience. Students are expected to draw conclusions through a brief written explanation and create a works-cited page from notes, including the author, title, publisher, and publication year for each source used.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen attentively to speakers, ask relevant questions, and make pertinent comments; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow, restate, and give oral instructions that involve a series of related sequences of action.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to speak coherently about the topic under discussion, employing eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, and the conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate in teacher- and student-led discussions by posing and answering questions with appropriate detail and by providing suggestions that build upon the ideas of others.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Fluency. Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Students are expected to read aloud grade-level stories with fluency (rate, accuracy, expression, appropriate phrasing) and comprehension.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level academic English words derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use the context of the sentence (e.g., in-sentence example or definition) to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words or multiple meaning words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Complete analogies using knowledge of antonyms and synonyms (e.g., boy:girl as male:____ or girl:woman as boy:_____);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the meaning of common idioms; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary or glossary to determine the meanings, syllabication, and pronunciation of unknown words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize and explain the lesson or message of a work of fiction as its theme; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the adventures or exploits of characters (e.g., the trickster) in traditional and classical literature.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain how the structural elements of poetry (e.g., rhyme, meter, stanzas, line breaks) relate to form (e.g., lyrical poetry, free verse).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to describe the structural elements particular to dramatic literature.
Keywords: perspective, point of view, play, script,

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Sequence and summarize the plot's main events and explain their influence on future events;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe the interaction of characters including their relationships and the changes they undergo; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to identify similarities and differences between the events and characters' experiences in a fictional work and the actual events and experiences described in an author's biography or autobiography.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to identify the author's use of similes and metaphors to produce imagery.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Text/Independent Reading. Students read independently for sustained periods of time and produce evidence of their reading. Students are expected to read independently for a sustained period of time and paraphrase what the reading was about, maintaining meaning and logical order (e.g., generate a reading log or journal; participate in book talks).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the difference between a stated and an implied purpose for an expository text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize the main idea and supporting details in text in ways that maintain meaning;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish fact from opinion in a text and explain how to verify what is a fact;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe explicit and implicit relationships among ideas in texts organized by cause-and-effect, sequence, or comparison; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use multiple text features (e.g., guide words, topic and concluding sentences) to gain an overview of the contents of text and to locate information.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to explain how an author uses language to present information to influence what the reader thinks or does.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the sequence of activities needed to carry out a procedure (e.g., following a recipe); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain factual information presented graphically (e.g., charts, diagrams, graphs, illustrations).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the positive and negative impacts of advertisement techniques used in various genres of media to impact consumer behavior;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain how various design techniques used in media influence the message (e.g., pacing, close-ups, sound effects); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare various written conventions used for digital media (e.g. language in an informal e-mail vs. language in a web-based news article).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting a genre appropriate for conveying the intended meaning to an audience and generating ideas through a range of strategies (e.g., brainstorming, graphic organizers, logs, journals);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by categorizing ideas and organizing them into paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts for coherence, organization, use of simple and compound sentences, and audience;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling using a teacher-developed rubric; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for a specific audience.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write imaginative stories that build the plot to a climax and contain details about the characters and setting; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write poems that convey sensory details using the conventions of poetry (e.g., rhyme, meter, patterns of verse).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing. Students write about their own experiences. Students are expected to write about important personal experiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Create brief compositions that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Establish a central idea in a topic sentence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Include supporting sentences with simple facts, details, and explanations; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Contain a concluding statement;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write letters whose language is tailored to the audience and purpose (e.g., a thank you note to a friend) and that use appropriate conventions (e.g., date, salutation, closing); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write responses to literary or expository texts and provide evidence from the text to demonstrate understanding.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write persuasive essays for appropriate audiences that establish a position and use supporting details.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Verbs (irregular verbs);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Nouns (singular/plural, common/proper);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adjectives (e.g., descriptive, including purpose: sleeping bag, frying pan) and their comparative and superlative forms (e.g., fast, faster, fastest);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adverbs (e.g., frequency: usually, sometimes; intensity: almost, a lot);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Prepositions and prepositional phrases to convey location, time, direction, or to provide details;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reflexive pronouns (e.g., myself, ourselves);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Correlative conjunctions (e.g., either/or, neither/nor); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use time-order transition words and transitions that indicate a conclusion;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use the complete subject and the complete predicate in a sentence; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use complete simple and compound sentences with correct subject-verb agreement.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write legibly by selecting cursive script or manuscript printing as appropriate;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use capitalization for:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Historical events and documents;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Titles of books, stories, and essays; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Languages, races, and nationalities; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize and use punctuation marks including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Commas in compound sentences; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Quotation marks.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell words with more advanced orthographic patterns and rules:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plural rules (e.g., words ending in f as in leaf, leaves; adding -es);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Irregular plurals (e.g., man/men, foot/feet, child/children);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Double consonants in middle of words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Other ways to spell sh (e.g., -sion, -tion, -cian); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Silent letters (e.g., knee, wring);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell base words and roots with affixes (e.g., -ion, -ment, -ly, dis-, pre-);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell commonly used homophones (e.g., there, they're, their; two, too, to); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use spelling patterns and rules and print and electronic resources to determine and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Generate a research plan for gathering relevant information (e.g., surveys, interviews, encyclopedias) about the major research question.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow the research plan to collect information from multiple sources of information both oral and written, including:

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Data from experts, reference texts, and online searches; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Visual sources of information (e.g., maps, timelines, graphs) where appropriate;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use skimming and scanning techniques to identify data by looking at text features (e.g., bold print, italics);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Take simple notes and sort evidence into provided categories or an organizer;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the author, title, publisher, and publication year of sources; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between paraphrasing and plagiarism and identify the importance of citing valid and reliable sources.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Synthesizing Information. Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information. Students are expected to improve the focus of research as a result of consulting expert sources (e.g., reference librarians and local experts on the topic).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Organizing and Presenting Ideas. Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of the research and their audience. Students are expected to draw conclusions through a brief written explanation and create a works-cited page from notes, including the author, title, publisher, and publication year for each source used.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen attentively to speakers, ask relevant questions, and make pertinent comments; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow, restate, and give oral instructions that involve a series of related sequences of action.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to express an opinion supported by accurate information, employing eye contact, speaking rate, volume, and enunciation, and the conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate in teacher- and student-led discussions by posing and answering questions with appropriate detail and by providing suggestions that build upon the ideas of others.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Fluency. Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Students are expected to read aloud grade-level stories with fluency (rate, accuracy, expression, appropriate phrasing) and comprehension.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level academic English words derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use context (e.g., in-sentence restatement) to determine or clarify the meaning of unfamiliar or multiple meaning words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce analogies with known antonyms and synonyms;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and other sayings; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary, a glossary, or a thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine the meanings, syllabication, pronunciations, alternate word choices, and parts of speech of words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the themes or moral lessons of several works of fiction from various cultures;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe the phenomena explained in origin myths from various cultures; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the effect of a historical event or movement on the theme of a work of literature.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how poets use sound effects (e.g., alliteration, internal rhyme, onomatopoeia, rhyme scheme) to reinforce meaning in poems.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the similarities and differences between an original text and its dramatic adaptation.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe incidents that advance the story or novel, explaining how each incident gives rise to or foreshadows future events;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the roles and functions of characters in various plots, including their relationships and conflicts; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain different forms of third-person points of view in stories.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe incidents that advance the story or novel, explaining how each incident gives rise to or foreshadows future events;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the roles and functions of characters in various plots, including their relationships and conflicts; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain different forms of third-person points of view in stories.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to identify the literary language and devices used in biographies and autobiographies, including how authors present major events in a person's life.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to evaluate the impact of sensory details, imagery, and figurative language in literary text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Text/Independent Reading. Students read independently for sustained periods of time and produce evidence of their reading. Students are expected to read independently for a sustained period of time and summarize or paraphrase what the reading was about, maintaining meaning and logical order (e.g., generate a reading log or journal; participate in book talks).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to draw conclusions from the information presented by an author and evaluate how well the author's purpose was achieved.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize the main ideas and supporting details in a text in ways that maintain meaning and logical order;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the facts in text and verify them through established methods;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how the organizational pattern of a text (e.g., cause-and-effect, compare-and-contrast, sequential order, logical order, classification schemes) influences the relationships among the ideas;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use multiple text features and graphics to gain an overview of the contents of text and to locate information; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize and make logical connections between ideas within a text and across two or three texts representing similar or different genres.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the author's viewpoint or position and explain the basic relationships among ideas (e.g., parallelism, comparison, causality) in the argument; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize exaggerated, contradictory, or misleading statements in text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Interpret details from procedural text to complete a task, solve a problem, or perform procedures; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Interpret factual or quantitative information presented in maps, charts, illustrations, graphs, timelines, tables, and diagrams.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain how messages conveyed in various forms of media are presented differently (e.g., documentaries, online information, televised news);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Consider the difference in techniques used in media (e.g., commercials, documentaries, news);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the point of view of media presentations; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze various digital media venues for levels of formality and informality.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting a genre appropriate for conveying the intended meaning to an audience, determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies (e.g., discussion, background reading, personal interests, interviews), and developing a thesis or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by choosing an appropriate organizational strategy (e.g., sequence of events, cause-effect, compare-contrast) and building on ideas to create a focused, organized, and coherent piece of writing;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts to clarify meaning, enhance style, include simple and compound sentences, and improve transitions by adding, deleting, combining, and rearranging sentences or larger units of text after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write imaginative stories that include:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clearly defined focus, plot, and point of view;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A specific, believable setting created through the use of sensory details; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Dialogue that develops the story; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write poems using:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Poetic techniques (e.g., alliteration, onomatopoeia);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Figurative language (e.g., similes, metaphors); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Graphic elements (e.g., capital letters, line length).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing. Students write about their own experiences. Students are expected to write a personal narrative that conveys thoughts and feelings about an experience.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Create multi-paragraph essays to convey information about the topic that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Present effective introductions and concluding paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Guide and inform the reader's understanding of key ideas and evidence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Include specific facts, details, and examples in an appropriately organized structure; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a variety of sentence structures and transitions to link paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write formal and informal letters that convey ideas, include important information, demonstrate a sense of closure, and use appropriate conventions (e.g., date, salutation, closing); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write responses to literary or expository texts and provide evidence from the text to demonstrate understanding.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write persuasive essays for appropriate audiences that establish a position and include sound reasoning, detailed and relevant evidence, and consideration of alternatives.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Verbs (irregular verbs and active voice);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Collective nouns (e.g., class, public);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adjectives (e.g., descriptive, including origins: French windows, American cars) and their comparative and superlative forms (e.g., good, better, best);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adverbs (e.g., frequency: usually, sometimes; intensity: almost, a lot);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Prepositions and prepositional phrases to convey location, time, direction, or to provide details;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Indefinite pronouns (e.g., all, both, nothing, anything);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Subordinating conjunctions (e.g., while, because, although, if); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Transitional words (e.g., also, therefore);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use the complete subject and the complete predicate in a sentence; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use complete simple and compound sentences with correct subject-verb agreement.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use capitalization for:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Abbreviations;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Initials and acronyms; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Organizations;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize and use punctuation marks including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Commas in compound sentences; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Proper punctuation and spacing for quotations; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use proper mechanics including italics and underlining for titles and emphasis.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell words with more advanced orthographic patterns and rules:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Consonant changes (e.g.,/t/ to/sh/ in select, selection;/k/ to/sh/ in music, musician);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Vowel changes (e.g., long to short in crime, criminal; long to schwa in define, definition; short to schwa in legality, legal); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Silent and sounded consonants (e.g., haste, hasten; sign, signal; condemn, condemnation);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Spell words with:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Greek Roots (e.g., tele, photo, graph, meter);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Latin Roots (e.g., spec, scrib, rupt, port, ject, dict);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Greek suffixes (e.g., -ology, -phobia, -ism, -ist); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Latin derived suffixes (e.g., -able, -ible; -ance, -ence);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between commonly confused terms (e.g., its, it's; affect, effect);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use spelling patterns and rules and print and electronic resources to determine and check correct spellings; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Know how to use the spell-check function in word processing while understanding its limitations.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Research Plan. Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Brainstorm, consult with others, decide upon a topic, and formulate open-ended questions to address the major research topic; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Generate a research plan for gathering relevant information about the major research question.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Gathering Sources. Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow the research plan to collect data from a range of print and electronic resources (e.g., reference texts, periodicals, web pages, online sources) and data from experts;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between primary and secondary sources;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Record data, utilizing available technology (e.g., word processors) in order to see the relationships between ideas, and convert graphic/visual data (e.g., charts, diagrams, timelines) into written notes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the source of notes (e.g., author, title, page number) and record bibliographic information concerning those sources according to a standard format; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between paraphrasing and plagiarism and identify the importance of citing valid and reliable sources.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Synthesizing Information. Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Refine the major research question, if necessary, guided by the answers to a secondary set of questions; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the relevance, validity, and reliability of sources for the research.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Organizing and Presenting Ideas. Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of the research and their audience. Students are expected to synthesize the research into a written or an oral presentation that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compiles important information from multiple sources;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develops a topic sentence, summarizes findings, and uses evidence to support conclusions;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Presents the findings in a consistent format; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses quotations to support ideas and an appropriate form of documentation to acknowledge sources (e.g., bibliography, works cited).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen to and interpret a speaker's messages (both verbal and nonverbal) and ask questions to clarify the speaker's purpose or perspective;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow, restate, and give oral instructions that include multiple action steps; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine both main and supporting ideas in the speaker's message.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to give organized presentations employing eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, natural gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate in student-led discussions by eliciting and considering suggestions from other group members and by identifying points of agreement and disagreement.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Fluency. Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Students are expected to adjust fluency when reading aloud grade-level text based on the reading purpose and the nature of the text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level academic English words derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use context (e.g., cause and effect or compare and contrast organizational text structures) to determine or clarify the meaning of unfamiliar or multiple meaning words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Complete analogies that describe part to whole or whole to part (e.g., ink:pen as page: ____ or pen:ink as book: _____);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the meaning of foreign words and phrases commonly used in written English (e.g., RSVP, que sera sera); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary, a glossary, or a thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine the meanings, syllabication, pronunciations, alternate word choices, and parts of speech of words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Infer the implicit theme of a work of fiction, distinguishing theme from the topic;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the function of stylistic elements (e.g., magic helper, rule of three) in traditional and classical literature from various cultures; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the historical and cultural settings of two literary works.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain how figurative language (e.g., personification, metaphors, similes, hyperbole) contributes to the meaning of a poem.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the similarities and differences in the setting, characters, and plot of a play and those in a film based upon the same story line.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize the elements of plot development (e.g., rising action, turning point, climax, falling action, denouement) in various works of fiction;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize dialect and conversational voice and explain how authors use dialect to convey character; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe different forms of point-of-view, including first- and third-person.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to identify the literary language and devices used in memoirs and personal narratives and compare their characteristics with those of an autobiography.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain how authors create meaning through stylistic elements and figurative language emphasizing the use of personification, hyperbole, and refrains.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to compare and contrast the stated or implied purposes of different authors writing on the same topic.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize the main ideas and supporting details in text, demonstrating an understanding that a summary does not include opinions;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain whether facts included in an argument are used for or against an issue;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain how different organizational patterns (e.g., proposition-and-support, problem-and-solution) develop the main idea and the author's viewpoint; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize and make logical connections between ideas within a text and across two or three texts representing similar or different genres.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the structure and viewpoints of two different authors writing for the same purpose, noting the stated claim and supporting evidence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify simply faulty reasoning used in persuasive texts.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow multi-tasked instructions to complete a task, solve a problem, or perform procedures; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Interpret factual, quantitative, or technical information presented in maps, charts, illustrations, graphs, timelines, tables, and diagrams.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain messages conveyed in various forms of media;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize how various techniques influence viewers' emotions;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Critique persuasive techniques (e.g., testimonials, bandwagon appeal) used in media messages; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze various digital media venues for levels of formality and informality.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting a genre appropriate for conveying the intended meaning to an audience, determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies (e.g., discussion, background reading, personal interests, interviews), and developing a thesis or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by choosing an appropriate organizational strategy (e.g., sequence of events, cause-effect, compare-contrast) and building on ideas to create a focused, organized, and coherent piece of writing;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts to clarify meaning, enhance style, include simple and compound sentences, and improve transitions by adding, deleting, combining, and rearranging sentences or larger units of text after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Poetic techniques (e.g., alliteration, onomatopoeia);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Figurative language (e.g., similes, metaphors); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Graphic elements (e.g., capital letters, line length).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing. Students write about their own experiences. Students are expected to write a personal narrative that has a clearly defined focus and communicates the importance of or reasons for actions and/or consequences.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Present effective introductions and concluding paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Guide and inform the reader's understanding of key ideas and evidence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Include specific facts, details, and examples in an appropriately organized structure; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a variety of sentence structures and transitions to link paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write informal letters that convey ideas, include important information, demonstrate a sense of closure, and use appropriate conventions (e.g., date, salutation, closing);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write responses to literary or expository texts and provide evidence from the text to demonstrate understanding; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce a multimedia presentation involving text and graphics using available technology.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write persuasive essays for appropriate audiences that establish a position and include sound reasoning, detailed and relevant evidence, and consideration of alternatives.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Verbs (irregular verbs and active and passive voice);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Non-count nouns (e.g., rice, paper);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Predicate adjectives (She is intelligent.) and their comparative and superlative forms (e.g., many, more, most);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Conjunctive adverbs (e.g., consequently, furthermore, indeed);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Prepositions and prepositional phrases to convey location, time, direction, or to provide details;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Indefinite pronouns (e.g., all, both, nothing, anything);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Subordinating conjunctions (e.g., while, because, although, if); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Transitional words and phrases that demonstrate an understanding of the function of the transition related to the organization of the writing (e.g., on the contrary, in addition to);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between the active and passive voice and know how to use them both; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use complete simple and compound sentences with correct subject-verb agreement.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use capitalization for:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Abbreviations;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Initials and acronyms; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Organizations;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize and use punctuation marks including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Commas in compound sentences;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Proper punctuation and spacing for quotations; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Parentheses, brackets, and ellipses (to indicate omissions and interruptions or incomplete statements); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use proper mechanics including italics and underlining for titles of books.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between commonly confused terms (e.g., its, it's; affect, effect);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use spelling patterns and rules and print and electronic resources to determine and check correct spellings; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Know how to use the spell-check function in word processing while understanding its limitations.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow and give oral instructions that include multiple action steps; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Paraphrase the major ideas and supporting evidence in formal and informal presentations.

Subject: English Language Arts
