Students are expected to give an organized presentation with a specific point of view, employing eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, natural gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate in student-led discussions by eliciting and considering suggestions from other group members and by identifying points of agreement and disagreement.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Fluency. Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Students are expected to adjust fluency when reading aloud grade-level text based on the reading purpose and the nature of the text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level academic English words derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to determine or clarify the meaning of unfamiliar or ambiguous words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Complete analogies that describe part to whole or whole to part;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify the meaning of foreign words commonly used in written English with emphasis on Latin and Greek words (e.g., habeus corpus, e pluribus unum, bona fide, nemesis);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary, a glossary, or a thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine the meanings, syllabication, pronunciations, alternate word choices, and parts of speech of words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe multiple themes in a work of fiction;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe conventions in myths and epic tales (e.g., extended simile, the quest, the hero's tasks, circle stories); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how place and time influence the theme or message of a literary work.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the importance of graphical elements (e.g., capital letters, line length, word position) on the meaning of a poem.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain a playwright's use of dialogue and stage directions.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the influence of the setting on plot development;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the development of the plot through the internal and external responses of the characters, including their motivations and conflicts; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze different forms of point of view, including first-person, third-person omniscient, and third-person limited.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to describe the structural and substantive differences between an autobiography or a diary and a fictional adaptation of it.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to determine the figurative meaning of phrases and analyze how an author's use of language creates imagery, appeals to the senses, and suggests mood.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the difference between the theme of a literary work and the author's purpose in an expository text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate a summary of the original text for accuracy of the main ideas, supporting details, and overall meaning;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish factual claims from commonplace assertions and opinions;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use different organizational patterns as guides for summarizing and forming an overview of different kinds of expository text; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize and make logical connections between ideas within a text and across two or three texts representing similar or different genres, and support those findings with textual evidence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the structure of the central argument in contemporary policy speeches (e.g., argument by cause and effect, analogy, authority) and identify the different types of evidence used to support the argument; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify such rhetorical fallacies as ad hominem, exaggeration, stereotyping, or categorical claims in persuasive texts.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow multi-dimensional instructions from text to complete a task, solve a problem, or perform procedures; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain the function of the graphical components of a text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Interpret both explicit and implicit messages in various forms of media;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Interpret how visual and sound techniques (e.g., special effects, camera angles, lighting, music) influence the message;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate various ways media influences and informs audiences; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Assess the correct level of formality and tone for successful participation in various digital media.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting a genre appropriate for conveying the intended meaning to an audience, determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies (e.g., discussion, background reading, personal interests, interviews), and developing a thesis or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by choosing an appropriate organizational strategy (e.g., sequence of events, cause-effect, compare-contrast) and building on ideas to create a focused, organized, and coherent piece of writing;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts to ensure precise word choice and vivid images; consistent point of view; use of simple, compound, and complex sentences; internal and external coherence; and the use of effective transitions after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an imaginative story that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Sustains reader interest;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Includes well-paced action and an engaging story line;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Creates a specific, believable setting through the use of sensory details;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develops interesting characters; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses a range of literary strategies and devices to enhance the style and tone; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a poem using:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Poetic techniques (e.g., rhyme scheme, meter);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Figurative language (e.g., personification, idioms, hyperbole); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Graphic elements (e.g., word position).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing. Students write about their own experiences. Students are expected to write a personal narrative that has a clearly defined focus and communicates the importance of or reasons for actions and/or consequences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a multi-paragraph essay to convey information about a topic that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Presents effective introductions and concluding paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Contains a clearly stated purpose or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Is logically organized with appropriate facts and details and includes no extraneous information or inconsistencies;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Accurately synthesizes ideas from several sources; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses a variety of sentence structures, rhetorical devices, and transitions to link paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a letter that reflects an opinion, registers a complaint, or requests information in a business or friendly context;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write responses to literary or expository texts that demonstrate the writing skills for multi-paragraph essays and provide sustained evidence from the text using quotations when appropriate; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce a multimedia presentation involving text and graphics using available technology.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write a persuasive essay to the appropriate audience that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Establishes a clear thesis or position;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Considers and responds to the views of others and anticipates and answers reader concerns and counter-arguments; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Includes evidence that is logically organized to support the author's viewpoint and that differentiates between fact and opinion.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify, use, and understand the function of the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Verbs (perfect and progressive tenses) and participles;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Appositive phrases;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Adverbial and adjectival phrases and clauses;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Conjunctive adverbs (e.g., consequently, furthermore, indeed);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Prepositions and prepositional phrases and their influence on subject-verb agreement;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relative pronouns (e.g., whose, that, which);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Subordinating conjunctions (e.g., because, since); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Transitions for sentence to sentence or paragraph to paragraph coherence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write complex sentences and differentiate between main versus subordinate clauses; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a variety of complete sentences (e.g., simple, compound, complex) that include properly placed modifiers, correctly identified antecedents, parallel structures, and consistent tenses.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use conventions of capitalization; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Recognize and use punctuation marks including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Commas after introductory words, phrases, and clauses; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Semicolons, colons, and hyphens.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Research Plan. Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Brainstorm, consult with others, decide upon a topic, and formulate a major research question to address the major research topic; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Apply steps for obtaining and evaluating information from a wide variety of sources and create a written plan after preliminary research in reference works and additional text searches.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Gathering Sources. Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow the research plan to gather information from a range of relevant print and electronic sources using advanced search strategies;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Categorize information thematically in order to see the larger constructs inherent in the information;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Record bibliographic information (e.g., author, title, page number) for all notes and sources according to a standard format; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between paraphrasing and plagiarism and identify the importance of citing valid and reliable sources.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Synthesizing Information. Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Narrow or broaden the major research question, if necessary, based on further research and investigation; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Utilize elements that demonstrate the reliability and validity of the sources used (e.g., publication date, coverage, language, point of view) and explain why one source is more useful than another.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Organizing and Presenting Ideas. Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of the research and their audience. Students are expected to synthesize the research into a written or an oral presentation that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Draws conclusions and summarizes or paraphrases the findings in a systematic way;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Marshals evidence to explain the topic and gives relevant reasons for conclusions;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Presents the findings in a meaningful format; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follows accepted formats for integrating quotations and citations into the written text to maintain a flow of ideas.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students will use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen to and interpret a speaker's purpose by explaining the content, evaluating the delivery of the presentation, and asking questions or making comments about the evidence that supports a speaker's claims;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, or solve problems; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Draw conclusions about the speaker's message by considering verbal communication (e.g., word choice, tone) and nonverbal cues (e.g., posture, gestures, facial expressions).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to present a critique of a literary work, film, or dramatic production, employing eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, a variety of natural gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate productively in discussions, plan agendas with clear goals and deadlines, set time limits for speakers, take notes, and vote on key issues.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Fluency. Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. Students are expected to adjust fluency when reading aloud grade-level text based on the reading purpose and the nature of the text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level academic English words derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to determine or clarify the meaning of unfamiliar or ambiguous words or words with novel meanings;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Complete analogies that describe a function or its description (e.g., pen:paper as chalk: ______ or soft:kitten as hard: ______);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify common words or word parts from other languages that are used in written English (e.g., phenomenon, charisma, chorus, passé, flora, fauna); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary, a glossary, or a thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine the meanings, syllabication, pronunciations, alternate word choices, and parts of speech of words.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze literary works that share similar themes across cultures;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the similarities and differences in mythologies from various cultures (e.g., ideas of afterlife, roles and characteristics of deities, purposes of myths); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain how the values and beliefs of particular characters are affected by the historical and cultural setting of the literary work.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to compare and contrast the relationship between the purpose and characteristics of different poetic forms (e.g., epic poetry, lyric poetry).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how different playwrights characterize their protagonists and antagonists through the dialogue and staging of their plays.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze linear plot developments (e.g., conflict, rising action, falling action, resolution, subplots) to determine whether and how conflicts are resolved;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how the central characters' qualities influence the theme of a fictional work and resolution of the central conflict; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze different forms of point of view, including limited versus omniscient, subjective versus objective.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze passages in well-known speeches for the author's use of literary devices and word and phrase choice (e.g., aphorisms, epigraphs) to appeal to the audience.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the effect of similes and extended metaphors in literary text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze works written on the same topic and compare how the authors achieved similar or different purposes.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize the main ideas, supporting details, and relationships among ideas in text succinctly in ways that maintain meaning and logical order;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish factual claims from commonplace assertions and opinions and evaluate inferences from their logic in text;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize and make logical connections between ideas within a text and across two or three texts representing similar or different genres and support those findings with textual evidence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast persuasive texts that reached different conclusions about the same issue and explain how the authors reached their conclusions through analyzing the evidence each presents; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the use of such rhetorical and logical fallacies as loaded terms, caricatures, leading questions, false assumptions, and incorrect premises in persuasive texts.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze text for missing or extraneous information in multi-step directions or legends for diagrams; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate graphics for their clarity in communicating meaning or achieving a specific purpose.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the role of media in focusing attention on events and informing opinion on issues;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Interpret how visual and sound techniques (e.g., special effects, camera angles, lighting, music) influence the message;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate various techniques used to create a point of view in media and the impact on audience; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Assess the correct level of formality and tone for successful participation in various digital media.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develop drafts by choosing an appropriate organizational strategy (e.g., sequence of events, cause-effect, compare-contrast) and building on ideas to create a focused, organized, and coherent piece of writing;

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Text: Use conventions of capitalization; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use correct punctuation marks, including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Commas after introductory structures and dependent adverbial clauses, and correct punctuation of complex sentences; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Semicolons, colons, hyphens, parentheses, brackets, and ellipses.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Utilize elements that demonstrate the reliability and validity of the sources used (e.g., publication date, coverage, language, point of view) and explain why one source is more useful and relevant than another.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, or solve problems; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize formal and informal presentations, distinguish between facts and opinions, and determine the effectiveness of rhetorical devices.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to advocate a position using anecdotes, analogies, and/or illustrations, and use eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, a variety of natural gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate productively in discussions, plan agendas with clear goals and deadlines, set time limits for speakers, take notes, and vote on key issues.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level technical academic English words in multiple content areas (e.g., science, mathematics, social studies, the arts) derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce analogies that describe a function of an object or its description;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Describe the origins and meanings of foreign words or phrases used frequently in written English (e.g., caveat emptor, carte blanche, tete a tete, pas de deux, bon appetit, quid pro quo); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary, a glossary, or a thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine or confirm the meanings of words and phrases, including their connotations and denotations, and their etymology.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how the genre of texts with similar themes shapes meaning;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the influence of mythic, classical and traditional literature on 20th and 21st century literature; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relate the figurative language of a literary work to its historical and cultural setting.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the effects of diction and imagery (e.g., controlling images, figurative language, understatement, overstatement, irony, paradox) in poetry.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain how dramatic conventions (e.g., monologues, soliloquies, dramatic irony) enhance dramatic text.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze non-linear plot development (e.g., flashbacks, foreshadowing, sub-plots, parallel plot structures) and compare it to linear plot development;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the way in which a work of fiction is shaped by the narrator's point of view; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrate familiarity with works by authors from non-English-speaking literary traditions with emphasis on classical literature.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how literary essays interweave personal examples and ideas with factual information to explain, present a perspective, or describe a situation or event.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the role of irony, sarcasm, and paradox in literary works.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the controlling idea and specific purpose of an expository text and distinguish the most important from the less important details that support the author's purpose.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize text and distinguish between a summary that captures the main ideas and elements of a text and a critique that takes a position and expresses an opinion;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between opinions that are substantiated and unsubstantiated in the text;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize and make logical connections between ideas and details in several texts selected to reflect a range of viewpoints on the same topic and support those findings with textual evidence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the relevance, quality, and credibility of evidence given to support or oppose an argument for a specific audience; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze famous speeches for the rhetorical structures and devices used to convince the reader of the authors' propositions.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the clarity of the objective(s) of procedural text (e.g., consider reading instructions for software, warranties, consumer publications); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze factual, quantitative, or technical data presented in multiple graphical sources.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast how events are presented and information is communicated by visual images (e.g., graphic art, illustrations, news photographs) versus non-visual texts;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how messages in media are conveyed through visual and sound techniques (e.g., editing, reaction shots, sequencing, background music);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast coverage of the same event in various media (e.g., newspapers, television, documentaries, blogs, Internet); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate changes in formality and tone within the same medium for specific audiences and purposes.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting the correct genre for conveying the intended meaning to multiple audiences, determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies (e.g., discussion, background reading, personal interests, interviews), and developing a thesis or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Structure ideas in a sustained and persuasive way (e.g., using outlines, note taking, graphic organizers, lists) and develop drafts in timed and open-ended situations that include transitions and the rhetorical devices used to convey meaning;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts to improve style, word choice, figurative language, sentence variety, and subtlety of meaning after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas. Students are responsible for at least two forms of literary writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an engaging story with a well-developed conflict and resolution, interesting and believable characters, and a range of literary strategies (e.g., dialogue, suspense) and devices to enhance the plot;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a poem using a variety of poetic techniques (e.g., structural elements, figurative language) and a variety of poetic forms (e.g., sonnets, ballads); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a script with an explicit or implicit theme and details that contribute to a definite mood or tone.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an analytical essay of sufficient length that includes:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Effective introductory and concluding paragraphs and a variety of sentence structures;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Rhetorical devices, and transitions between paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A controlling idea or thesis;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: An organizing structure appropriate to purpose, audience, and context; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relevant information and valid inferences;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write procedural or work-related documents (e.g., instructions, e-mails, correspondence, memos, project plans) that include:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Organized and accurately conveyed information; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reader-friendly formatting techniques;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an interpretative response to an expository or a literary text (e.g., essay or review) that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Extends beyond a summary and literal analysis;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Addresses the writing skills for an analytical essay and provides evidence from the text using embedded quotations; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyzes the aesthetic effects of an author's use of stylistic or rhetorical devices; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce a multimedia presentation (e.g., documentary, class newspaper, docudrama, infomercial, visual or textual parodies, theatrical production) with graphics, images, and sound that conveys a distinctive point of view and appeals to a specific audience.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write an argumentative essay to the appropriate audience that includes:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clear thesis or position based on logical reasons supported by precise and relevant evidence;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Consideration of the whole range of information and views on the topic and accurate and honest representation of these views;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Counter-arguments based on evidence to anticipate and address objections;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: An organizing structure appropriate to the purpose, audience, and context; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: An analysis of the relative value of specific data, facts, and ideas.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of the following parts of speech in the context of reading, writing, and speaking:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: More complex active and passive tenses and verbals (gerunds, infinitives, participles);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Restrictive and nonrestrictive relative clauses; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reciprocal pronouns (e.g., each other, one another);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identify and use the subjunctive mood to express doubts, wishes, and possibilities; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a variety of correctly structured sentences (e.g., compound, complex, compound-complex).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use conventions of capitalization; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use correct punctuation marks including:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Quotation marks to indicate sarcasm or irony;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Comma placement in nonrestrictive phrases, clauses, and contrasting expressions; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Dashes to emphasize parenthetical information.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Research Plan. Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Brainstorm, consult with others, decide upon a topic, and formulate a major research question to address the major research topic; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Formulate a plan for engaging in research on a complex, multi-faceted topic.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Gathering Sources. Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow the research plan to compile data from authoritative sources in a manner that identifies the major issues and debates within the field of inquiry;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Organize information gathered from multiple sources to create a variety of graphics and forms (e.g., notes, learning logs); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Paraphrase, summarize, quote, and accurately cite all researched information according to a standard format (e.g., author, title, page number).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Synthesizing Information. Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Modify the major research question as necessary to refocus the research plan;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the relevance of information to the topic and determine the reliability, validity, and accuracy of sources (including Internet sources) by examining their authority and objectivity; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Critique the research process at each step to implement changes as the need occurs and is identified.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Organizing and Presenting Ideas. Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of the research and their audience. Students are expected to synthesize the research into a written or an oral presentation that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Marshals evidence in support of a clear thesis statement and related claims;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Provides an analysis for the audience that reflects a logical progression of ideas and a clearly stated point of view;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses graphics and illustrations to help explain concepts where appropriate;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses a variety of evaluative tools (e.g., self-made rubrics, peer reviews, teacher and expert evaluations) to examine the quality of the research; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses a style manual (e.g., Modern Language Association, Chicago Manual of Style) to document sources and format written materials.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students will use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen responsively to a speaker by taking notes that summarize, synthesize, or highlight the speaker's ideas for critical reflection and by asking questions related to the content for clarification and elaboration;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, solve problems, and complete processes; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the effectiveness of a speaker's main and supporting ideas.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to give presentations using informal, formal, and technical language effectively to meet the needs of audience, purpose, and occasion, employing eye contact, speaking rate (e.g., pauses for effect), volume, enunciation, purposeful gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate productively in teams, building on the ideas of others, contributing relevant information, developing a plan for consensus-building, and setting ground rules for decision-making.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level technical academic English words in multiple content areas (e.g., science, mathematics, social studies, the arts) derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Infer word meaning through the identification and analysis of analogies and other word relationships;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Show the relationship between the origins and meaning of foreign words or phrases used frequently in written English and historical events or developments (e.g., glasnost, avant-garde, coup d'Žtat); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a dictionary, a glossary, or a thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine or confirm the meanings of words and phrases, including their connotations and denotations, and their etymology.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast differences in similar themes expressed in different time periods;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze archetypes (e.g., journey of a hero, tragic flaw) in mythic, traditional and classical literature; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relate the figurative language of a literary work to its historical and cultural setting.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the structure or prosody (e.g., meter, rhyme scheme) and graphic elements (e.g., line length, punctuation, word position) in poetry.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how archetypes and motifs in drama affect the plot of plays.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze isolated scenes and their contribution to the success of the plot as a whole in a variety of works of fiction;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze differences in the characters' moral dilemmas in works of fiction across different countries or cultures;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the connection between forms of narration (e.g., unreliable, omniscient) and tone in works of fiction; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrate familiarity with works by authors from non-English-speaking literary traditions with emphasis on 20th century world literature.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to evaluate the role of syntax and diction and the effect of voice, tone, and imagery on a speech, literary essay, or other forms of literary nonfiction.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to explain the function of symbolism, allegory, and allusions in literary works.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the controlling idea and specific purpose of a passage and the textual elements that support and elaborate it, including both the most important details and the less important details.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize text and distinguish between a summary and a critique and identify non-essential information in a summary and unsubstantiated opinions in a critique;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish among different kinds of evidence (e.g., logical, empirical, anecdotal) used to support conclusions and arguments in texts;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Make and defend subtle inferences and complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize and make logical connections between ideas and details in several texts selected to reflect a range of viewpoints on the same topic and support those findings with textual evidence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain shifts in perspective in arguments about the same topic and evaluate the accuracy of the evidence used to support the different viewpoints within those arguments; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze contemporary political debates for such rhetorical and logical fallacies as appeals to commonly held opinions, false dilemmas, appeals to pity, and personal attacks.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate text for the clarity of its graphics and its visual appeal; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize information from multiple graphical sources to draw conclusions about the ideas presented (e.g., maps, charts, schematics).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how messages presented in media reflect social and cultural views in ways different from traditional texts;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how messages in media are conveyed through visual and sound techniques (e.g., editing, reaction shots, sequencing, background music);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Examine how individual perception or bias in coverage of the same event influences the audience; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate changes in formality and tone within the same medium for specific audiences and purposes.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how the style and structure of a speech support or undermine its purpose or meaning.

Subject: English Language Arts

Students are expected to advance a coherent argument that incorporates a clear thesis and a logical progression of valid evidence from reliable sources and that employs eye contact, speaking rate (e.g., pauses for effect), volume, enunciation, purposeful gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts

Students are expected to participate productively in teams, building on the ideas of others, contributing relevant information, developing a plan for consensus-building, and setting ground rules for decision-making.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of grade-level technical academic English words in multiple content areas (e.g., science, mathematics, social studies, the arts) derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to draw conclusions about the nuance in word meanings;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Infer word meaning through the identification and analysis of analogies and other word relationships;

Text: Recognize and use knowledge of cognates in different languages and of word origins to determine the meaning of words; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use general and specialized dictionaries, thesauri, glossaries, histories of language, books of quotations, and other related references (printed or electronic) as needed.
