Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the way in which the theme or meaning of a selection represents a view or comment on the human condition;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relate the characters and text structures of mythic, traditional, and classical literature to 20th and 21st century American novels, plays, or films; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relate the main ideas found in a literary work to primary source documents from its historical and cultural setting.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the effects of metrics, rhyme schemes (e.g., end, internal, slant, eye), and other conventions in American poetry.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the themes and characteristics in different periods of modern American drama.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how different literary elements (e.g., figurative language, point of view) shape the author's portrayal of the plot and setting in works of fiction;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the internal and external development of characters through a range of literary devices;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the impact of narration when the narrator's point of view shifts from one character to another; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrate familiarity with works by authors in American fiction from each major literary period.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how rhetorical techniques (e.g., repetition, parallel structure, understatement, overstatement) in literary essays, true life adventures, and historically important speeches influence the reader, evoke emotions, and create meaning.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the meaning of classical, mythological, and biblical allusions in words, phrases, passages, and literary works.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how the style, tone, and diction of a text advance the author's purpose and perspective or stance.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize a text in a manner that captures the author's viewpoint, its main ideas, and its elements without taking a position or expressing an opinion;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Distinguish between inductive and deductive reasoning and analyze the elements of deductively and inductively reasoned texts and the different ways conclusions are supported;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Make and defend subtle inferences and complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize ideas and make logical connections (e.g., thematic links, author analyses) between and among multiple texts representing similar or different genres and technical sources and support those findings with textual evidence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how the author's purpose and stated or perceived audience affect the tone of persuasive texts; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze historical and contemporary political debates for such logical fallacies as non-sequiturs, circular logic, and hasty generalizations.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the logic of the sequence of information presented in text (e.g., product support material, contracts); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Translate (from text to graphic or from graphic to text) complex, factual, quantitative, or technical information presented in maps, charts, illustrations, graphs, timelines, tables, and diagrams.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how messages presented in media reflect social and cultural views in ways different from traditional texts;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the interactions of different techniques (e.g., layout, pictures, typeface in print media, images, text, sound in electronic journalism) used in multi-layered media;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the objectivity of coverage of the same event in various types of media; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate changes in formality and tone across various media for different audiences and purposes.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Writing Process. Students use elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing, and publishing) to compose text. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting the correct genre for conveying the intended meaning to multiple audiences, determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies (e.g., discussion, background reading, personal interests, interviews), and developing a thesis or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Structure ideas in a sustained and persuasive way (e.g., using outlines, note taking, graphic organizers, lists) and develop drafts in timed and open-ended situations that include transitions and rhetorical devices to convey meaning;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise drafts to clarify meaning and achieve specific rhetorical purposes, consistency of tone, and logical organization by rearranging the words, sentences, and paragraphs to employ tropes (e.g., metaphors, similes, analogies, hyperbole, understatement, rhetorical questions, irony), schemes (e.g., parallelism, antithesis, inverted word order, repetition, reversed structures), and by adding transitional words and phrases;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Literary Texts. Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined people, events, and ideas. Students are responsible for at least two forms of literary writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an engaging story with a well-developed conflict and resolution, complex and non-stereotypical characters, a range of literary strategies (e.g., dialogue, suspense) and devices to enhance the plot, and sensory details that define the mood or tone;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a poem that reflects an awareness of poetic conventions and traditions within different forms (e.g., sonnets, ballads, free verse); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a script with an explicit or implicit theme, using a variety of literary techniques.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Expository and Procedural Texts. Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas and information to specific audiences for specific purposes. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an analytical essay of sufficient length that includes:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Effective introductory and concluding paragraphs and a variety of sentence structures;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Rhetorical devices, and transitions between paragraphs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clear thesis statement or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clear organizational schema for conveying ideas;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relevant and substantial evidence and well-chosen details; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Information on multiple relevant perspectives and a consideration of the validity, reliability, and relevance of primary and secondary sources;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write procedural or work-related documents (e.g., résumés, proposals, college applications, operation manuals) that include:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clearly stated purpose combined with a well-supported viewpoint on the topic;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Appropriate formatting structures (e.g., headings, graphics, white space);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relevant questions that engage readers and consider their needs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Accurate technical information in accessible language; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Appropriate organizational structures supported by facts and details (documented if appropriate);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an interpretation of an expository or a literary text that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Advances a clear thesis statement;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Addresses the writing skills for an analytical essay, including references to and commentary on quotations from the text;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyzes the aesthetic effects of an author's use of stylistic or rhetorical devices;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identifies and analyzes the ambiguities, nuances, and complexities within the text; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Anticipates and responds to readers' questions or contradictory information; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce a multimedia presentation (e.g., documentary, class newspaper, docudrama, infomercial, visual or textual parodies, theatrical production) with graphics, images, and sound that appeals to a specific audience and synthesizes information from multiple points of view.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write an argumentative essay (e.g., evaluative essays, proposals) to the appropriate audience that includes:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clear thesis or position based on logical reasons supported by precise and relevant evidence, including facts, expert opinions, quotations, and/or expressions of commonly accepted beliefs;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Accurate and honest representation of divergent views (i.e., in the author's own words and not out of context);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: An organizing structure appropriate to the purpose, audience, and context;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Information on the complete range of relevant perspectives;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrated consideration of the validity and reliability of all primary and secondary sources used; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Language attentively crafted to move a disinterested or opposed audience, using specific rhetorical devices to back up assertions (e.g., appeals to logic, emotions, ethical beliefs).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of different types of clauses and phrases (e.g., adjectival, noun, adverbial clauses and phrases); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a variety of correctly structured sentences (e.g., compound, complex, compound-complex).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to correctly and consistently use conventions of punctuation and capitalization.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Research Plan. Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Brainstorm, consult with others, decide upon a topic, and formulate a major research question to address the major research topic; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Formulate a plan for engaging in in-depth research on a complex, multi-faceted topic.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Gathering Sources. Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a research question and systematically record the information they gather. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Follow the research plan to gather evidence from experts on the topic and texts written for informed audiences in the field, distinguishing between reliable and unreliable sources and avoiding over-reliance on one source;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Systematically organize relevant and accurate information to support central ideas, concepts, and themes, outline ideas into conceptual maps/timelines, and separate factual data from complex inferences; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Paraphrase, summarize, quote, and accurately cite all researched information according to a standard format (e.g., author, title, page number), differentiating among primary, secondary, and other sources.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Synthesizing Information. Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Modify the major research question as necessary to refocus the research plan;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Differentiate between theories and the evidence that supports them and determine whether the evidence found is weak or strong and how that evidence helps create a cogent argument; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Critique the research process at each step to implement changes as the need occurs and is identified.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Research/Organizing and Presenting Ideas. Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of the research and their audience. Students are expected to synthesize the research into an extended written or oral presentation that:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Provides an analysis that supports and develops personal opinions, as opposed to simply restating existing information;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses a variety of formats and rhetorical strategies to argue for the thesis;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Develops an argument that incorporates the complexities of and discrepancies in information from multiple sources and perspectives while anticipating and refuting counter-arguments;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Uses a style manual (e.g., Modern Language Association, Chicago Manual of Style) to document sources and format written materials; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Is of sufficient length and complexity to address the topic.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Listening. Students will use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and informal settings. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen responsively to a speaker by framing inquiries that reflect an understanding of the content and by identifying the positions taken and the evidence in support of those positions; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the clarity and coherence of a speaker's message and critique the impact of a speaker's diction and syntax on an audience.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to give a formal presentation that exhibits a logical structure, smooth transitions, accurate evidence, well-chosen details, and rhetorical devices, and that employs eye contact, speaking rate (e.g., pauses for effect), volume, enunciation, purposeful gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate productively in teams, offering ideas or judgments that are purposeful in moving the team towards goals, asking relevant and insightful questions, tolerating a range of positions and ambiguity in decision-making, and evaluating the work of the group based on agreed-upon criteria.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Vocabulary Development. Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Determine the meaning of technical academic English words in multiple content areas (e.g., science, mathematics, social studies, the arts) derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to draw conclusions about the nuance in word meanings;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use the relationship between words encountered in analogies to determine their meanings (e.g., synonyms/antonyms, connotation/denotation);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze and explain how the English language has developed and been influenced by other languages; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use general and specialized dictionaries, thesauri, histories of language, books of quotations, and other related references (printed or electronic) as needed.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Theme and Genre. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast works of literature that express a universal theme;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the similarities and differences in classical plays with their modern day novel, play, or film versions; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Relate the characters, setting, and theme of a literary work to the historical, social, and economic ideas of its time.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Poetry. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to evaluate the changes in sound, form, figurative language, graphics, and dramatic structure in poetry across literary time periods.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Drama. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to evaluate how the structure and elements of drama change in the works of British dramatists across literary periods.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Fiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the structure and elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze how complex plot structures (e.g., subplots) and devices (e.g., foreshadowing, flashbacks, suspense) function and advance the action in a work of fiction;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyze the moral dilemmas and quandaries presented in works of fiction as revealed by the underlying motivations and behaviors of the characters;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Compare and contrast the effects of different forms of narration across various genres of fiction; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrate familiarity with works of fiction by British authors from each major literary period.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Literary Nonfiction. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the effect of ambiguity, contradiction, subtlety, paradox, irony, sarcasm, and overstatement in literary essays, speeches, and other forms of literary nonfiction.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Literary Text/Sensory Language. Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze how the author's patterns of imagery, literary allusions, and conceits reveal theme, set tone, and create meaning in metaphors, passages, and literary works.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Culture and History. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about the author's purpose in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding. Students are expected to analyze the consistency and clarity of the expression of the controlling idea and the ways in which the organizational and rhetorical patterns of text support or confound the author's meaning or purpose.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Expository Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about expository text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Summarize a text in a manner that captures the author's viewpoint, its main ideas, and its elements without taking a position or expressing an opinion;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Explain how authors writing on the same issue reached different conclusions because of differences in assumptions, evidence, reasoning, and viewpoints;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Make and defend subtle inferences and complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Synthesize ideas and make logical connections (e.g., thematic links, author analysis) among multiple texts representing similar or different genres and technical sources and support those findings with textual evidence.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Persuasive Text. Students analyze, make inferences and draw conclusions about persuasive text and provide evidence from text to support their analysis. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the merits of an argument, action, or policy by analyzing the relationships (e.g., implication, necessity, sufficiency) among evidence, inferences, assumptions, and claims in text; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Draw conclusions about the credibility of persuasive text by examining its implicit and stated assumptions about an issue as conveyed by the specific use of language.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Comprehension of Informational Text/Procedural Texts. Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and documents. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Draw conclusions about how the patterns of organization and hierarchic structures support the understandability of text; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the structures of text (e.g., format, headers) for their clarity and organizational coherence and for the effectiveness of their graphic representations.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Reading/Media Literacy. Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly more complex texts. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how messages presented in media reflect social and cultural views in ways different from traditional texts;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate the interactions of different techniques (e.g., layout, pictures, typeface in print media, images, text, sound in electronic journalism) used in multi-layered media;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate how one issue or event is represented across various media to understand the notions of bias, audience, and purpose; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Evaluate changes in formality and tone across various media for different audiences and purposes.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Plan a first draft by selecting the correct genre for conveying the intended meaning to multiple audiences, determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies (e.g., discussion, background reading, personal interests, interviews), and developing a thesis or controlling idea;

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written work for appropriate audiences.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write an engaging story with a well-developed conflict and resolution, a clear theme, complex and non-stereotypical characters, a range of literary strategies (e.g., dialogue, suspense), devices to enhance the plot, and sensory details that define the mood or tone;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a poem that reflects an awareness of poetic conventions and traditions within different forms (e.g., sonnets, ballads, free verse); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Write a script with an explicit or implicit theme, using a variety of literary techniques.

Text: Addresses the writing skills for an analytical essay including references to and commentary on quotations from the text;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Analyzes the aesthetic effects of an author's use of stylistic or rhetorical devices;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Identifies and analyzes ambiguities, nuances, and complexities within the text; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Anticipates and responds to readers' questions and contradictory information; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Produce a multimedia presentation (e.g., documentary, class newspaper, docudrama, infomercial, visual or textual parodies, theatrical production) with graphics, images, and sound that appeals to a specific audience and synthesizes information from multiple points of view.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Writing/Persuasive Texts. Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific audience on specific issues. Students are expected to write an argumentative essay (e.g., evaluative essays, proposals) to the appropriate audience that includes:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: A clear thesis or position based on logical reasons with various forms of support (e.g., hard evidence, reason, common sense, cultural assumptions);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Accurate and honest representation of divergent views (i.e., in the author's own words and not out of context);

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: An organizing structure appropriate to the purpose, audience, and context;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Information on the complete range of relevant perspectives;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Demonstrated consideration of the validity and reliability of all primary and secondary sources used;

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Language attentively crafted to move a disinterested or opposed audience, using specific rhetorical devices to back up assertions (e.g., appeals to logic, emotions, ethical beliefs); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: An awareness and anticipation of audience response that is reflected in different levels of formality, style, and tone.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Conventions. Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language when speaking and writing. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to:

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use and understand the function of different types of clauses and phrases (e.g., adjectival, noun, adverbial clauses and phrases); and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Use a variety of correctly structured sentences (e.g., compound, complex, compound-complex).

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Handwriting, Capitalization, and Punctuation. Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions in their compositions. Students are expected to correctly and consistently use conventions of punctuation and capitalization.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Oral and Written Conventions/Spelling. Students spell correctly. Students are expected to spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.

Subject: English Language Arts

Subject: English Language Arts

Text: Uses a style manual (e.g., Modern Language Association, Chicago Manual of Style) to document sources and format written materials; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Is of sufficient length and complexity to address the topic.
