Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listen responsively to a speaker by framing inquiries that reflect an understanding of the content and by identifying the positions taken and the evidence in support of those positions; and

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Assess the persuasiveness of a presentation based on content, diction, rhetorical strategies, and delivery.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Teamwork. Students work productively with others in teams. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to participate productively in teams, offering ideas or judgments that are purposeful in moving the team towards goals, asking relevant and insightful questions, tolerating a range of positions and ambiguity in decision-making, and evaluating the work of the group based on agreed-upon criteria.

Subject: English Language Arts
Text: Listening and Speaking/Speaking. Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity. Students are expected to formulate sound arguments by using elements of classical speeches (e.g., introduction, first and second transitions, body, and conclusion), the art of persuasion, rhetorical devices, eye contact, speaking rate (e.g., pauses for effect), volume, enunciation, purposeful gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometric structure. The student understands the structure of, and relationships within, an axiomatic system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Develop an awareness of the structure of a mathematical system, connecting definitions, postulates, logical reasoning, and theorems;

Subject: Math
Text: Recognize the historical development of geometric systems and know mathematics is developed for a variety of purposes; and

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and contrast the structures and implications of Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometries.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometric structure. The student analyzes geometric relationships in order to make and verify conjectures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use constructions to explore attributes of geometric figures and to make conjectures about geometric relationships; and

Subject: Math
Text: Make conjectures about angles, lines, polygons, circles, and three-dimensional figures and determine the validity of the conjectures, choosing from a variety of approaches such as coordinate, transformational, or axiomatic.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometric structure. The student applies logical reasoning to justify and prove mathematical statements. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the validity of a conditional statement, its converse, inverse, and contrapositive;

Subject: Math
Text: Construct and justify statements about geometric figures and their properties;

Subject: Math
Text: Use logical reasoning to prove statements are true and find counter examples to disprove statements that are false;

Subject: Math
Text: Use inductive reasoning to formulate a conjecture; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use deductive reasoning to prove a statement.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometric structure. The student uses a variety of representations to describe geometric relationships and solve problems. The student is expected to select an appropriate representation (concrete, pictorial, graphical, verbal, or symbolic) in order to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometric patterns. The student uses a variety of representations to describe geometric relationships and solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use numeric and geometric patterns to develop algebraic expressions representing geometric  properties

Subject: Math
Text: Use numeric and geometric patterns to make generalizations about geometric properties, including properties of polygons, ratios in similar figures and solids, and angle relationships in polygons and circles;

Subject: Math
Text: Use properties of transformations and their compositions to make connections between mathematics and the real world, such as tessellations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and apply patterns from right triangles to solve meaningful problems, including special right triangles (45-45-90 and 30-60-90) and triangles whose sides are Pythagorean triples.

Subject: Math
Text: Dimensionality and the geometry of location. The student analyzes the relationship between three-dimensional geometric figures and related two-dimensional representations and uses these representations to solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and draw the intersection of a given plane with various three-dimensional geometric figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Use nets to represent and construct three-dimensional geometric figures; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use orthographic and isometric views of three-dimensional geometric figures to represent and construct three-dimensional geometric figures and solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Dimensionality and the geometry of location. The student understands that coordinate systems provide convenient and efficient ways of representing geometric figures and uses them accordingly. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use one- and two-dimensional coordinate systems to represent points, lines, rays, line segments, and figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Use slopes and equations of lines to investigate geometric relationships, including parallel lines, perpendicular lines, and special segments of triangles and other polygons; and

Subject: Math
Text: Derive and use formulas involving length, slope, and midpoint.

Subject: Math
Text: Congruence and the geometry of size. The student uses tools to determine measurements of geometric figures and extends measurement concepts to find perimeter, area, and volume in problem situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Find areas of regular polygons, circles, and composite figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Find areas of sectors and arc lengths of circles using proportional reasoning;

Subject: Math
Text: Derive, extend, and use the Pythagorean Theorem;

Subject: Math
Text: Find surface areas and volumes of prisms, pyramids, spheres, cones, cylinders, and composites of these figures in problem situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Use area models to connect geometry to probability and statistics; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use conversions between measurement systems to solve problems in real-world situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Congruence and the geometry of size. The student analyzes properties and describes relationships in geometric figures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Formulate and test conjectures about the properties of parallel and perpendicular lines based on explorations and concrete models;

Subject: Math
Text: Formulate and test conjectures about the properties and attributes of polygons and their component parts based on explorations and concrete models;

Subject: Math
Text: Formulate and test conjectures about the properties and attributes of circles and the lines that intersect them based on explorations and concrete models; and

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze the characteristics of polyhedra and other three-dimensional figures and their component parts based on explorations and concrete models.

Subject: Math
Text: Congruence and the geometry of size. The student applies the concept of congruence to justify properties of figures and solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use congruence transformations to make conjectures and justify properties of geometric figures including figures represented on a coordinate plane; and

Subject: Math
Text: Justify and apply triangle congruence relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Similarity and the geometry of shape. The student applies the concepts of similarity to justify properties of figures and solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use and extend similarity properties and transformations to explore and justify conjectures about geometric figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Use ratios to solve problems involving similar figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Develop, apply, and justify triangle similarity relationships, such as right triangle ratios, trigonometric ratios, and Pythagorean triples using a variety of methods; and

Subject: Math
Text: Describe the effect on perimeter, area, and volume when one or more dimensions of a figure are changed and apply this idea in solving problems.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands major political ideas and forms of government in history. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain major political ideas in history, including the laws of nature and nature's God, unalienable rights, divine right of kings, social contract theory, and the rights of resistance to illegitimate government;
Keywords: Declaration of Independence, John Locke, Thomas Hobbes, Jacques Rousseau,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify major intellectual, philosophical, political, and religious traditions that informed the American founding, including Judeo-Christian (especially biblical law), English common law and constitutionalism, Enlightenment, and republicanism, as they address issues of liberty, rights, and responsibilities of individuals;
Keywords: Statutory Law, Founding Fathers, Voltaire, Montesquieu,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the individuals whose principles of laws and government institutions informed the American founding documents, including those of Moses, William Blackstone, John Locke, and Charles de Montesquieu;
Keywords: Commentaries on the Laws of England, natural rights, separation of powers, checks and balances,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the contributions of the political philosophies of the Founding Fathers, including John Adams, Alexander Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, John Jay, George Mason, Roger Sherman, and James Wilson, on the development of the U.S. government;
Keywords: Revolutionary War, US Constitution, Declaration of Independance, Federalist Papers,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine debates and compromises that impacted the creation of the founding documents; and
Keywords: The  Virginia Plan, the New Jersey Plan, The Great Compromise, Three-fifths Compromise,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant individuals in the field of government and politics, including George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, John Marshall, Andrew Jackson, Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Ronald Reagan.
Keywords: Louisiana Purchase, Supreme Court, Republican Party, The Great Depression,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands the roles played by individuals, political parties, interest groups, and the media in the U.S. political system, past and present. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Give examples of the processes used by individuals, political parties, interest groups, or the media to affect public policy; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the impact of political changes brought about by individuals, political parties, interest groups, or the media, past and present.
Keywords: third party canidate, Ron Paul, Civil Rights movement, citizens united v FEC,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands how geography can influence U.S. political divisions and policies. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand how population shifts affect voting patterns;
Keywords: Westward expansion, urbaniztion, great migration, Rust Belt to Sun Belt,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine political boundaries to make inferences regarding the distribution of political power; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how political divisions are crafted and how they are affected by Supreme Court decisions such as Baker v. Carr.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands why certain places or regions are important to the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the significance to the United States of the location and key natural resources of selected global places or regions; and
Keywords: current events, oil, Middle East, Tiawan,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze how U.S. foreign policy affects selected places and regions.
Keywords: oil and Middle East, immigration and Mexico, current events,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the roles played by local, state, and national governments in both the public and private sectors of the U.S. free enterprise system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how government fiscal, monetary, and regulatory policies influence the economy at the local, state, and national levels;
Keywords: fiat money, free enterprise, Federal Reserve,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the sources of revenue and expenditures of the U. S. government and analyze their impact on the U.S. economy;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the role of government in the U.S. free enterprise system and other economic systems; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand how government taxation and regulation can serve as restrictions to private enterprise.
Keywords: regulation, product testing, monopolies, health regulation,

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the relationship between U.S. government policies and the economy. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine how the U.S. government uses economic resources in foreign policy; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the roles of the executive and legislative branches in setting international trade and fiscal policies.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the American beliefs and principles reflected in the U.S. Constitution and why these are significant. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the importance of a written constitution;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate how the federal government serves the purposes set forth in the Preamble to the U.S. Constitution;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze how the Federalist Papers such as Number 10, Number 39, and Number 51 explain the principles of the American constitutional system of government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate constitutional provisions for limiting the role of government, including republicanism, checks and balances, federalism, separation of powers, popular sovereignty, and individual rights;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the constitutionally prescribed procedures by which the U.S. Constitution can be changed and analyze the role of the amendment process in a constitutional government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify how the American beliefs and principles reflected in the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution contribute to both a national identity and federal identity and are embodied in the United States today; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine the reasons the Founding Fathers protected religious freedom in America and guaranteed its free exercise by saying that Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof, and compare and contrast this to the phrase, separation of church and state.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the structure and functions of the government created by the U.S. Constitution. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the structure and functions of the legislative branch of government, including the bicameral structure of Congress, the role of committees, and the procedure for enacting laws;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the structure and functions of the executive branch of government, including the constitutional powers of the president, the growth of presidential power, and the role of the Cabinet and executive departments;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the structure and functions of the judicial branch of government, including the federal court system, types of jurisdiction, and judicial review;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the purpose of selected independent executive agencies, including the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), and regulatory commissions, including the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and Federal Communications Commission (FCC);

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how certain provisions of the U.S. Constitution provide for checks and balances among the three branches of government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze selected issues raised by judicial activism and judicial restraint;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the major responsibilities of the federal government for domestic and foreign policy such as national defense; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the structures, functions, and processes of national, state, and local governments in the U.S. federal system.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the concept of federalism. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain why the Founding Fathers created a distinctly new form of federalism and adopted a federal system of government instead of a unitary system;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Categorize government powers as national, state, or shared;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze historical and contemporary conflicts over the respective roles of national and state governments; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the limits on the national and state governments in the U.S. federal system of government.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the processes for filling public offices in the U.S. system of government. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare different methods of filling public offices, including elected and appointed offices at the local, state, and national levels;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the process of electing the president of the United States and analyze the Electoral College; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the impact of the passage of the 17th Amendment.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the role of political parties in the U.S. system of government. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the functions of political parties and their role in the electoral process at local, state, and national levels;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the two-party system and evaluate the role of third parties in the United States; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify opportunities for citizens to participate in political party activities at local, state, and national levels.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the similarities and differences that exist among the U.S. system of government and other political systems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the U.S. constitutional republic to historical and contemporary forms of government such as monarchy, a classical republic, authoritarian, socialist, direct democracy, theocracy, tribal, and other republics;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze advantages and disadvantages of federal, confederate, and unitary systems of government; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze advantages and disadvantages of presidential and parliamentary systems of government.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands rights guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the roles of limited government and the rule of law in the protection of individual rights;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and define the unalienable rights;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the freedoms and rights guaranteed by each amendment in the Bill of Rights;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze U.S. Supreme Court interpretations of rights guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution in selected cases, including Engel v. Vitale, Schenck v. United States, Texas v. Johnson, Miranda v. Arizona, Gideon v. Wainwright, Mapp v. Ohio, and Roe v. Wade;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the importance of due process rights to the protection of individual rights and in limiting the powers of government; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Recall the conditions that produced the 14th Amendment and describe subsequent efforts to selectively extend some of the Bill of Rights to the states, including the Blaine Amendment and U.S. Supreme Court rulings, and analyze the impact on the scope of fundamental rights and federalism.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the difference between personal and civic responsibilities. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the difference between personal and civic responsibilities;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate whether and/or when the obligation of citizenship requires that personal desires and interests be subordinated to the public good;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the responsibilities, duties, and obligations of citizenship such as being well informed about civic affairs, serving in the military, voting, serving on a jury, observing the laws, paying taxes, and serving the public good; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the voter registration process and the criteria for voting in elections.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of voluntary individual participation in the U.S. constitutional republic. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the effectiveness of various methods of participation in the political process at local, state, and national levels;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze historical and contemporary examples of citizen movements to bring about political change or to maintain continuity; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the factors that influence an individual's political attitudes and actions.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of the expression of different points of view in a constitutional republic. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine different points of view of political parties and interest groups such as the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC), the National Rifle Association (NRA), and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) on important contemporary issues; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the importance of the First Amendment rights of petition, assembly, speech, and press and the Second Amendment right to keep and bear arms.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the relationship between government policies and the culture of the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate a U.S. government policy or court decision that has affected a particular racial, ethnic, or religious group such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the U.S. Supreme Court cases of Hernandez v. Texas and Grutter v. Bollinger; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain changes in American culture brought about by government policies such as voting rights, the Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944 (GI Bill of Rights), the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965, the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, affirmative action, and racial integration.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Science, technology, and society. The student understands the role the government plays in developing policies and establishing conditions that influence scientific discoveries and technological innovations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand how U.S. constitutional protections such as patents have fostered competition and entrepreneurship; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify examples of government-assisted research that, when shared with the private sector, have resulted in improved consumer products such as computer and communication technologies.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Science, technology, and society. The student understands the impact of advances in science and technology on government and society. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the potential impact on society of recent scientific discoveries and technological innovations; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the impact of the Internet and other electronic information on the political process.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired from a variety of valid sources, including electronic technology. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing, contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations and predictions, and drawing inferences and conclusions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create a product on a contemporary government issue or topic using critical methods of inquiry;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze and defend a point of view on a current political issue;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze and evaluate the validity of information, arguments, and counterarguments from primary and secondary sources for bias, propaganda, point of view, and frame of reference;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate government data using charts, tables, graphs, and maps; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use appropriate mathematical skills to interpret social studies information such as maps and graphs.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use social studies terminology correctly;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use standard grammar, spelling, sentence structure, and punctuation;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Transfer information from one medium to another, including written to visual and statistical to written or visual, using computer software as appropriate; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create written, oral, and visual presentations of social studies information.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others, in a variety of settings. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses scientific methods during laboratory and field investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the following definition of science: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement investigative procedures, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology

Subject: Science
Text: Collect data and make measurements with precision

Subject: Science
Text: Organize, analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid conclusions.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials

Subject: Science
Text: Draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services

Subject: Science
Text: Evaluate the impact of research on scientific thought, society, and the environment

Subject: Science
Text: Describe connections between physics and chemistry and future careers

Subject: Science
Text: Research and describe the history of physics and chemistry and contributions of scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows concepts of force and motion evident in everyday life.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and calculate an object's motion in terms of position, displacement, speed, and acceleration

Subject: Science
Text: Measure and graph distance and speed as a function of time using moving toys

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate how an object's motion changes only when a net force is applied, including activities and equipment such as toy cars, vehicle restraints, sports activities, and classroom objects

Subject: Science
Text: Assess the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration, noting the relationship is independent of the nature of the force, using equipment such as dynamic carts, moving toys, vehicles, and falling objects

Subject: Science
Text: Apply the concept of conservation of momentum using action and reaction forces such as students on skateboards

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the gravitational attraction between objects of different masses at different distances, including satellites

Subject: Science
Text: Examine electrical force as a universal force between any two charged objects and compare the relative strength of the electrical force and gravitational force.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student recognizes multiple forms of energy and knows the impact of energy transfer and energy conservation in everyday life.

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize and demonstrate that objects and substances in motion have kinetic energy such as vibration of atoms, water flowing down a stream moving pebbles, and bowling balls knocking down pins

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate common forms of potential energy, including gravitational, elastic, and chemical, such as a ball on an inclined plane, springs, and batteries

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that moving electric charges produce magnetic forces and moving magnets produce electric forces

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate the law of conservation of energy

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and demonstrate the movement of thermal energy through solids, liquids, and gases by convection, conduction, and radiation such as in weather, living, and mechanical systems

Subject: Science
Text: Evaluate the transfer of electrical energy in series and parallel circuits and conductive materials

Subject: Science
Text: Explore the characteristics and behaviors of energy transferred by waves, including acoustic, seismic, light, and waves on water as they superpose on one another, bend around corners, reflect off surfaces, are absorbed by materials, and change direction when entering new materials

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze energy conversions such as those from radiant, nuclear, and geothermal sources; fossil fuels such as coal, gas, oil; and the movement of water or wind

Subject: Science
Text: Critique the advantages and disadvantages of various energy sources and their impact on society and the environment.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that relationships exist between the structure and properties of matter.
Keywords: gas, liquid, solid, states of matter,

Subject: Science
Text: Examine differences in physical properties of solids, liquids, and gases as explained by the arrangement and motion of atoms, ions, or molecules of the substances and the strength of the forces of attraction between those particles

Subject: Science
Text: Relate chemical properties of substances to the arrangement of their atoms or molecules

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds such as color, density, viscosity, buoyancy, boiling point, freezing point, conductivity, and reactivity

Subject: Science
Text: Relate the physical and chemical behavior of an element, including bonding and classification, to its placement on the Periodic Table

Subject: Science
Text: Relate the structure of water to its function as a solvent and investigate the properties of solutions and factors affecting gas and solid solubility, including nature of solute, temperature, pressure, pH, and concentration.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that changes in matter affect everyday life.

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate changes of state as it relates to the arrangement of particles of matter and energy transfer

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that chemical changes can occur when substances react to form different substances and that these interactions are largely determined by the valence electrons

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that mass is conserved when substances undergo chemical change and that the number and kind of atoms are the same in the reactants and products

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze energy changes that accompany chemical reactions such as those occurring in heat packs, cold packs, and glow sticks and classify them as exothermic or endothermic reactions

Subject: Science
Text: Describe types of nuclear reactions such as fission and fusion and their roles in applications such as medicine and energy production

Subject: Science
Text: Research and describe the environmental and economic impact of the end-products of chemical reactions such as those that may result in acid rain, degradation of water and air quality, and ozone depletion.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student uses numbers to name quantities. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use one-to-one correspondence and language such as more than, same number as, or two less than to describe relative sizes of sets of concrete objects;

Subject: Math
Text: Use sets of concrete objects to represent quantities given in verbal or written form (through 20); and

Subject: Math
Text: Use numbers to describe how many objects are in a set (through 20) using verbal and symbolic descriptions.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student describes order of events or objects. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use language such as before or after to describe relative position in a sequence of events or objects; and

Subject: Math
Text: Name the ordinal positions in a sequence such as first, second, third, etc.

Subject: Math
Text: Share a whole by separating it into two equal parts; and

Subject: Math
Text: Explain why a given part is half of the whole.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student recognizes that there are quantities less than a whole. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student models addition (joining) and subtraction (separating). The student is expected to model and create addition and subtraction problems in real situations with concrete objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student identifies, extends, and creates patterns. The student is expected to identify, extend, and create patterns of sounds, physical movement, and concrete objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses patterns to make predictions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns to predict what comes next, including cause-and-effect relationships; and

Subject: Math
Text: Count by ones to 100.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student describes the relative positions of objects. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe one object in relation to another using informal language such as over, under, above, and below; and

Subject: Math
Text: Place an object in a specified position.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses attributes to determine how objects are alike and different. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and identify an object by its attributes using informal language;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare two objects based on their attributes; and

Subject: Math
Text: Sort a variety of objects including two- and three-dimensional geometric figures according to their attributes and describe how the objects are sorted.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student recognizes attributes of two- and three-dimensional geometric figures.

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and compare the attributes of real-life objects such as balls, boxes, cans, and cones or models of three-dimensional geometric figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Recognize shapes in real-life three-dimensional geometric figures or models of three-dimensional geometric figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Describe, identify, and compare circles, triangles, rectangles, and squares (a special type of rectangle).

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student directly compares the attributes of length, area, weight/mass, capacity, and/or relative temperature. The student uses comparative language to solve problems and answer questions.

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order two or three concrete objects according to length (longer/shorter than, or the same);
Keywords: manipulat, longer than, shorter than, estimate,

Subject: Math
Text: Compare the areas of two flat surfaces of two-dimensional figures (covers more, covers less, or covers the same);

Subject: Math
Text: Compare two containers according to capacity (holds more, holds less, or holds the same);

Subject: Math
Text: Compare two objects according to weight/mass (heavier than, lighter than or equal to);

Subject: Math
Text: Compare situations or objects according to relative temperature (hotter/colder than, or the same as).

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student uses time to describe, compare, and order events and situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Compare events according to duration such as more time than or less time than;

Subject: Math
Text: Sequence events (up to three);

Subject: Math
Text: Read a calendar using days, weeks, and months.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student constructs and uses graphs of real objects or pictures to answer questions.

Subject: Math
Text: Construct graphs using real objects or pictures in order to answer questions;

Subject: Math
Text: Use information from a graph of real objects or pictures in order to answer questions.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Kindergarten mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences and activities in and outside of school.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify mathematics in everyday situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Solve problems with guidance that incorporates the processes of understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving strategy including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, or acting it out in order to solve a problem;

Subject: Math
Text: Use tools such as real objects, manipulatives, and technology to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student communicates about Kindergarten mathematics using informal language.

Subject: Math
Text: Communicate mathematical ideas using objects, words, pictures, numbers, and technology;

Subject: Math
Text: Relate everyday language to mathematical language and symbols.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student uses logical reasoning. The student is expected to justify his or her thinking using objects, words, pictures, numbers, and technology.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student uses whole numbers to describe and compare quantities.

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order whole numbers up to 99 (less than, greater than, or equal to) using sets of concrete objects and pictorial models;

Subject: Math
Text: Create sets of tens and ones using concrete objects to describe, compare, and order whole numbers;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify individual coins by name and value and describe relationships among them;

Subject: Math
Text: Read and write numbers to 99 to describe sets of concrete objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student uses pairs of whole numbers to describe fractional parts of whole objects or sets of objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Separate a whole into two, three, or four equal parts and use appropriate language to describe the parts such as three out of four equal parts;

Subject: Math
Text: Use appropriate language to describe part of a set such as three out of the eight crayons are red.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student recognizes and solves problems in addition and subtraction situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Model and create addition and subtraction problem situations with concrete objects and write corresponding number sentences;

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete and pictorial models to apply basic addition and subtraction facts (up to 9 + 9 = 18 and 18 - 9 = 9).

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses repeating patterns and additive patterns to make predictions. The student is expected to identify, describe, and extend concrete and pictorial patterns in order to make predictions and solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student recognizes patterns in numbers and operations.

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns to skip count by twos, fives, and tens;

Subject: Math
Text: Find patterns in numbers, including odd and even;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order whole numbers using place value;

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns to develop strategies to solve basic addition and basic subtraction problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify patterns in related addition and subtraction sentences (fact families for sums to 18) such as 2 + 3 = 5, 3 + 2 = 5, 5 - 2 = 3, and 5 - 3 = 2.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses attributes to identify two- and three-dimensional geometric figures. The student compares and contrasts two- and three-dimensional geometric figures or both.

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and identify two-dimensional geometric figures, including circles, triangles, rectangles, and squares (a special type of rectangle);

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and identify three-dimensional geometric figures, including spheres, rectangular prisms (including cubes), cylinders, and cones;

Subject: Math
Text: Describe and identify two- and three-dimensional geometric figures in order to sort them according to a given attribute using informal and formal language;

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models to combine two-dimensional geometric figures to make new geometric figures.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student directly compares the attributes of length, area, weight/mass, capacity, and temperature. The student uses comparative language to solve problems and answer questions. The student selects and uses nonstandard units to describe length.

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate and measure length using nonstandard units such as paper clips or sides of color tiles;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order two or more concrete objects according to length (from longest to shortest);

Subject: Math
Text: Describe the relationship between the size of the unit and the number of units needed to measure the length of an object;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order the area of two or more two-dimensional surfaces (from covers the most to covers the least);

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order two or more containers according to capacity (from holds the most to holds the least);

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order two or more objects according to weight/mass (from heaviest to lightest);

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order two or more objects according to relative temperature (from hottest to coldest).

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student understands that time can be measured. The student uses time to describe and compare situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Order three or more events according to duration;

Subject: Math
Text: Read time to the hour and half-hour using analog and digital clocks.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student displays data in an organized form.

Subject: Math
Text: Collect and sort data;

Subject: Math
Text: Use organized data to construct real-object graphs, picture graphs, and bar-type graphs.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student uses information from organized data.

Subject: Math
Text: Draw conclusions and answer questions using information organized in real-object graphs, picture graphs, and bar-type graphs;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify events as certain or impossible such as drawing a red crayon from a bag of green crayons.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Grade 1 mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences and activities in and outside of school.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify mathematics in everyday situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Solve problems with guidance that incorporates the processes of understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving plan or strategy including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, or acting it out in order to solve a problem;

Subject: Math
Text: Use tools such as real objects, manipulatives, and technology to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student communicates about Grade 1 mathematics using informal language.

Subject: Math
Text: Explain and record observations using objects, words, pictures, numbers, and technology;

Subject: Math
Text: Relate informal language to mathematical language and symbols.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student uses logical reasoning. The student is expected to justify his or her thinking using objects, words, pictures, numbers, and technology.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student understands how place value is used to represent whole numbers.

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models of hundreds, tens, and ones to represent a given whole number (up to 999) in various ways;

Subject: Math
Text: Use place value to read, write, and describe the value of whole numbers to 999;

Subject: Math
Text: Use place value to compare and order whole numbers to 999 and record the comparisons using numbers and symbols (<, =, >).

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student describes how fractions are used to name parts of whole objects or sets of objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models to represent and name fractional parts of a whole object (with denominators of 12 or less);

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models to represent and name fractional parts of a set of objects (with denominators of 12 or less);

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models to determine if a fractional part of a whole is closer to 0, ½, or 1.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student adds and subtracts whole numbers to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Recall and apply basic addition and subtraction facts ( to 18);

Subject: Math
Text: Model addition and subtraction of two-digit numbers with objects, pictures, words, and numbers;

Subject: Math
Text: Select addition or subtraction to solve problems using two-digit numbers, whether or not regrouping is necessary;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the value of a collection of coins up to one dollar;

Subject: Math
Text: Describe how the cent symbol, dollar symbol, and the decimal point are used to name the value of a collection of coins.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student models multiplication and division.

Subject: Math
Text: Model, create, and describe multiplication situations in which equivalent sets of concrete objects are joined;

Subject: Math
Text: Model, create, and describe division situations in which a set of concrete objects is separated into equivalent sets.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses patterns in numbers and operations.

Subject: Math
Text: Find patterns in numbers such as in a 100s chart;

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns in place value to compare and order whole numbers through 999;

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns and relationships to develop strategies to remember basic addition and subtraction facts. Determine patterns in related addition and subtraction number sentences (including fact families) such as 8 + 9 = 17, 9 + 8 = 17, 17 - 8 = 9, and 17 - 9 = 8.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses patterns to describe relationships and make predictions.

Subject: Math
Text: Generate a list of paired numbers based on a real-life situation such as number of tricycles related to number of wheels;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify patterns in a list of related number pairs based on a real-life situation and extend the list;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify, describe, and extend repeating and additive patterns to make predictions and solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses attributes to identify two- and three-dimensional geometric figures. The student compares and contrasts two- and three-dimensional geometric figures or both.

Subject: Math
Text: Describe attributes (the number of vertices, faces, edges, sides) of two- and three-dimensional geometric figures such as circles, polygons, spheres, cones, cylinders, prisms, and pyramids, etc.;

Subject: Math
Text: Use attributes to describe how 2 two-dimensional figures or 2 three-dimensional geometric figures are alike or different;

Subject: Math
Text: Cut two-dimensional geometric figures apart and identify the new geometric figures formed.
Keywords: half, scissor, manipulat, compare, same, different,

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student recognizes that a line can be used to represent a set of numbers and its properties. The student is expected to use whole numbers to locate and name points on a number line.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student directly compares the attributes of length, area, weight/mass, and capacity, and uses comparative language to solve problems and answer questions. The student selects and uses nonstandard units to describe length, area, capacity, and weight/mass. The student recognizes and uses models that approximate standard units ( from both SI, also known as metric, and customary systems) of length, weight/mass, capacity, and time.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify concrete models that approximate standard units of length and use them to measure length;

Subject: Math
Text: Select a non-standard unit of measure such as square tiles to determine the area of a two-dimensional surface;

Subject: Math
Text: Select a non-standard unit of measure such as a bathroom cup or a jar to determine the capacity of a given container;

Subject: Math
Text: Select a non-standard unit of measure such as beans or marbles to determine the weight/mass of a given object.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student uses standard tools to estimate and measure time and temperature (in degrees Fahrenheit).
Keywords: degree, hot, cold, thermom, freeze, boil,

Subject: Math
Text: Read a thermometer to gather data;

Subject: Math
Text: Read and write times shown on analog and digital clocks using five-minute increments;

Subject: Math
Text: Describe activities that take approximately one second, one minute, and one hour.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student organizes data to make it useful for interpreting information.

Subject: Math
Text: Construct picture graphs and bar-type graphs;
Keywords: draw, show, graph, result, total, number,

Subject: Math
Text: Draw conclusions and answer questions based on picture graphs and bar-type graphs;

Subject: Math
Text: Use data to describe events as more likely or less likely such as drawing a certain color crayon from a bag of seven red crayons and three green crayons.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Grade 2 mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences and activities in and outside of school.
Keywords: daily, home, real, life, world, apply,

Subject: Math
Text: Identify the mathematics in everyday situations;
Keywords: describe, home, daily, math, real, life,

Subject: Math
Text: Solve problems with guidance that incorporates the processes of understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving plan or strategy including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, or acting it out in order to solve a problem;
Keywords: graph, total, result, outcome, number, use,

Subject: Math
Text: Use tools such as real objects, manipulatives, and technology to solve problems.
Keywords: count, show, display, illustrat, total, number,

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student communicates about Grade 2 mathematics using informal language.

Subject: Math
Text: Explain and record observations using objects, words, pictures, numbers, and technology;

Subject: Math
Text: Relate informal language to mathematical language and symbols.
Keywords: explain, describe, result, number, total, count,

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student uses logical reasoning. The student is expected to justify his or her thinking using objects, words, pictures, numbers, and technology.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student uses place value to communicate about increasingly large whole numbers in verbal and written form, including money.

Subject: Math
Text: Use place value to read, write (in symbols and words), and describe the value of whole numbers through 999,999;

Subject: Math
Text: Use place value to compare and order whole numbers through 9,999;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the value of a collection of coins and bills.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student uses fraction names and symbols (with denominators of 12 or less) to describe fractional parts of whole objects or sets of objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Construct concrete models of fractions;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare fractional parts of whole objects or sets of objects in a problem situation using concrete models;

Subject: Math
Text: Use fraction names and symbols to describe fractional parts of whole objects or sets of objects;

Subject: Math
Text: Onstruct concrete models of equivalent fractions for fractional parts of whole objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student adds and subtracts to solve meaningful problems involving whole numbers.

Subject: Math
Text: Model addition and subtraction using pictures, words, and numbers;

Subject: Math
Text: Select addition or subtraction and use the operation to solve problems involving whole numbers through 999.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student recognizes and solves problems in multiplication and division situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Learn and apply multiplication facts through 12 by 12 using concrete models and objects;

Subject: Math
Text: Solve and record multiplication problems (up to two digits times one digit);

Subject: Math
Text: Use models to solve division problems and use number sentences to record the solutions.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student estimates to determine reasonable results.

Subject: Math
Text: Round whole numbers to the nearest ten or hundred to approximate reasonable results in problem situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Use strategies including rounding and compatible numbers to estimate solutions to addition and subtraction problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses patterns to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and extend whole-number and geometric patterns to make predictions and solve problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify patterns in multiplication facts using concrete objects, pictorial models, or technology;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify patterns in related multiplication and division sentences (fact families) such as 2 x 3 = 6, 3 x 2 = 6, 6 Ìá 2 = 3, 6 Ìá 3 = 2.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses lists, tables, and charts to express patterns and relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Generate a table of paired numbers based on a real-life situation such as insects and legs;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and describe patterns in a table of related number pairs based on a meaningful problem and extend the table.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses formal geometric vocabulary. The student is expected to identify, classify, and describe two- and three-dimensional geometric figures by their attributes. The student compares two- dimensional figures, three-dimensional figures, or both by their attributes using formal geometry vocabulary.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student recognizes congruence and symmetry.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify congruent two-dimensional figures;

Subject: Math
Text: Create two-dimensional figures with lines of symmetry using concrete models and technology;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify lines of symmetry in two-dimensional geometric figures.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student recognizes that a line can be used to represent numbers and fractions and their properties and relationships. The student is expected to locate and name points on a number line using whole numbers and fractions, including halves and fourths.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student directly compares the attributes of length, area, weight/mass, and capacity, and uses comparative language to solve problems and answer questions. The student selects and uses standard units to describe length, area, capacity/volume, and weight/mass.

Subject: Math
Text: Use linear measurement tools to estimate and measure lengths using standard units;

Subject: Math
Text: Use standard units to find the perimeter of a shape;

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete and pictorial models of square units to determine the area of two-dimensional surfaces;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify concrete models that approximate standard units of weight/mass and use them to measure weight/mass;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify concrete models that approximate standard units for capacity and use them to measure capacity;

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models that approximate cubic units to determine the volume of a given container or other three-dimensional geometric figure.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student reads and writes time and measures temperature in degrees Fahrenheit to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Use a thermometer to measure temperature;

Subject: Math
Text: Tell and write time shown on analog and digital clocks.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student solves problems by collecting, organizing, displaying, and interpreting sets of data.

Subject: Math
Text: Collect, organize, record, and display data in pictographs and bar graphs where each picture or cell might represent more than one piece of data;

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret information from pictographs and bar graphs;

Subject: Math
Text: Use data to describe events as more likely than, less likely than, or equally likely as.

Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Grade 3 mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences and activities in and outside of school.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify the mathematics in everyday situations;

Text: Solve problems that incorporate understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving plan or strategy, including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, acting it out, making a table, working a simpler problem, or working backwards to solve a problem;

Subject: Math
Text: Use tools such as real objects, manipulatives, and technology to solve problems.

Text: Relate informal language to mathematical language and symbols.

Text: Make generalizations from patterns or sets of examples and nonexamples;

Subject: Math
Text: Justify why an answer is reasonable and explain the solution process.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student uses place value to represent whole numbers and decimals.

Subject: Math
Text: Use place value to read, write, compare, and order whole numbers through 999,999,999;

Subject: Math
Text: Use place value to read, write, compare, and order decimals involving tenths and hundredths, including money, using concrete objects and pictorial models.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student describes and compares fractional parts of whole objects or sets of objects.

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete objects and pictorial models to generate equivalent fractions;

Subject: Math
Text: Model fraction quantities greater than one using concrete objects and pictorial models;

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order fractions using concrete objects and pictorial models;

Subject: Math
Text: Relate decimals to fractions that name tenths and hundredths using concrete objects and pictorial models.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student adds and subtracts to solve meaningful problems involving whole numbers and decimals.

Subject: Math
Text: Use addition and subtraction to solve problems involving whole numbers;

Subject: Math
Text: Add and subtract decimals to the hundredths place using concrete objects and pictorial models.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student multiplies and divides to solve meaningful problems involving whole numbers.

Subject: Math
Text: Model factors and products using arrays and area models;

Subject: Math
Text: Represent multiplication and division situations in picture, word, and number form;

Subject: Math
Text: Recall and apply multiplication facts through 12 x 12;

Subject: Math
Text: Use multiplication to solve problems (no more than two digits times two digits without technology);

Subject: Math
Text: Use division to solve problems (no more than one-digit divisors and three-digit dividends without technology).

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student estimates to determine reasonable results.

Subject: Math
Text: Round whole numbers to the nearest ten, hundred, or thousand to approximate reasonable results in problem situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Use strategies including rounding and compatible numbers to estimate solutions to multiplication and division problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses patterns in multiplication and division.

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns and relationships to develop strategies to remember basic multiplication and division facts (such as the patterns in related multiplication and division number sentences (fact families) such as 9 x 9 = 81 and 81 Ìá 9 = 9);

Subject: Math
Text: Use patterns to multiply by 10 and 100.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses organizational structures to analyze and describe patterns and relationships. The student is expected to describe the relationship between two sets of related data such as ordered pairs in a table.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student identifies and describes attributes of geometric figures using formal geometric language.

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and describe right, acute, and obtuse angles;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and describe parallel and intersecting (including perpendicular) lines using concrete objects and pictorial models;

Subject: Math
Text: Use essential attributes to define two- and three-dimensional geometric figures.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student connects transformations to congruence and symmetry.

Subject: Math
Text: Demonstrate translations, reflections, and rotations using concrete models;

Subject: Math
Text: Use translations, reflections, and rotations to verify that two shapes are congruent;

Subject: Math
Text: Use reflections to verify that a shape has symmetry.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student recognizes the connection between numbers and their properties and points on a line. The student is expected to locate and name points on a number line using whole numbers, fractions such as halves and fourths, and decimals such as tenths.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student applies measurement concepts. The student is expected to estimate and measure to solve problems involving length (including perimeter) and area. The student uses measurement tools to measure capacity/volume and weight/mass.

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate and use measurement tools to determine length (including perimeter), area, capacity and weight/mass using standard units SI (metric) and customary;

Subject: Math
Text: Perform simple conversions between different units of length, between different units of capacity, and between different units of weight within the customary measurement system;

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete models of standard cubic units to measure volume;

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate volume in cubic units;

Subject: Math
Text: Explain the difference between weight and mass.

Text: Measurement. The student applies measurement concepts. The student measures time and temperature (in degrees Fahrenheit and Celsius).

Subject: Math
Text: Use a thermometer to measure temperature and changes in temperature;

Subject: Math
Text: Use tools such as a clock with gears or a stopwatch to solve problems involving elapsed time.

Text: Probability and statistics. The student solves problems by collecting, organizing, displaying, and interpreting sets of data.

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete objects or pictures to make generalizations about determining all possible combinations of a given set of data or of objects in a problem situation;

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret bar graphs.

Text: Use place value to read, write, compare, and order decimals through the thousandths place.

Text: Generate a mixed number equivalent to a given improper fraction or generate an improper fraction equivalent to a given mixed number;

Text: Compare two fractional quantities in problem-solving situations using a variety of methods, including common denominators;

Text: Use models to relate decimals to fractions that name tenths, hundredths, and thousandths.

Text: Use addition and subtraction to solve problems involving whole numbers and decimals;

Text: Use multiplication to solve problems involving whole numbers (no more than three digits times two digits without technology);

Text: Use division to solve problems involving whole numbers (no more than two-digit divisors and three-digit dividends without technology), including interpreting the remainder within a given context;

Text: Model situations using addition and/or subtraction involving fractions with like denominators using concrete objects, pictures, words, and numbers.

Text: Generate equivalent forms of rational numbers including whole numbers, fractions, and decimals

Subject: Math
Text: Use integers to represent real-life situations

Subject: Math
Text: Write prime factorizations using exponents

Subject: Math
Text: Identify factors of a positive integer, common factors, and the greatest common factor of a set of positive integers

Subject: Math
Text: Identify multiples of a positive integer and common multiples and the least common multiple of a set of positive integers

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student adds, subtracts, multiplies, and divides to solve problems and justify solutions

Subject: Math
Text: Model addition and subtraction situations involving fractions with objects, pictures, words, and numbers

Subject: Math
Text: Use addition and subtraction to solve problems involving fractions and decimals

Subject: Math
Text: Use multiplication and division of whole numbers to solve problems including situations involving equivalent ratios and rates

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate and round to approximate reasonable results and to solve problems where exact answers are not required

Subject: Math
Text: Use order of operations to simplify whole number expressions (without exponents) in problem solving situations

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student solves problems involving direct proportional relationships

Subject: Math
Text: Use ratios to describe proportional situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Represent ratios and percents with concrete models, fractions, and decimals; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use ratios to make predictions in proportional situations

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses letters as variables in mathematical expressions to describe how one quantity changes when a related quantity changes. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use tables and symbols to represent and describe proportional and other relationships such as those involving conversions, arithmetic sequences (with a constant rate of change), perimeter and area; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use tables of data to generate formulas representing relationships involving perimeter, area, volume of a rectangular prism, etc.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses letters to represent an unknown in an equation. The student is expected to formulate equations from problem situations described by linear relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses geometric vocabulary to describe angles, polygons, and circles. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use angle measurements to classify angles as acute, obtuse, or right;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify relationships involving angles in triangles and quadrilaterals; and

Subject: Math
Text: Describe the relationship between radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses coordinate geometry to identify location in two dimensions. The student is expected to locate and name points on a coordinate plane using ordered pairs of non-negative rational numbers.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student solves application problems involving estimation and measurement of length, area, time, temperature, volume, weight, and angles. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate measurements (including circumference) and evaluate reasonableness of results;

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use appropriate units, tools, or formulas to measure and to solve problems involving length (including perimeter), area, time, temperature, volume, and weight;

Subject: Math
Text: Measure angles; and

Subject: Math
Text: Convert measures within the same measurement system (customary and metric) based on relationships between units.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student uses experimental and theoretical probability to make predictions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Construct sample spaces using lists and tree diagrams; and

Subject: Math
Text: Find the probabilities of a simple event and its complement and describe the relationship between the two.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student uses statistical representations to analyze data. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use an appropriate representation for presenting and displaying different graphical representations of the same data including line plot, line graph, bar graph, and stem and leaf plot;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify mean (using concrete objects and pictorial models), median, mode, and range of a set of data;

Subject: Math
Text: Sketch circle graphs to display data; and

Subject: Math
Text: Solve problems by collecting, organizing, displaying, and interpreting data.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Grade 6 mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences, investigations in other disciplines, and activities in and outside of school. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and apply mathematics to everyday experiences, to activities in and outside of school, with other disciplines, and with other mathematical topics;

Subject: Math
Text: Use a problem-solving model that incorporates understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving strategy from a variety of different types, including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, acting it out, making a table, working a simpler problem, or working backwards to solve a problem; and

Subject: Math
Text: Select tools such as real objects, manipulatives, paper/pencil, and technology or techniques such as mental math, estimation, and number sense to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student communicates about Grade 6 mathematics through informal and mathematical language, representations, and models. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Communicate mathematical ideas using language, efficient tools, appropriate units, and graphical, numerical, physical, or algebraic mathematical models; and

Subject: Math
Text: Evaluate the effectiveness of different representations to communicate ideas.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student uses logical reasoning to make conjectures and verify conclusions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Make conjectures from patterns or sets of examples and nonexamples; and

Subject: Math
Text: Validate his/her conclusions using mathematical properties and relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student represents and uses numbers in a variety of equivalent forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order integers and positive rational numbers;

Subject: Math
Text: Convert between fractions, decimals, whole numbers, and percents mentally, on paper, or with a calculator; and

Subject: Math
Text: Represent squares and square roots using geometric models.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student adds, subtracts, multiplies, or divides to solve problems and justify solutions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Represent multiplication and division situations involving fractions and decimals with models, including concrete objects, pictures, words, and numbers;

Subject: Math
Text: Use addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division to solve problems involving fractions and decimals;

Subject: Math
Text: Use models, such as concrete objects, pictorial models, and number lines, to add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers and connect the actions to algorithms;

Subject: Math
Text: Use division to find unit rates and ratios in proportional relationships such as speed, density, price, recipes, and student-teacher ratio;

Subject: Math
Text: Simplify numerical expressions involving order of operations and exponents;

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use appropriate operations to solve problems and justify the selections; and

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the reasonableness of a solution to a problem.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student solves problems involving direct proportional relationships. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate and find solutions to application problems involving percent; and

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate and find solutions to application problems involving proportional relationships such as similarity, scaling, unit costs, and related measurement units.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student represents a relationship in numerical, geometric, verbal, and symbolic form. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Generate formulas involving unit conversions within the same system (customary and metric), perimeter, area, circumference, volume, and scaling;

Subject: Math
Text: Graph data to demonstrate relationships in familiar concepts such as conversions, perimeter, area, circumference, volume, and scaling; and

Subject: Math
