Text: Use words and symbols to describe the relationship between the terms in an arithmetic sequence (with a constant rate of change) and their positions in the sequence.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses equations to solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use concrete and pictorial models to solve equations and use symbols to record the actions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Formulate problem situations when given a simple equation and formulate an equation when given a problem situation.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student compares and classifies two- and three-dimensional figures using geometric vocabulary and properties. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use angle measurements to classify pairs of angles as complementary or supplementary;

Subject: Math
Text: Use properties to classify triangles and quadrilaterals;

Subject: Math
Text: Use properties to classify three-dimensional figures, including pyramids, cones, prisms, and cylinders; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use critical attributes to define similarity.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses coordinate geometry to describe location on a plane. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Locate and name points on a coordinate plane using ordered pairs of integers; and

Subject: Math
Text: Graph reflections across the horizontal or vertical axis and graph translations on a coordinate plane.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses geometry to model and describe the physical world. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Sketch three-dimensional figures when given the top, side, and front views;

Subject: Math
Text: Make a net (two-dimensional model) of the surface area of a three-dimensional figure; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use geometric concepts and properties to solve problems in fields such as art and architecture.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student solves application problems involving estimation and measurement. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate measurements and solve application problems involving length (including perimeter and circumference) and area of polygons and other shapes;

Subject: Math
Text: Connect models for volume of prisms (triangular and rectangular) and cylinders to formulas of prisms (triangular and rectangular) and cylinders; and

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate measurements and solve application problems involving volume of prisms (rectangular and triangular) and cylinders.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student recognizes that a physical or mathematical model (including geometric) can be used to describe the experimental and theoretical probability of real-life events. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Construct sample spaces for simple or composite experiments; and

Subject: Math
Text: Find the probability of independent events.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student understands that the way a set of data is displayed influences its interpretation. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use an appropriate representation for presenting and displaying relationships among collected data, including line plot, line graph, bar graph, stem and leaf plot, circle graph, and Venn diagrams, and justify the selection; and

Subject: Math
Text: Make inferences and convincing arguments based on an analysis of given or collected data.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student uses measures of central tendency and variability to describe a set of data. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe a set of data using mean, median, mode, and range; and

Subject: Math
Text: Choose among mean, median, mode, or range to describe a set of data and justify the choice for a particular situation.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Grade 7 mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences, investigations in other disciplines, and activities in and outside of school. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and apply mathematics to everyday experiences, to activities in and outside of school, with other disciplines, and with other mathematical topics;

Subject: Math
Text: Use a problem-solving model that incorporates understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving strategy from a variety of different types, including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, acting it out, making a table, working a simpler problem, or working backwards to solve a problem; and

Subject: Math
Text: Select tools such as real objects, manipulatives, paper/pencil, and technology or techniques such as mental math, estimation, and number sense to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student communicates about Grade 7 mathematics through informal and mathematical language, representations, and models. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Communicate mathematical ideas using language, efficient tools, appropriate units, and graphical, numerical, physical, or algebraic mathematical models; and

Subject: Math
Text: Evaluate the effectiveness of different representations to communicate ideas.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student uses logical reasoning to make conjectures and verify conclusions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Make conjectures from patterns or sets of examples and nonexamples; and

Subject: Math
Text: Validate his/her conclusions using mathematical properties and relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student understands that different forms of numbers are appropriate for different situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order rational numbers in various forms including integers, percents, and positive and negative fractions and decimals;

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use appropriate forms of rational numbers to solve real-life problems including those involving proportional relationships;

Subject: Math
Text: Approximate (mentally and with calculators) the value of irrational numbers as they arise from problem situations (such as ìÛ, ‰ö_2);

Subject: Math
Text: Express numbers in scientific notation, including negative exponents, in appropriate problem situations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and order real numbers with a calculator.

Subject: Math
Text: Number, operation, and quantitative reasoning. The student selects and uses appropriate operations to solve problems and justify solutions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Select appropriate operations to solve problems involving rational numbers and justify the selections;

Subject: Math
Text: Use appropriate operations to solve problems involving rational numbers in problem situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Evaluate a solution for reasonableness; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use multiplication by a given constant factor (including unit rate) to represent and solve problems involving proportional relationships including conversions between measurement systems.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student identifies proportional or non-proportional linear relationships in problem situations and solves problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Compare and contrast proportional and non-proportional linear relationships; and

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate and find solutions to application problems involving percents and other proportional relationships such as similarity and rates.

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student makes connections among various representations of a numerical relationship. The student is expected to generate a different representation of data given another representation of data (such as a table, graph, equation, or verbal description).

Subject: Math
Text: Patterns, relationships, and algebraic thinking. The student uses graphs, tables, and algebraic representations to make predictions and solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Predict, find, and justify solutions to application problems using appropriate tables, graphs, and algebraic equations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Find and evaluate an algebraic expression to determine any term in an arithmetic sequence (with a constant rate of change).

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses transformational geometry to develop spatial sense. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Generate similar figures using dilations including enlargements and reductions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Graph dilations, reflections, and translations on a coordinate plane.

Subject: Math
Text: Geometry and spatial reasoning. The student uses geometry to model and describe the physical world. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Draw three-dimensional figures from different perspectives;

Subject: Math
Text: Use geometric concepts and properties to solve problems in fields such as art and architecture;

Subject: Math
Text: Use pictures or models to demonstrate the Pythagorean Theorem; and

Subject: Math
Text: Locate and name points on a coordinate plane using ordered pairs of rational numbers.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student uses procedures to determine measures of three-dimensional figures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Find lateral and total surface area of prisms, pyramids, and cylinders using concrete models and nets (two-dimensional models);

Subject: Math
Text: Connect models of prisms, cylinders, pyramids, spheres, and cones to formulas for volume of these objects; and

Subject: Math
Text: Estimate measurements and use formulas to solve application problems involving lateral and total surface area and volume.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student uses indirect measurement to solve problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use the Pythagorean Theorem to solve real-life problems; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use proportional relationships in similar two-dimensional figures or similar three-dimensional figures to find missing measurements.

Subject: Math
Text: Measurement. The student describes how changes in dimensions affect linear, area, and volume measures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe the resulting effects on perimeter and area when dimensions of a shape are changed proportionally; and

Subject: Math
Text: Describe the resulting effect on volume when dimensions of a solid are changed proportionally.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student applies concepts of theoretical and experimental probability to make predictions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Find the probabilities of dependent and independent events;

Subject: Math
Text: Use theoretical probabilities and experimental results to make predictions and decisions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use different models to simulate an event.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student uses statistical procedures to describe data. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use variability (range, including interquartile range (IQR)) and select the appropriate measure of central tendency to describe a set of data and justify the choice for a particular situation;

Subject: Math
Text: Draw conclusions and make predictions by analyzing trends in scatterplots; and

Subject: Math
Text: Select and use an appropriate representation for presenting and displaying relationships among collected data, including line plots, line graphs, stem and leaf plots, circle graphs, bar graphs, box and whisker plots, histograms, and Venn diagrams, with and without the use of technology.

Subject: Math
Text: Probability and statistics. The student evaluates predictions and conclusions based on statistical data. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Evaluate methods of sampling to determine validity of an inference made from a set of data; and

Subject: Math
Text: Recognize misuses of graphical or numerical information and evaluate predictions and conclusions based on data analysis.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student applies Grade 8 mathematics to solve problems connected to everyday experiences, investigations in other disciplines, and activities in and outside of school. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and apply mathematics to everyday experiences, to activities in and outside of school, with other disciplines, and with other mathematical topics;

Subject: Math
Text: Use a problem-solving model that incorporates understanding the problem, making a plan, carrying out the plan, and evaluating the solution for reasonableness;

Subject: Math
Text: Select or develop an appropriate problem-solving strategy from a variety of different types, including drawing a picture, looking for a pattern, systematic guessing and checking, acting it out, making a table, working a simpler problem, or working backwards to solve a problem; and

Subject: Math
Text: Select tools such as real objects, manipulatives, paper/pencil, and technology or techniques such as mental math, estimation, and number sense to solve problems.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student communicates about Grade 8 mathematics through informal and mathematical language, representations, and models. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Communicate mathematical ideas using language, efficient tools, appropriate units, and graphical, numerical, physical, or algebraic mathematical models; and

Subject: Math
Text: Evaluate the effectiveness of different representations to communicate ideas.

Subject: Math
Text: Underlying processes and mathematical tools. The student uses logical reasoning to make conjectures and verify conclusions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Make conjectures from patterns or sets of examples and nonexamples; and

Subject: Math
Text: Validate his/her conclusions using mathematical properties and relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student understands that a function represents a dependence of one quantity on another and can be described in a variety of ways. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Describe independent and dependent quantities in functional relationships;

Subject: Math
Text: Gather and record data and use data sets to determine functional relationships between quantities

Subject: Math
Text: Describe functional relationships for given problem situations and write equations or inequalities to answer questions arising from the situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Represent relationships among quantities using concrete models, tables, graphs, diagrams, verbal descriptions, equations, and inequalities; and

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret and make decisions, predictions, and critical judgments from functional relationships.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student uses the properties and attributes of functions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Identify and sketch the general forms of linear (y = x) and quadratic (y = x2) parent functions;

Subject: Math
Text: Identify mathematical domains and ranges and determine reasonable domain and range values for given situations, both continuous and discrete;

Subject: Math
Text: Interpret situations in terms of given graphs or creates situations that fit given graphs; and

Subject: Math
Text: Collect and organize data, make and interpret scatterplots (including recognizing positive, negative, or no correlation for data approximating linear situations), and model, predict, and make decisions and critical judgments in problem situations.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student understands how algebra can be used to express generalizations and recognizes and uses the power of symbols to represent situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use symbols to represent unknowns and variables; and

Subject: Math
Text: Look for patterns and represent generalizations algebraically.

Subject: Math
Text: Foundations for functions. The student understands the importance of the skills required to manipulate symbols in order to solve problems and uses the necessary algebraic skills required to simplify algebraic expressions and solve equations and inequalities in problem situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Find specific function values, simplify polynomial expressions, transform and solve equations, and factor as necessary in problem situations;

Subject: Math
Text: Use the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to simplify algebraic expressions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Connect equation notation with function notation, such as y = x + 1 and f(x) = x + 1.

Subject: Math
Text: Linear functions. The student understands that linear functions can be represented in different ways and translates among their various representations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Determine whether or not given situations can be represented by linear functions;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the domain and range for linear functions in given situations; and

Subject: Math
Text: Use, translate, and make connections among algebraic, tabular, graphical, or verbal descriptions of linear functions.

Subject: Math
Text: Linear functions. The student understands the meaning of the slope and intercepts of the graphs of linear functions and zeros of linear functions and interprets and describes the effects of changes in parameters of linear functions in real-world and mathematical situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: The student conducts investigations, for at least 40% of instructional time, using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. These investigations must involve actively obtaining and analyzing data with physical equipment, but may also involve experimentation in a simulated environment as well as field observations that extend beyond the classroom.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: The student uses a systematic approach to answer scientific laboratory and field investigative questions

Subject: Science
Text: Understand the following definition of science: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

Subject: Science
Text: Know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories

Subject: Science
Text: Know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories

Subject: Science
Text: Design and implement investigative procedures, including making observations, asking well-defined questions, formulating testable hypotheses, identifying variables, selecting appropriate equipment and technology, and evaluating numerical answers for reasonableness

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate the use of course apparatus, equipment, techniques, and procedures, including multimeters (current, voltage, resistance), triple beam balances, batteries, clamps, dynamics demonstration equipment, collision apparatus, data acquisition probes, discharge tubes with power supply (H, He, Ne, Ar), hand-held visual spectroscopes, hot plates, slotted and hooked lab masses, bar magnets, horseshoe magnets, plane mirrors, convex lenses, pendulum support, power supply, ring clamps, ring stands, stopwatches, trajectory apparatus, tuning forks, carbon paper, graph paper, magnetic compasses, polarized film, prisms, protractors, resistors, friction blocks, mini lamps (bulbs) and sockets, electrostatics kits, 90-degree rod clamps, metric rulers, spring scales, knife blade switches, Celsius thermometers, meter sticks, scientific calculators, graphing technology, computers, cathode ray tubes with horseshoe magnets, ballistic carts or equivalent, resonance tubes, spools of nylon thread or string, containers of iron filings, rolls of white craft paper, copper wire, Periodic Table, electromagnetic spectrum charts, slinky springs, wave motion ropes, and laser pointers

Subject: Science
Text: Use a wide variety of additional course apparatus, equipment, techniques, materials, and procedures as appropriate such as ripple tank with wave generator, wave motion rope, micrometer, caliper, radiation monitor, computer, ballistic pendulum, electroscope, inclined plane, optics bench, optics kit, pulley with table clamp, resonance tube, ring stand screen, four inch ring, stroboscope, graduated cylinders, and ticker timer

Subject: Science
Text: Make measurements with accuracy and precision and record data using scientific notation and International System (SI) units

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and quantify causes and effects of uncertainties in measured data

Subject: Science
Text: Organize and evaluate data and make inferences from data, including the use of tables, charts, and graphs

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through various methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports

Subject: Science
Text: Express and manipulate relationships among physical variables quantitatively, including the use of graphs, charts, and equations.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials

Subject: Science
Text: Draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services

Subject: Science
Text: Explain the impacts of the scientific contributions of a variety of historical and contemporary scientists on scientific thought and society

Subject: Science
Text: Research and describe the connections between physics and future careers

Subject: Science
Text: Express and interpret relationships symbolically in accordance with accepted theories to make predictions and solve problems mathematically, including problems requiring proportional reasoning and graphical vector addition.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows and applies the laws governing motion in a variety of situations

Subject: Science
Text: Generate and interpret graphs and charts describing different types of motion, including the use of real-time technology such as motion detectors or photogates

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and analyze motion in one dimension using equations with the concepts of distance, displacement, speed, average velocity, instantaneous velocity, and acceleration

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and describe accelerated motion in two dimensions using equations, including projectile and circular examples

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate the effect of forces on objects, including the law of inertia, the relationship between force and acceleration, and the nature of force pairs between objects

Subject: Science
Text: Develop and interpret free-body force diagrams

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and describe motion relative to different frames of reference.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows the nature of forces in the physical world. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Research and describe the historical development of the concepts of gravitational, electromagnetic, weak nuclear, and strong nuclear forces;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and calculate how the magnitude of the gravitational force between two objects depends on their masses and the distance between their centers;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and calculate how the magnitude of the electrical force between two objects depends on their charges and the distance between them;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify examples of electric and magnetic forces in everyday life;

Subject: Science
Text: Characterize materials as conductors or insulators based on their electrical properties;

Subject: Science
Text: Design, construct, and calculate in terms of current through, potential difference across, resistance of, and power used by electric circuit elements connected in both series and parallel combinations;

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and describe the relationship between electric and magnetic fields in applications such as generators, motors, and transformers; and

Subject: Science
Text: Describe evidence for and effects of the strong and weak nuclear forces in nature.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows that changes occur within a physical system and applies the laws of conservation of energy and momentum. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and calculate quantities using the work-energy theorem in various situations;

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate examples of kinetic and potential energy and their transformations;

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate the mechanical energy of, power generated within, impulse applied to, and momentum of a physical system;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and apply the laws of conservation of energy and conservation of momentum in one dimension;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how the macroscopic properties of a thermodynamic system such as temperature, specific heat, and pressure are related to the molecular level of matter, including kinetic or potential energy of atoms;

Subject: Science
Text: Contrast and give examples of different processes of thermal energy transfer, including conduction, convection, and radiation; and

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and explain everyday examples that illustrate the laws of thermodynamics, including the law of conservation of energy and the law of entropy.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows the characteristics and behavior of waves. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Examine and describe oscillatory motion and wave propagation in various types of media;

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and analyze characteristics of waves, including velocity, frequency, amplitude, and wavelength, and calculate using the relationship between wavespeed, frequency, and wavelength;

Subject: Science
Text: Compare characteristics and behaviors of transverse waves, including electromagnetic waves and the electromagnetic spectrum, and characteristics and behaviors of longitudinal waves, including sound waves;

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate behaviors of waves, including reflection, refraction, diffraction, interference, resonance, and the Doppler effect;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and predict image formation as a consequence of reflection from a plane mirror and refraction through a thin convex lens; and

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the role of wave characteristics and behaviors in medical and industrial applications.

Subject: Science
Text: Science concepts. The student knows simple examples of atomic, nuclear, and quantum phenomena. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the photoelectric effect and the dual nature of light;

Subject: Science
Text: Compare and explain the emission spectra produced by various atoms;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the significance of mass-energy equivalence and apply it in explanations of phenomena such as nuclear stability, fission, and fusion; and

Subject: Science
Text: Give examples of applications of atomic and nuclear phenomena such as radiation therapy, diagnostic imaging, and nuclear power and examples of applications of quantum phenomena such as digital cameras.

Subject: Math
Text: The student defines functions, describes characteristics of functions, and translates among verbal, numerical, graphical, and symbolic representations of functions, including polynomial, rational, power (including radical), exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric, and piecewise-defined functions.

Subject: Math
Text: Describe parent functions symbolically and graphically, including f(x) = xn, f(x) = 1n x, f(x) = loga x, f(x) = 1/x, f(x) = ex, f(x) = |x|, f(x) = ax, f(x) = sin x, f(x) = arcsin x, etc.;

Subject: Math
Text: Determine the domain and range of functions using graphs, tables, and symbols;

Subject: Math
Text: Describe symmetry of graphs of even and odd functions;

Subject: Math
Text: Recognize and use connections among significant values of a function (zeros, maximum values, minimum values, etc.), points on the graph of a function, and the symbolic representation of a function; and

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate the concepts of continuity, end behavior, asymptotes, and limits and connect these characteristics to functions represented graphically and numerically.

Subject: Math
Text: The student interprets the meaning of the symbolic representations of functions and operations on functions to solve meaningful problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Apply basic transformations, including a ‰Û¢ f(x), f(x) + d, f(x - c), f(b ‰Û¢ x), and compositions with absolute value functions, including |f(x)|, and f(|x|), to the parent functions;

Subject: Math
Text: Perform operations including composition on functions, find inverses, and describe these procedures and results verbally, numerically, symbolically, and graphically; and

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate identities graphically and verify them symbolically, including logarithmic properties, trigonometric identities, and exponential properties.

Subject: Math
Text: The student uses functions and their properties, tools and technology, to model and solve meaningful problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Investigate properties of trigonometric and polynomial functions;

Subject: Math
Text: Use functions such as logarithmic, exponential, trigonometric, polynomial, etc. to model real-life data;

Subject: Math
Text: Use regression to determine the appropriateness of a linear function to model real-life data (including using technology to determine the correlation coefficient);

Subject: Math
Text: Use properties of functions to analyze and solve problems and make predictions; and

Subject: Math
Text: Solve problems from physical situations using trigonometry, including the use of Law of Sines, Law of Cosines, and area formulas and incorporate radian measure where needed.

Subject: Math
Text: The student uses sequences and series as well as tools and technology to represent, analyze, and solve real-life problems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Represent patterns using arithmetic and geometric sequences and series;

Subject: Math
Text: Use arithmetic, geometric, and other sequences and series to solve real-life problems;

Subject: Math
Text: Describe limits of sequences and apply their properties to investigate convergent and divergent series; and

Subject: Math
Text: Apply sequences and series to solve problems including sums and binomial expansion.

Subject: Math
Text: The student uses conic sections, their properties, and parametric representations, as well as tools and technology, to model physical situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use conic sections to model motion, such as the graph of velocity vs. position of a pendulum and motions of planets;

Subject: Math
Text: Use properties of conic sections to describe physical phenomena such as the reflective properties of light and sound;

Subject: Math
Text: Convert between parametric and rectangular forms of functions and equations to graph them

Subject: Math
Text: Use parametric functions to simulate problems involving motion.

Subject: Math
Text: The student uses vectors to model physical situations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Math
Text: Use the concept of vectors to model situations defined by magnitude and direction; and

Subject: Math
Text: Analyze and solve vector problems generated by real-life situations.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student conducts classroom and outdoor investigations following home and school safety procedures and uses environmentally appropriate and responsible practices. The student is expected to:
Keywords: tool, equipment, lab, expiriment, listening, reading,

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and demonstrate safe practices as described in the Texas Safety Standards during classroom and outdoor investigations, including wearing safety goggles, washing hands, and using materials appropriately;

Subject: Science
Text: Discuss the importance of safe practices to keep self and others safe and healthy; and

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate how to use, conserve, and dispose of natural resources and materials such as conserving water and reusing or recycling paper, plastic, and metal.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student develops abilities to ask questions and seek answers in classroom and outdoor investigations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Ask questions about organisms, objects, and events observed in the natural world;

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and conduct simple descriptive investigations such as ways objects move;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect data and make observations using simple equipment such as hand lenses, primary balances, and non-standard measurement tools;

Subject: Science
Text: Record and organize data and observations using pictures, numbers, and words; and

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate observations with others about simple descriptive investigations

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows that information and critical thinking are used in scientific problem solving. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and explain a problem such as the impact of littering on the playground and propose a solution in his/her own words;

Subject: Science
Text: Make predictions based on observable patterns in nature such as the shapes of leaves; and

Subject: Science
Text: Explore that scientists investigate different things in the natural world and use tools to help in their investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses age-appropriate tools and models to investigate the natural world. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Collect information using tools, including computers, hand lenses, primary balances, cups, bowls, magnets, collecting nets, and notebooks; timing devices, including clocks and timers; non-standard measuring items such as paper clips and clothespins; weather instruments such as demonstration thermometers and wind socks; and materials to support observations of habitats of organisms such as terrariums and aquariums; and

Subject: Science
Text: Use senses as a tool of observation to identify properties and patterns of organisms, objects, and events in the environment.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that objects have properties and patterns. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and record properties of objects, including relative size and mass, such as bigger or smaller and heavier or lighter, shape, color, and texture; and

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, record, and discuss how materials can be changed by heating or cooling.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that energy, force, and motion are related and are a part of their everyday life. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Use the five senses to explore different forms of energy such as light, heat, and sound;

Subject: Science
Text: Explore interactions between magnets and various materials;

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe the location of an object in relation to another such as above, below, behind, in front of, and beside; and

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe the ways that objects can move such as in a straight line, zigzag, up and down, back and forth, round and round, and fast and slow.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that the natural world includes earth materials. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, describe, compare, and sort rocks by size, shape, color, and texture;

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe physical properties of natural sources of water, including color and clarity; and

Subject: Science
Text: Give examples of ways rocks, soil, and water are useful.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that there are recognizable patterns in the natural world and among objects in the sky. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe weather changes from day to day and over seasons;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify events that have repeating patterns, including seasons of the year and day and night; and

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, describe, and illustrate objects in the sky such as the clouds, Moon, and stars, including the Sun.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that plants and animals have basic needs and depend on the living and nonliving things around them for survival. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between living and nonliving things based upon whether they have basic needs and produce offspring; and

Subject: Science
Text: Examine evidence that living organisms have basic needs such as food, water, and shelter for animals and air, water, nutrients, sunlight, and space for plants.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms resemble their parents and have structures and processes that help them survive within their environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Sort plants and animals into groups based on physical characteristics such as color, size, body covering, or leaf shape;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify parts of plants such as roots, stem, and leaves and parts of animals such as head, eyes, and limbs;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify ways that young plants resemble the parent plant; and

Subject: Science
Text: Observe changes that are part of a simple life cycle of a plant: seed, seedling, plant, flower, and fruit.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student conducts classroom and outdoor investigations following home and school safety procedures and uses environmentally appropriate and responsible practices. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize and demonstrate safe practices as described in the Texas Safety Standards during classroom and outdoor investigations, including wearing safety goggles, washing hands, and using materials appropriately;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize the importance of safe practices to keep self and others safe and healthy; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and learn how to use natural resources and materials, including conservation and reuse or recycling of paper, plastic, and metals.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student develops abilities to ask questions and seek answers in classroom and outdoor investigations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Ask questions about organisms, objects, and events observed in the natural world;

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and conduct simple descriptive investigations such as ways objects move;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect data and make observations using simple equipment such as hand lenses, primary balances, and non-standard measurement tools;

Subject: Science
Text: Record and organize data using pictures, numbers, and words; and

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate observations and provide reasons for explanations using student-generated data from simple descriptive investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows that information and critical thinking are used in scientific problem solving. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and explain a problem such as finding a home for a classroom pet and propose a solution in his/her own words;

Subject: Science
Text: Make predictions based on observable patterns; and

Subject: Science
Text: Describe what scientists do.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses age-appropriate tools and models to investigate the natural world. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Collect, record, and compare information using tools, including computers, hand lenses, primary balances, cups, bowls, magnets, collecting nets, notebooks, and safety goggles; timing devices, including clocks and timers; non-standard measuring items such as paper clips and clothespins; weather instruments such as classroom demonstration thermometers and wind socks; and materials to support observations of habitats of organisms such as aquariums and terrariums; and

Subject: Science
Text: Measure and compare organisms and objects using non-standard units.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that objects have properties and patterns. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Classify objects by observable properties of the materials from which they are made such as larger and smaller, heavier and lighter, shape, color, and texture; and

Subject: Science
Text: Predict and identify changes in materials caused by heating and cooling such as ice melting, water freezing, and water evaporating.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that force, motion, and energy are related and are a part of everyday life. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and discuss how different forms of energy such as light, heat, and sound are important to everyday life;

Subject: Science
Text: Predict and describe how a magnet can be used to push or pull an object;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the change in the location of an object such as closer to, nearer to, and farther from;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and record the ways that objects can move such as in a straight line, zig zag, up and down, back and forth, round and round, and fast and slow.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that the natural world includes rocks, soil, and water that can be observed in cycles, patterns, and systems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, compare, describe, and sort components of soil by size, texture, and color;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and describe a variety of natural sources of water, including streams, lakes, and oceans; and

Subject: Science
Text: Gather evidence of how rocks, soil, and water help to make useful products.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that the natural world includes the air around us and objects in the sky. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Record weather information, including relative temperature, such as hot or cold, clear or cloudy, calm or windy, and rainy or icy;

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and record changes in the appearance of objects in the sky such as clouds, the Moon, and stars, including the Sun;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify characteristics of the seasons of the year and day and night; and

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that air is all around us and observe that wind is moving air.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that the living environment is composed of relationships between organisms and the life cycles that occur. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Sort and classify living and nonliving things based upon whether or not they have basic needs and produce offspring;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and record examples of interdependence found in various situations such as terrariums and aquariums or pet and caregiver; and

Subject: Science
Text: Gather evidence of interdependence among living organisms such as energy transfer through food chains and animals using plants for shelter.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms resemble their parents and have structures and processes that help them survive within their environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate how the external characteristics of an animal are related to where it lives, how it moves, and what it eats;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and compare the parts of plants;

Subject: Science
Text: Compare ways that young animals resemble their parents

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and record life cycles of animals such as a chicken, frog, or fish.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student conducts classroom and outdoor investigations following home and school safety procedures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and demonstrate safe practices as described in the Texas Safety Standards during classroom and outdoor investigations, including wearing safety goggles, washing hands, and using materials appropriately;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the importance of safe practices; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and demonstrate how to use, conserve, and dispose of natural resources and materials such as conserving water and reuse or recycling of paper, plastic, and metal.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student develops abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry in classroom and outdoor investigations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Ask questions about organisms, objects, and events during observations and investigations;

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and conduct descriptive investigations such as how organisms grow;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect data from observations using simple equipment such as hand lenses, primary balances, thermometers, and non-standard measurement tools;

Subject: Science
Text: Record and organize data using pictures, numbers, and words;

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate observations and justify explanations using student-generated data from simple descriptive investigations; and

Subject: Science
Text: Compare results of investigations with what students and scientists know about the world.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows that information and critical thinking, scientific problem solving, and the contributions of scientists are used in making decisions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and explain a problem in his/her own words and propose a task and solution for the problem such as lack of water in a habitat;

Subject: Science
Text: Make predictions based on observable patterns;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify what a scientist is and explore what different scientists do.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses age-appropriate tools and models to investigate the natural world. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Collect, record, and compare information using tools, including computers, hand lenses, rulers, primary balances, plastic beakers, magnets, collecting nets, notebooks, and safety goggles; timing devices, including clocks and stopwatches; weather instruments such as thermometers, wind vanes, and rain gauges; and materials to support observations of habitats of organisms such as terrariums and aquariums; and

Subject: Science
Text: Measure and compare organisms and objects using non-standard units that approximate metric units.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter has physical properties and those properties determine how it is described, classified, changed, and used. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Classify matter by physical properties, including shape, relative mass, relative temperature, texture, flexibility, and whether material is a solid or liquid;

Subject: Science
Text: Compare changes in materials caused by heating and cooling;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that things can be done to materials to change their physical properties such as cutting, folding, sanding, and melting; and

Subject: Science
Text: Combine materials that when put together can do things that they cannot do by themselves such as building a tower or a bridge and justify the selection of those materials based on their physical properties.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that forces cause change and energy exists in many forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate the effects on an object by increasing or decreasing amounts of light, heat, and sound energy such as how the color of an object appears different in dimmer light or how heat melts butter;

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and identify how magnets are used in everyday life;

Subject: Science
Text: Trace the changes in the position of an object over time such as a cup rolling on the floor and a car rolling down a ramp; and

Subject: Science
Text: Compare patterns of movement of objects such as sliding, rolling, and spinning.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that the natural world includes earth materials. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe rocks by size, texture, and color

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and compare the properties of natural sources of freshwater and saltwater; and

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between natural and manmade resources.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that there are recognizable patterns in the natural world and among objects in the sky. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Measure, record, and graph weather information, including temperature, wind conditions, precipitation, and cloud coverage, in order to identify patterns in the data;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the importance of weather and seasonal information to make choices in clothing, activities, and transportation;

Subject: Science
Text: Explore the processes in the water cycle, including evaporation, condensation, and precipitation, as connected to weather conditions; and

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, describe, and record patterns of objects in the sky, including the appearance of the Moon.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that living organisms have basic needs that must be met for them to survive within their environment. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the basic needs of plants and animals;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify factors in the environment, including temperature and precipitation, that affect growth and behavior such as migration, hibernation, and dormancy of living things; and

Subject: Science
Text: Compare and give examples of the ways living organisms depend on each other and on their environments such as food chains within a garden, park, beach, lake, and wooded area.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms resemble their parents and have structures and processes that help them survive within their environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, record, and compare how the physical characteristics and behaviors of animals help them meet their basic needs such as fins help fish move and balance in the water;

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, record, and compare how the physical characteristics of plants help them meet their basic needs such as stems carry water throughout the plant; and

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and record some of the unique stages that insects undergo during their life cycle.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student conducts classroom and outdoor investigations following school and home safety procedures and environmentally appropriate practices. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices as described in the Texas Safety Standards during classroom and outdoor investigations, including observing a schoolyard habitat; and

Subject: Science
Text: Make informed choices in the use and conservation of natural resources by recycling or reusing materials such as paper, aluminum cans, and plastics.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific inquiry methods during laboratory and outdoor investigations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement descriptive investigations, including asking and answering questions, making inferences, and selecting and using equipment or technology needed, to solve a specific problem in the natural world;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect data by observing and measuring using the metric system and recognize differences between observed and measured data;

Subject: Science
Text: Construct maps, graphic organizers, simple tables, charts, and bar graphs using tools and current technology to organize, examine, and evaluate measured data;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and interpret patterns in data to construct reasonable explanations based on evidence from investigations;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that repeated investigations may increase the reliability of results; and

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid conclusions supported by data in writing, by drawing pictures, and through verbal discussion.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows that information, critical thinking, scientific problem solving, and the contributions of scientists are used in making decisions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student

Subject: Science
Text: Draw inferences and evaluate accuracy of product claims found in advertisements and labels such as for toys and food;

Subject: Science
Text: Represent the natural world using models such as volcanoes or Sun, Earth, and Moon system and identify their limitations, including size, properties, and materials; and

Subject: Science
Text: Connect grade-level appropriate science concepts with the history of science, science careers, and contributions of scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows how to use a variety of tools and methods to conduct science inquiry. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Collect, record, and analyze information using tools, including microscopes, cameras, computers, hand lenses, metric rulers, Celsius thermometers, wind vanes, rain gauges, pan balances, graduated cylinders, beakers, spring scales, hot plates, meter sticks, compasses, magnets, collecting nets, notebooks, sound recorders, and Sun, Earth, and Moon system models; timing devices, including clocks and stopwatches; and materials to support observation of habitats of organisms such as terrariums and aquariums; and

Subject: Science
Text: Use safety equipment as appropriate, including safety goggles and gloves.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter has measurable physical properties and those properties determine how matter is classified, changed, and used. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Measure, test, and record physical properties of matter, including temperature, mass, magnetism, and the ability to sink or float;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and classify samples of matter as solids, liquids, and gases and demonstrate that solids have a definite shape and that liquids and gases take the shape of their container;

Subject: Science
Text: Predict, observe, and record changes in the state of matter caused by heating or cooling; and

Subject: Science
Text: Explore and recognize that a mixture is created when two materials are combined such as gravel and sand and metal and plastic paper clips.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that forces cause change and that energy exists in many forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Explore different forms of energy, including mechanical, light, sound, and heat/thermal in everyday life;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and observe how position and motion can be changed by pushing and pulling objects to show work being done such as swings, balls, pulleys, and wagons; and

Subject: Science
Text: Observe forces such as magnetism and gravity acting on objects.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that Earth consists of natural resources and its surface is constantly changing. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Explore and record how soils are formed by weathering of rock and the decomposition of plant and animal remains;

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate rapid changes in Earth's surface such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, and landslides;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and compare different landforms, including mountains, hills, valleys, and plains; and

Subject: Science
Text: Explore the characteristics of natural resources that make them useful in products and materials such as clothing and furniture and how resources may be conserved.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows there are recognizable patterns in the natural world and among objects in the sky. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, measure, record, and compare day-to-day weather changes in different locations at the same time that include air temperature, wind direction, and precipitation;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and illustrate the Sun as a star composed of gases that provides light and heat energy for the water cycle;

Subject: Science
Text: Construct models that demonstrate the relationship of the Sun, Earth, and Moon, including orbits and positions; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the planets in Earth's solar system and their position in relation to the Sun.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms have characteristics that help them survive and can describe patterns, cycles, systems, and relationships within the environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe the physical characteristics of environments and how they support populations and communities within an ecosystem;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and describe the flow of energy in a food chain and predict how changes in a food chain affect the ecosystem such as removal of frogs from a pond or bees from a field; and

Subject: Science
Text: Describe environmental changes such as floods and droughts where some organisms thrive and others perish or move to new locations.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms undergo similar life processes and have structures that help them survive within their environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Explore how structures and functions of plants and animals allow them to survive in a particular environment;

Subject: Science
Text: Explore that some characteristics of organisms are inherited such as the number of limbs on an animal or flower color and recognize that some behaviors are learned in response to living in a certain environment such as animals using tools to get food; and

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and compare how animals and plants undergo a series of orderly changes in their diverse life cycles such as tomato plants, frogs, and lady bugs.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student conducts classroom and outdoor investigations, following home and school safety procedures and environmentally appropriate and ethical practices. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices and the use of safety equipment as described in the Texas Safety Standards during classroom and outdoor investigations; and

Subject: Science
Text: Make informed choices in the use and conservation of natural resources and reusing and recycling of materials such as paper, aluminum, glass, cans, and plastic.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific inquiry methods during laboratory and outdoor investigations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement descriptive investigations, including asking well-defined questions, making inferences, and selecting and using appropriate equipment or technology to answer his/her questions;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect and record data by observing and measuring, using the metric system, and using descriptive words and numerals such as labeled drawings, writing, and concept maps;

Subject: Science
Text: Construct simple tables, charts, bar graphs, and maps using tools and current technology to organize, examine, and evaluate data;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze data and interpret patterns to construct reasonable explanations from data that can be observed and measured;

Subject: Science
Text: Perform repeated investigations to increase the reliability of results; and

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid, oral, and written results supported by data.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses critical thinking and scientific problem solving to make informed decisions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

Subject: Science
Text: Draw inferences and evaluate accuracy of services and product claims found in advertisements and labels such as for toys, food, and sunscreen;

Subject: Science
Text: Represent the natural world using models such as rivers, stream tables, or fossils and identify their limitations, including accuracy and size; and

Subject: Science
Text: Connect grade-level appropriate science concepts with the history of science, science careers, and contributions of scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows how to use a variety of tools, materials, equipment, and models to conduct science inquiry. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Collect, record, and analyze information using tools, including calculators, microscopes, cameras, computers, hand lenses, metric rulers, Celsius thermometers, mirrors, spring scales, pan balances, triple beam balances, graduated cylinders, beakers, hot plates, meter sticks, compasses, magnets, collecting nets, and notebooks; timing devices, including clocks and stopwatches; and materials to support observation of habitats of organisms such as terrariums and aquariums; and

Subject: Science
Text: Use safety equipment as appropriate, including safety goggles and gloves.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter has measurable physical properties and those properties determine how matter is classified, changed, and used. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Measure, compare, and contrast physical properties of matter, including size, mass, volume, states (solid, liquid, gas), temperature, magnetism, and the ability to sink or float;

Subject: Science
Text: Predict the changes caused by heating and cooling such as ice becoming liquid water and condensation forming on the outside of a glass of ice water; and

Subject: Science
Text: Compare and contrast a variety of mixtures and solutions such as rocks in sand, sand in water, or sugar in water.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that energy exists in many forms and can be observed in cycles, patterns, and systems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate among forms of energy, including mechanical, sound, electrical, light, and heat/thermal;

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between conductors and insulators;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that electricity travels in a closed path, creating an electrical circuit, and explore an electromagnetic field; and

Subject: Science
Text: Design an experiment to test the effect of force on an object such as a push or a pull, gravity, friction, or magnetism.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The students know that Earth consists of useful resources and its surface is constantly changing. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Examine properties of soils, including color and texture, capacity to retain water, and ability to support the growth of plants;

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and identify slow changes to Earth's surface caused by weathering, erosion, and deposition from water, wind, and ice; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and classify Earth's renewable resources, including air, plants, water, and animals; and nonrenewable resources, including coal, oil, and natural gas; and the importance of conservation.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that there are recognizable patterns in the natural world and among the Sun, Earth, and Moon system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Measure and record changes in weather and make predictions using weather maps, weather symbols, and a map key;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and illustrate the continuous movement of water above and on the surface of Earth through the water cycle and explain the role of the Sun as a major source of energy in this process; and

Subject: Science
Text: Collect and analyze data to identify sequences and predict patterns of change in shadows, tides, seasons, and the observable appearance of the Moon over time.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows and understands that living organisms within an ecosystem interact with one another and with their environment. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate that most producers need sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to make their own food, while consumers are dependent on other organisms for food; and

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the flow of energy through food webs, beginning with the Sun, and predict how changes in the ecosystem affect the food web such as a fire in a forest.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms undergo similar life processes and have structures that help them survive within their environment. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Explore how adaptations enable organisms to survive in their environment such as comparing birds' beaks and leaves on plants;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that some likenesses between parents and offspring are inherited, passed from generation to generation such as eye color in humans or shapes of leaves in plants. Other likenesses are learned such as table manners or reading a book and seals balancing balls on their noses; and

Subject: Science
Text: Explore, illustrate, and compare life cycles in living organisms such as butterflies, beetles, radishes, or lima beans.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student conducts classroom and outdoor investigations following home and school safety procedures and environmentally appropriate and ethical practices. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices and the use of safety equipment as described in the Texas Safety Standards during classroom and outdoor investigations; and

Subject: Science
Text: Make informed choices in the conservation, disposal, and recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific methods during laboratory and outdoor investigations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Describe, plan, and implement simple experimental investigations testing one variable;

Subject: Science
Text: Ask well-defined questions, formulate testable hypotheses, and select and use appropriate equipment and technology;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect information by detailed observations and accurate measuring;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze and interpret information to construct reasonable explanations from direct (observable) and indirect (inferred) evidence;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that repeated investigations may increase the reliability of results;

Subject: Science
Text: Communicate valid conclusions in both written and verbal forms; and

Subject: Science
Text: Construct appropriate simple graphs, tables, maps, and charts using technology, including computers, to organize, examine, and evaluate information.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses critical thinking and scientific problem solving to make informed decisions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

Subject: Science
Text: Evaluate the accuracy of the information related to promotional materials for products and services such as nutritional labels;

Subject: Science
Text: Draw or develop a model that represents how something works or looks that cannot be seen such as how a soda dispensing machine works; and

Subject: Science
Text: Connect grade-level appropriate science concepts with the history of science, science careers, and contributions of scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows how to use a variety of tools and methods to conduct science inquiry. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Collect, record, and analyze information using tools, including calculators, microscopes, cameras, computers, hand lenses, metric rulers, Celsius thermometers, prisms, mirrors, pan balances, triple beam balances, spring scales, graduated cylinders, beakers, hot plates, meter sticks, magnets, collecting nets, and notebooks; timing devices, including clocks and stopwatches; and materials to support observations of habitats or organisms such as terrariums and aquariums; and

Subject: Science
Text: Use safety equipment, including safety goggles and gloves.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter has measurable physical properties and those properties determine how matter is classified, changed, and used. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Classify matter based on physical properties, including mass, magnetism, physical state (solid, liquid, and gas), relative density (sinking and floating), solubility in water, and the ability to conduct or insulate thermal energy or electric energy;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the boiling and freezing/melting points of water on the Celsius scale;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that some mixtures maintain physical properties of their ingredients such as iron filings and sand; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify changes that can occur in the physical properties of the ingredients of solutions such as dissolving salt in water or adding lemon juice to water.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that energy occurs in many forms and can be observed in cycles, patterns, and systems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Explore the uses of energy, including mechanical, light, thermal, electrical, and sound energy;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that the flow of electricity in circuits requires a complete path through which an electric current can pass and can produce light, heat, and sound;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that light travels in a straight line until it strikes an object or travels through one medium to another and demonstrate that light can be reflected such as the use of mirrors or other shiny surfaces and refracted such as the appearance of an object when observed through water; and

Subject: Science
Text: Design an experiment that tests the effect of force on an object.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows Earth's surface is constantly changing and consists of useful resources. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Explore the processes that led to the formation of sedimentary rocks and fossil fuels;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize how landforms such as deltas, canyons, and sand dunes are the result of changes to Earth's surface by wind, water, and ice;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify alternative energy resources such as wind, solar, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biofuels; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify fossils as evidence of past living organisms and the nature of the environments at the time using models.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that there are recognizable patterns in the natural world and among the Sun, Earth, and Moon system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between weather and climate;

Subject: Science
Text: Explain how the Sun and the ocean interact in the water cycle;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate that Earth rotates on its axis once approximately every 24 hours causing the day/night cycle and the apparent movement of the Sun across the sky; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and compare the physical characteristics of the Sun, Earth, and Moon.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that there are relationships, systems, and cycles within environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Observe the way organisms live and survive in their ecosystem by interacting with the living and non-living elements;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how the flow of energy derived from the Sun, used by producers to create their own food, is transferred through a food chain and food web to consumers and decomposers;

Subject: Science
Text: Predict the effects of changes in ecosystems caused by living organisms, including humans, such as the overpopulation of grazers or the building of highways; and

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the significance of the carbon dioxide-oxygen cycle to the survival of plants and animals.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that organisms undergo similar life processes and have structures that help them survive within their environments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Science
Text: Compare the structures and functions of different species that help them live and survive such as hooves on prairie animals or webbed feet in aquatic animals;

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between inherited traits of plants and animals such as spines on a cactus or shape of a beak and learned behaviors such as an animal learning tricks or a child riding a bicycle; and

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the differences between complete and incomplete metamorphosis of insects.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations following safety procedures and environmentally appropriate and ethical practices.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations as outlined in the Texas Safety Standards

Subject: Science
Text: Practice appropriate use and conservation of resources, including disposal, reuse, or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific inquiry methods during laboratory and field investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement comparative and descriptive investigations by making observations, asking well-defined questions, and using appropriate equipment and technology;

Subject: Science
Text: Design and implement experimental investigations by making observations, asking well-defined questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and using appropriate equipment and technology;

Subject: Science
Text: Collect and record data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative means such as labeled drawings, writing, and graphic organizers;

Subject: Science
Text: Construct tables and graphs, using repeated trials and means, to organize data and identify patterns

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions and knows the contributions of relevant scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student

Subject: Science
Text: Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as a model of Earth's layers;

Subject: Science
