Text: Identify advantages and limitations of models such as size, scale, properties, and materials

Subject: Science
Text: Relate the impact of research on scientific thought and society, including the history of science and contributions of scientists as related to the content.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student knows how to use a variety of tools and safety equipment to conduct science inquiry.

Subject: Science
Text: Use appropriate tools to collect, record, and analyze information, including journals/notebooks, beakers, Petri dishes, meter sticks, graduated cylinders, hot plates, test tubes, triple beam balances, microscopes, thermometers, calculators, computers, timing devices, and other equipment as needed to teach the curriculum;

Subject: Science
Text: Use preventative safety equipment, including chemical splash goggles, aprons, and gloves, and be prepared to use emergency safety equipment, including an eye/face wash, a fire blanket, and a fire extinguisher.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows the differences between elements and compounds.

Subject: Science
Text: Know that an element is a pure substance represented by chemical symbols;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that a limited number of the many known elements comprise the largest portion of solid Earth, living matter, oceans, and the atmosphere;

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between elements and compounds on the most basic level;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the formation of a new substance by using the evidence of a possible chemical change such as production of a gas, change in temperature, production of a precipitate, or color change.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows matter has physical properties that can be used for classification.

Subject: Science
Text: Compare metals, nonmetals, and metalloids using physical properties such as luster, conductivity, or malleability;

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate density to identify an unknown substance;

Subject: Science
Text: Test the physical properties of minerals, including hardness, color, luster, and streak.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that some of Earth's energy resources are available on a nearly perpetual basis, while others can be renewed over a relatively short period of time. Some energy resources, once depleted, are essentially nonrenewable.

Subject: Science
Text: Research and debate the advantages and disadvantages of using coal, oil, natural gas, nuclear power, biomass, wind, hydropower, geothermal, and solar resources;

Subject: Science
Text: Design a logical plan to manage energy resources in the home, school, or community.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows force and motion are related to potential and kinetic energy.

Subject: Science
Text: Compare and contrast potential and kinetic energy

Subject: Science
Text: Identify and describe the changes in position, direction, and speed of an object when acted upon by unbalanced forces;

Subject: Science
Text: Calculate average speed using distance and time measurements;

Subject: Science
Text: Measure and graph changes in motion

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate how inclined planes and pulleys can be used to change the amount of force to move an object.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that the Law of Conservation of Energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed, it just changes form.

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate methods of thermal energy transfer, including conduction, convection, and radiation

Subject: Science
Text: Verify through investigations that thermal energy moves in a predictable pattern from warmer to cooler until all the substances attain the same temperature such as an ice cube melting;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate energy transformations such as energy in a flashlight battery changes from chemical energy to electrical energy to light energy.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student understands the structure of Earth, the rock cycle, and plate tectonics.

Subject: Science
Text: Build a model to illustrate the structural layers of Earth, including the inner core, outer core, mantle, crust, asthenosphere, and lithosphere

Subject: Science
Text: Classify rocks as metamorphic, igneous, or sedimentary by the processes of their formation

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the major tectonic plates, including Eurasian, African, Indo-Australian, Pacific, North American, and South American;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how plate tectonics causes major geological events such as ocean basins, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and mountain building.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student understands the organization of our solar system and the relationships among the various bodies that comprise it.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the physical properties, locations, and movements of the Sun, planets, Galilean moons, meteors, asteroids, and comets

Subject: Science
Text: Understand that gravity is the force that governs the motion of our solar system;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the history and future of space exploration, including the types of equipment and transportation needed for space travel.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows all organisms are classified into Domains and Kingdoms. Organisms within these taxonomic groups share similar characteristics which allow them to interact with the living and nonliving parts of their ecosystem.

Subject: Science
Text: Understand that all organisms are composed of one or more cells;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that the presence of a nucleus determines whether a cell is prokaryotic or eukaryotic

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that the broadest taxonomic classification of living organisms is divided into currently recognized Domains

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the basic characteristics of organisms, including prokaryotic or eukaryotic, unicellular or multicellular, autotrophic or heterotrophic, and mode of reproduction, that further classify them in the currently recognized Kingdoms

Subject: Science
Text: Describe biotic and abiotic parts of an ecosystem in which organisms interact

Subject: Science
Text: Diagram the levels of organization within an ecosystem, including organism, population, community, and ecosystem.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student, for at least 40% of the instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations following safety procedures and environmentally appropriate and ethical practices.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations as outlined in the Texas Safety Standards

Subject: Science
Text: Practice appropriate use and conservation of resources, including disposal, reuse, or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific inquiry methods during laboratory and field investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement comparative and descriptive investigations by making observations, asking well-defined questions, and using appropriate equipment and technology;

Subject: Science
Text: Design and implement experimental investigations by making observations, asking well-defined questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and using appropriate equipment and technology

Subject: Science
Text: Collect and record data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative means such as labeled drawings, writing, and graphic organizers

Subject: Science
Text: Construct tables and graphs, using repeated trials and means, to organize data and identify patterns;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions and knows the contributions of relevant scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

Subject: Science
Text: Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as human body systems and plant and animal cells;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify advantages and limitations of models such as size, scale, properties, and materials

Subject: Science
Text: Relate the impact of research on scientific thought and society, including the history of science and contributions of scientists as related to the content.

Subject: Science
Text: Science investigation and reasoning. The student knows how to use a variety of tools and safety equipment to conduct science inquiry.

Subject: Science
Text: Use appropriate tools to collect, record, and analyze information, including life science models, hand lens, stereoscopes, microscopes, beakers, Petri dishes, microscope slides, graduated cylinders, test tubes, meter sticks, metric rulers, metric tape measures, timing devices, hot plates, balances, thermometers, calculators, water test kits, computers, temperature and pH probes, collecting nets, insect traps, globes, digital cameras, journals/notebooks, and other equipment as needed to teach the curriculum;

Subject: Science
Text: Use preventative safety equipment, including chemical splash goggles, aprons, and gloves, and be prepared to use emergency safety equipment, including an eye/face wash, a fire blanket, and a fire extinguisher.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that interactions occur between matter and energy.

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that radiant energy from the Sun is transformed into chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and explain the cycling of matter within living systems such as in the decay of biomass in a compost bin

Subject: Science
Text: Diagram the flow of energy through living systems, including food chains, food webs, and energy pyramids.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter has physical and chemical properties and can undergo physical and chemical changes.

Subject: Science
Text: Identify that organic compounds contain carbon and other elements such as hydrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, nitrogen, or sulfur

Subject: Science
Text: Distinguish between physical and chemical changes in matter in the digestive system;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize how large molecules are broken down into smaller molecules such as carbohydrates can be broken down into sugars.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that there is a relationship among force, motion, and energy.

Subject: Science
Text: Contrast situations where work is done with different amounts of force to situations where no work is done such as moving a box with a ramp and without a ramp, or standing still

Subject: Science
Text: Illustrate the transformation of energy within an organism such as the transfer from chemical energy to heat and thermal energy in digestion;

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and illustrate forces that affect motion in everyday life such as emergence of seedlings, turgor pressure, and geotropism.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that natural events and human activity can impact Earth systems.

Subject: Science
Text: Predict and describe how different types of catastrophic events impact ecosystems such as floods, hurricanes, or tornadoes;

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze the effects of weathering, erosion, and deposition on the environment in ecoregions of Texas

Subject: Science
Text: Model the effects of human activity on groundwater and surface water in a watershed.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows components of our solar system.

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze the characteristics of objects in our solar system that allow life to exist such as the proximity of the Sun, presence of water, and composition of the atmosphere;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the accommodations, considering the characteristics of our solar system, that enabled manned space exploration.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that there is a relationship between organisms and the environment.

Subject: Science
Text: Observe and describe how different environments, including microhabitats in schoolyards and biomes, support different varieties of organisms;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe how biodiversity contributes to the sustainability of an ecosystem

Subject: Science
Text: Observe, record, and describe the role of ecological succession such as in a microhabitat of a garden with weeds.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that populations and species demonstrate variation and inherit many of their unique traits through gradual processes over many generations.

Subject: Science
Text: Examine organisms or their structures such as insects or leaves and use dichotomous keys for identification;

Subject: Science
Text: Explain variation within a population or species by comparing external features, behaviors, or physiology of organisms that enhance their survival such as migration, hibernation, or storage of food in a bulb;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify some changes in genetic traits that have occurred over several generations through natural selection and selective breeding such as the Galapagos Medium Ground Finch (Geospiza fortis) or domestic animals.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that living systems at all levels of organization demonstrate the complementary nature of structure and function.

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and explain how internal structures of organisms have adaptations that allow specific functions such as gills in fish, hollow bones in birds, or xylem in plants;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the main functions of the systems of the human organism, including the circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, digestive, excretory, reproductive, integumentary, nervous, and endocrine systems

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize levels of organization in plants and animals, including cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between structure and function in plant and animal cell organelles, including cell membrane, cell wall, nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondrion, chloroplast, and vacuole

Subject: Science
Text: Compare the functions of a cell to the functions of organisms such as waste removal;

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that according to cell theory all organisms are composed of cells and cells carry on similar functions such as extracting energy from food to sustain life.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that a living organism must be able to maintain balance in stable internal conditions in response to external and internal stimuli.

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate how organisms respond to external stimuli found in the environment such as phototropism and fight or flight;

Subject: Science
Text: Describe and relate responses in organisms that may result from internal stimuli such as wilting in plants and fever or vomiting in animals that allow them to maintain balance.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that reproduction is a characteristic of living organisms and that the instructions for traits are governed in the genetic material.

Subject: Science
Text: Define heredity as the passage of genetic instructions from one generation to the next generation

Subject: Science
Text: Compare the results of uniform or diverse offspring from sexual reproduction or asexual reproduction

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that inherited traits of individuals are governed in the genetic material found in the genes within chromosomes in the nucleus.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations following safety procedures and environmentally appropriate and ethical practices.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations as outlined in the Texas Safety Standards

Subject: Science
Text: Practice appropriate use and conservation of resources, including disposal, reuse, or recycling of materials.

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific inquiry methods during laboratory and field investigations.

Subject: Science
Text: Plan and implement comparative and descriptive investigations by making observations, asking well-defined questions, and using appropriate equipment and technology

Subject: Science
Text: Design and implement comparative and experimental investigations by making observations, asking well-defined questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and using appropriate equipment and technology

Subject: Science
Text: Collect and record data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative means such as labeled drawings, writing, and graphic organizers

Subject: Science
Text: Construct tables and graphs, using repeated trials and means, to organize data and identify patterns

Subject: Science
Text: Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends

Subject: Science
Text: Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions and knows the contributions of relevant scientists.

Subject: Science
Text: In all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

Subject: Science
Text: Use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as an atom, a molecule, space, or a geologic feature

Subject: Science
Text: Identify advantages and limitations of models such as size, scale, properties, and materials;

Subject: Science
Text: Relate the impact of research on scientific thought and society, including the history of science and contributions of scientists as related to the content.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter is composed of atoms and has chemical and physical properties.

Subject: Science
Text: Use appropriate tools to collect, record, and analyze information, including lab journals/notebooks, beakers, meter sticks, graduated cylinders, anemometers, psychrometers, hot plates, test tubes, spring scales, balances, microscopes, thermometers, calculators, computers, spectroscopes, timing devices, and other equipment as needed to teach the curriculum;

Subject: Science
Text: Use preventative safety equipment, including chemical splash goggles, aprons, and gloves, and be prepared to use emergency safety equipment, including an eye/face wash, a fire blanket, and a fire extinguisher.

Subject: Science
Text: Matter and energy. The student knows that matter is composed of atoms and has chemical and physical properties.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the structure of atoms, including the masses, electrical charges, and locations, of protons and neutrons in the nucleus and electrons in the electron cloud;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify that protons determine an element's identity and valence electrons determine its chemical properties, including reactivity

Subject: Science
Text: Interpret the arrangement of the Periodic Table, including groups and periods, to explain how properties are used to classify elements

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that chemical formulas are used to identify substances and determine the number of atoms of each element in chemical formulas containing subscripts

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate how evidence of chemical reactions indicate that new substances with different properties are formed

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize whether a chemical equation containing coefficients is balanced or not and how that relates to the law of conservation of mass.

Subject: Science
Text: Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that there is a relationship between force, motion, and energy.

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and calculate how unbalanced forces change the speed or direction of an object's motion;

Subject: Science
Text: Differentiate between speed, velocity, and acceleration

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate and describe applications of Newton's law of inertia, law of force and acceleration, and law of action-reaction such as in vehicle restraints, sports activities, amusement park rides, Earth's tectonic activities, and rocket launches.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows the effects resulting from cyclical movements of the Sun, Earth, and Moon.

Subject: Science
Text: Model and illustrate how the tilted Earth rotates on its axis, causing day and night, and revolves around the Sun causing changes in seasons

Subject: Science
Text: Demonstrate and predict the sequence of events in the lunar cycle

Subject: Science
Text: Relate the position of the Moon and Sun to their effect on ocean tides.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows characteristics of the universe.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe components of the universe, including stars, nebulae, and galaxies, and use models such as the Herztsprung-Russell diagram for classification

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that the Sun is a medium-sized star near the edge of a disc-shaped galaxy of stars and that the Sun is many thousands of times closer to Earth than any other star

Subject: Science
Text: Explore how different wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum such as light and radio waves are used to gain information about distances and properties of components in the universe

Subject: Science
Text: Model and describe how light years are used to measure distances and sizes in the universe;

Subject: Science
Text: Research how scientific data are used as evidence to develop scientific theories to describe the origin of the universe.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that natural events can impact Earth systems.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe the historical development of evidence that supports plate tectonic theory

Subject: Science
Text: Relate plate tectonics to the formation of crustal features

Subject: Science
Text: Interpret topographic maps and satellite views to identify land and erosional features and predict how these features may be reshaped by weathering.

Subject: Science
Text: Earth and space. The student knows that climatic interactions exist among Earth, ocean, and weather systems.

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize that the Sun provides the energy that drives convection within the atmosphere and oceans, producing winds and ocean currents

Subject: Science
Text: Identify how global patterns of atmospheric movement influence local weather using weather maps that show high and low pressures and fronts;

Subject: Science
Text: Identify the role of the oceans in the formation of weather systems such as hurricanes.

Subject: Science
Text: Organisms and environments. The student knows that interdependence occurs among living systems and the environment and that human activities can affect these systems.

Subject: Science
Text: Describe producer/consumer, predator/prey, and parasite/host relationships as they occur in food webs within marine, freshwater, and terrestrial ecosystems;

Subject: Science
Text: Investigate how organisms and populations in an ecosystem depend on and may compete for biotic and abiotic factors such as quantity of light, water, range of temperatures, or soil composition

Subject: Science
Text: Explore how short- and long-term environmental changes affect organisms and traits in subsequent populations

Subject: Science
Text: Recognize human dependence on ocean systems and explain how human activities such as runoff, artificial reefs, or use of resources have modified these systems.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands that holidays are celebrations of special events. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the reasons for national patriotic holidays such as Presidents' Day, Veterans Day, and Independence Day

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify customs associated with national patriotic holidays such as parades and fireworks on Independence Day

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how historical figures, patriots, and good citizens helped shape the community, state, and nation.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify contributions of historical figures, including Stephen F. Austin, George Washington, Christopher Columbus, and Jose Antonio Navarro, who helped to shape the state and nation; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify contributions of patriots and good citizens who have shaped the community

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands the concept of chronology

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Place events in chronological order;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use vocabulary related to time and chronology, including before, after, next, first, last, yesterday, today, and tomorrow.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands the concept of location.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use terms, including over, under, near, far, left, and right, to describe relative location

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Locate places on the school campus and describe their relative locations

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands the physical and human characteristics of the environment.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the physical characteristics of places such as landforms, bodies of water, natural resources, and weather

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the human characteristics of places such as types of houses and ways of earning a living

Subject: Social Studies

Text: Analyze the consequences of human modification of the environment in Texas, past and present

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the basic economic patterns of early societies in Texas and the Western Hemisphere

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the economic patterns of various early Native-American groups in Texas and the Western Hemisphere

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the economic patterns of early European immigrants to Texas and the Western Hemisphere

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the reasons for exploration and colonization.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the economic motivations for European exploration and settlement in Texas and the Western Hemisphere

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the economic motivations for Anglo-American colonization in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the characteristics and benefits of the free enterprise system in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the development of the free enterprise system in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe how the free enterprise system works in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Give examples of the benefits of the free enterprise system in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands patterns of work and economic activities in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how people in different regions of Texas earn their living, past and present

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how geographic factors have influenced the location of economic activities in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the effects of immigration, migration, and limited resources on the economic development and growth of Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the impact of mass production, specialization, and division of labor on the economic growth of Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how developments in transportation and communication have influenced economic activities in Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the impact of American ideas about progress and equality of opportunity on the economic development and growth of Texas

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands how Texas, the United States, and other parts of the world are economically interdependent. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify ways in which technological changes have resulted in increased interdependence among Texas, the United States, and the world;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify oil and gas, agricultural, and technological products of Texas that are purchased to meet needs in the United States and around the world; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how Texans meet some of their needs through the purchase of products from the United States and the rest of the world.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands how people organized governments in different ways during the early development of Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare how selected Native-American groups governed themselves; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify characteristics of Spanish and Mexican colonial governments and their influence on inhabitants of Texas.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands important ideas in historic documents of Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the purposes and explain the importance of the Texas Declaration of Independence, the Texas Constitution, and the Treaty of Velasco; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain the basic functions of the three branches of state government.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands important customs, symbols, and celebrations of Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the meaning of selected patriotic symbols and landmarks of Texas, including the six flags over Texas, San Jos_ Mission, and the San Jacinto Monument;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Sing or recite Texas, Our Texas;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Recite and explain the meaning of the Pledge to the Texas Flag; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the origins and significance of state celebrations such as Texas Independence Day and Juneteenth.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of voluntary individual participation in the democratic process. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how individuals can participate voluntarily in civic affairs at state and local levels;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the role of the individual in state and local elections;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the importance of historical figures such as Sam Houston, Barbara Jordan, and Lorenzo de Zavala who modeled active participation in the democratic process; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how to contact elected and appointed leaders in state and local governments.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of effective leadership in a democratic society. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify leaders in state and local governments, including the governor, selected members of the Texas Legislature, and Texans who have been President of the United States, and their political parties; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify leadership qualities of state and local leaders, past and present.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the contributions of people of various racial, ethnic, and religious groups to Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the similarities and differences within and among selected racial, ethnic, and religious groups in Texas;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify customs, celebrations, and traditions of various culture groups in Texas; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Summarize the contributions of people of various racial, ethnic, and religious groups in the development of Texas.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Science, technology, and society. The student understands the impact of science and technology on life in Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify famous inventors and scientists such as Gail Borden, Joseph Glidden, and Patillo Higgins and their contributions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe how scientific discoveries and technological innovations have benefited individuals, businesses, and society in Texas; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Predict how future scientific discoveries and technological innovations might affect life in Texas.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired from a variety of sources including electronic technology. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Differentiate between, locate, and use primary and secondary sources such as computer software; interviews; biographies; oral, print, and visual material; and artifacts to acquire information about the United States and Texas;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing, contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations and predictions, and drawing inferences and conclusions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Organize and interpret information in outlines, reports, databases, and visuals including graphs, charts, timelines, and maps;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify different points of view about an issue or topic;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the elements of frame of reference that influenced the participants in an event; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use appropriate mathematical skills to interpret social studies information such as maps and graphs.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use social studies terminology correctly;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Incorporate main and supporting ideas in verbal and written communication;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Express ideas orally based on research and experiences;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create written and visual material such as journal entries, reports, graphic organizers, outlines, and bibliographies; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use standard grammar, spelling, sentence structure, and punctuation.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others, in a variety of settings. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands the causes and effects of European colonization in the United States beginning in 1565, the founding of St. Augustine. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain when, where, and why groups of people explored, colonized, and settled in the United States, including the search for religious freedom and economic gain; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the accomplishments of significant individuals during the colonial period, including William Bradford, Anne Hutchinson, William Penn, John Smith, John Wise, and Roger Williams.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how conflict between the American colonies and Great Britain led to American independence. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and analyze the causes and effects of events prior to and during the American Revolution, including the French and Indian War and the Boston Tea Party;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the Founding Fathers and Patriot heroes, including John Adams, Samuel Adams, Benjamin Franklin, Nathan Hale, Thomas Jefferson, the Sons of Liberty, and George Washington, and their motivations and contributions during the revolutionary period; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Summarize the results of the American Revolution, including the establishment of the United States and the development of the U.S. military.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands the events that led from the Articles of Confederation to the creation of the U.S. Constitution and the government it established. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the issues that led to the creation of the U.S. Constitution, including the weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the contributions of individuals, including James Madison, and others such as George Mason, Charles Pinckney, and Roger Sherman who helped create the U.S. Constitution.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands political, economic, and social changes that occurred in the United States during the 19th century. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the causes and effects of the War of 1812;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain how changes resulting from the Industrial Revolution led to conflict among sections of the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify reasons people moved west;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant events and concepts associated with U.S. territorial expansion, including the Louisiana Purchase, the expedition of Lewis and Clark, and Manifest Destiny;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the causes of the Civil War, including sectionalism, states' rights, and slavery, and the effects of the Civil War, including Reconstruction and the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments to the U.S. Constitution;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how industry and the mechanization of agriculture changed the American way of life; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the challenges, opportunities, and contributions of people from various American Indian and immigrant groups.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands important issues, events, and individuals in the United States during the 20th and 21st centuries. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze various issues and events of the 20th century such as industrialization, urbanization, increased use of oil and gas, the Great Depression, the world wars, the civil rights movement, and military actions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze various issues and events of the 21st century such as the War on Terror and the 2008 presidential election; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the accomplishments of individuals and groups such as Jane Addams, Susan B. Anthony, Dwight Eisenhower, Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks, Cesar Chavez, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Ronald Reagan, Colin Powell, the Tuskegee Airmen, and the 442nd Regimental Combat Team who have made contributions to society in the areas of civil rights, women's rights, military actions, and politics.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student uses geographic tools to collect, analyze, and interpret data. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Apply geographic tools, including grid systems, legends, symbols, scales, and compass roses, to construct and interpret maps; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Translate geographic data into a variety of formats such as raw data to graphs and maps.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands the concept of regions in the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe a variety of regions in the United States such as political, population, and economic regions that result from patterns of human activity;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe a variety of regions in the United States such as landform, climate, and vegetation regions that result from physical characteristics such as the Great Plains, Rocky Mountains, and Coastal Plains;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Locate on a map important political features such as the ten largest urban areas in the United States, the 50 states and their capitals, and regions such as the Northeast, the Midwest, and the Southwest; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Locate on a map important physical features such as the Rocky Mountains, Mississippi River, and Great Plains.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands the location and patterns of settlement and the geographic factors that influence where people live. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe the types of settlement and patterns of land use in the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the geographic factors that influence patterns of settlement and the distribution of population in the United States, past and present; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the reasons for the location of cities in the United States, including capital cities, and explain their distribution, past and present.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands how people adapt to and modify their environment. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe how and why people have adapted to and modified their environment in the United States, past and present, such as the use of human resources to meet basic needs; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the positive and negative consequences of human modification of the environment in the United States, past and present.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the basic economic patterns of early societies in the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the economic patterns of early European colonists; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify major industries of colonial America.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the development, characteristics, and benefits of the free enterprise system in the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the development of the free enterprise system in colonial America and the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe how the free enterprise system works in the United States; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Give examples of the benefits of the free enterprise system in the United States.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the impact of supply and demand on consumers and producers in a free enterprise system. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how supply and demand affects consumers in the United States; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the effects of supply and demand on business, industry, and agriculture, including the plantation system, in the United States.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands patterns of work and economic activities in the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare how people in different parts of the United States earn a living, past and present;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain how geographic factors have influenced the location of economic activities in the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the effects of immigration, migration, and limited resources on the economic development and growth of the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the impact of mass production, specialization, and division of labor on the economic growth of the United States; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the impact of American ideas about progress and equality of opportunity on the economic development and growth of the United States.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the organization of governments in colonial America. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and compare the systems of government of early European colonists, including representative government and monarchy; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify examples of representative government in the American colonies, including the Mayflower Compact and the Virginia House of Burgesses.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands important ideas in the Declaration of Independence, the U.S. Constitution, and the Bill of Rights. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the key elements and the purposes and explain the importance of the Declaration of Independence;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the purposes of the U.S. Constitution as identified in the Preamble; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the reasons for the creation of the Bill of Rights and its importance.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the framework of government created by the U.S. Constitution of 1787. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain the basic functions of the three branches of government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the reasons for and describe the system of checks and balances outlined in the U.S. Constitution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Distinguish between national and state governments and compare their responsibilities in the U.S. federal system.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands important symbols, customs, celebrations, and landmarks that represent American beliefs and principles and contribute to our national identity. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain various patriotic symbols, including Uncle Sam, and political symbols such as the donkey and elephant;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Sing or recite The Star-Spangled Banner and explain its history;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Recite and explain the meaning of the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States Flag;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the origins and significance of national celebrations such as Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Constitution Day, Columbus Day, and Veterans Day; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the significance of important landmarks, including the White House, the Statue of Liberty, and Mount Rushmore.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of individual participation in the democratic process at the local, state, and national levels. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the duty individuals have to participate in civic affairs at the local, state, and national levels; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how to contact elected and appointed leaders in local, state, and national governments.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the importance of effective leadership in a constitutional republic. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the contributions of the Founding Fathers to the development of the national government;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify past and present leaders in the national government, including the president and various members of Congress, and their political parties; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and compare leadership qualities of national leaders, past and present.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the fundamental rights of American citizens guaranteed in the Bill of Rights and other amendments to the U.S. Constitution. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe the fundamental rights guaranteed by each amendment in the Bill of Rights, including freedom of religion, speech, and press; the right to assemble and petition the government; the right to keep and bear arms; the right to trial by jury; and the right to an attorney

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe various amendments to the U.S. Constitution such as those that extended voting rights of U.S. citizens.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the relationship between the arts and the times during which they were created. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant examples of art, music, and literature from various periods in U.S. history such as the painting American Progress, Yankee Doodle, and Paul Revere's Ride; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how examples of art, music, and literature reflect the times during which they were created.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the contributions of people of various racial, ethnic, and religious groups to the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the similarities and differences within and among various racial, ethnic, and religious groups in the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe customs and traditions of various racial, ethnic, and religious groups in the United States; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Summarize the contributions of people of various racial, ethnic, and religious groups to our national identity.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Science, technology, and society. The student understands the impact of science and technology on society in the United States. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the accomplishments of notable individuals in the fields of science and technology, including Benjamin Franklin, Eli Whitney, John Deere, Thomas Edison, Alexander Graham Bell, George Washington Carver, the Wright Brothers, and Neil Armstrong;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify how scientific discoveries, technological innovations, and the rapid growth of technology industries have advanced the economic development of the United States, including the transcontinental railroad and the space program;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how scientific discoveries and technological innovations in the fields of medicine, communication, and transportation have benefited individuals and society in the United States; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Predict how future scientific discoveries and technological innovations could affect society in the United States.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired from a variety of valid sources, including electronic technology. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Differentiate between, locate, and use valid primary and secondary sources such as computer software; interviews; biographies; oral, print, and visual material; documents; and artifacts to acquire information about the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing, contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations and predictions, and drawing inferences and conclusions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Organize and interpret information in outlines, reports, databases, and visuals, including graphs, charts, timelines, and maps;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify different points of view about an issue, topic, or current event; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the historical context of an event.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use social studies terminology correctly;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Incorporate main and supporting ideas in verbal and written communication;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Express ideas orally based on research and experiences;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create written and visual material such as journal entries, reports, graphic organizers, outlines, and bibliographies; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use standard grammar, spelling, sentence structure, and punctuation.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others, in a variety of settings. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands that historical events influence contemporary events. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Trace characteristics of various contemporary societies in regions that resulted from historical events or factors such as invasion, conquests, colonization, immigration, and trade; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the historical background of various contemporary societies to evaluate relationships between past conflicts and current conditions.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands the influences of individuals and groups from various cultures on various historical and contemporary societies. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe the influence of individual or group achievements on various historical or contemporary societies such as the classical Greeks on government and the American Revolution on the French Revolution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the social, political, economic, and cultural contributions of individuals and groups from various societies, past and present.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student uses geographic tools to answer geographic questions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Pose and answer geographic questions, including: Where is it located? Why is it there? What is significant about its location? How is its location related to the location of other people, places, and environments?;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Pose and answer questions about geographic distributions and patterns for various world regions and countries shown on maps, graphs, charts, models, and databases;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare various world regions and countries using data from geographic tools, including maps, graphs, charts, databases, and models; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create thematic maps, graphs, charts, models, and databases depicting aspects such as population, disease, and economic activities of various world regions and countries.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands the factors that influence the locations and characteristics of locations of various contemporary societies on maps and globes and uses latitude and longitude to determine absolute locations. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Locate various contemporary societies on maps and globes using latitude and longitude to determine absolute location;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain the geographic factors responsible for patterns of population in places and regions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain ways in which human migration influences the character of places and regions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and locate major physical and human geographic features such as landforms, water bodies, and urban centers of various places and regions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Draw sketch maps that illustrate various places and regions; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the location of major world countries such as Canada, Mexico, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Norway, Sweden, Russia, South Africa, Nigeria, Iraq, Afghanistan, Israel, Iran, India, Pakistan, the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China (Taiwan), Japan, North and South Korea, Indonesia, and Australia.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands how geographic factors influence the economic development, political relationships, and policies of societies. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain the geographic factors responsible for the location of economic activities in places and regions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify geographic factors such as location, physical features, transportation corridors and barriers, and distribution of natural resources that influence a society's ability to control territory; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the impact of geographic factors on economic development and the domestic and foreign policies of societies.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands that geographical patterns result from physical environmental processes. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe and explain the effects of physical environmental processes such as erosion, ocean currents, and earthquakes on Earth's surface;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the location of renewable and nonrenewable natural resources such as fresh water, fossil fuels, fertile soils, and timber; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the effects of the interaction of physical processes and the environment on humans.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student understands the impact of interactions between people and the physical environment on the development and conditions of places and regions. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and analyze ways people have adapted to the physical environment in various places and regions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and analyze ways people have modified the physical environment such as mining, irrigation, and transportation infrastructure; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe ways in which technology influences human interactions with the environment such as humans building dams for flood control.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the factors of production in a society's economy. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe ways in which the factors of production (natural resources, labor, capital, and entrepreneurs) influence the economies of various contemporary societies;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify problems and issues that may arise when one or more of the factors of production is in relatively short supply; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the impact of relative scarcity of resources on international trade and economic interdependence among and within societies.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands the various ways in which people organize economic systems. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare ways in which various societies organize the production and distribution of goods and services;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare and contrast free enterprise, socialist, and communist economies in various contemporary societies, including the benefits of the U.S. free enterprise system;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Understand the importance of morality and ethics in maintaining a functional free enterprise system; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Examine the record of collective, non-free market economic systems in contemporary world societies.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Economics. The student understands categories of economic activities and the data used to measure a society's economic level. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Define and give examples of agricultural, wholesale, retail, manufacturing (goods), and service industries;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe levels of economic development of various societies using indicators such as life expectancy, gross domestic product (GDP), GDP per capita, and literacy; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe the effects of government regulation and taxation on economic development and business planning.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands the concepts of limited and unlimited governments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe examples of limited and unlimited governments such as constitutional (limited) and totalitarian (unlimited);

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the characteristics of limited and unlimited governments;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify reasons for limiting the power of government; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Review the record of human rights abuses of limited or unlimited governments such as the oppression of Christians in Sudan.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Government. The student understands various ways in which people organize governments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and give examples of governments with rule by one, few, or many;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare ways in which various societies such as China, Germany, India, and Russia organize government and how they function; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify historical origins of democratic forms of government such as Ancient Greece.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands that the nature of citizenship varies among societies. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe roles and responsibilities of citizens in various contemporary societies, including the United States;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how opportunities for citizens to participate in and influence the political process vary among various contemporary societies; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the role of citizens in the United States with the role of citizens from various contemporary societies with representative and nonrepresentative governments.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Citizenship. The student understands the relationship among individual rights, responsibilities, duties, and freedoms in societies with representative governments. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain the duty of civic participation in societies with representative governments; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain relationships among rights, responsibilities, and duties in societies with representative governments.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the similarities and differences within and among cultures in various world societies. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Define culture and the common traits that unify a culture region;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe common traits that define cultures;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Define a multicultural society and consider both the positive and negative qualities of multiculturalism;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the experiences and evaluate the contributions of diverse groups to multicultural societies;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the similarities and differences among various world societies; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and explain examples of conflict and cooperation between and among cultures.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands that all societies have basic institutions in common even though the characteristics of these institutions may differ. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify institutions basic to all societies, including government, economic, educational, and religious institutions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare characteristics of institutions in various contemporary societies; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the efforts and activities institutions use to sustain themselves over time such as the development of an informed citizenry through education and the use of monumental architecture by religious institutions.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands relationships that exist among world cultures. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe how culture traits such as trade, travel, and war spread;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and describe factors that influence cultural change such as improved communication, transportation, and economic development;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Evaluate the impact of improved communication technology among cultures;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify and define the impact of cultural diffusion on individuals and world societies; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify examples of positive and negative effects of cultural diffusion.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the relationship that exists between the arts and the societies in which they are produced. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the relationships that exist between societies and their architecture, art, music, and literature;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Relate ways in which contemporary expressions of culture have been influenced by the past;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe ways in which contemporary issues influence creative expressions; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify examples of art, music, and literature that have transcended the boundaries of societies and convey universal themes such as religion, justice, and the passage of time.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Culture. The student understands the relationships among religion, philosophy, and culture. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the relationship among religious ideas, philosophical ideas, and cultures; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the significance of religious holidays and observances such as Christmas, Easter, Ramadan, the annual hajj, Yom Kippur, Rosh Hashanah, Diwali, and Vaisakhi in various contemporary societies.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Science, technology, and society. The student understands the influences of science and technology on contemporary societies. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Give examples of scientific discoveries and technological innovations, including the roles of scientists and inventors, that have transcended the boundaries of societies and have shaped the world;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how resources, belief systems, economic factors, and political decisions have affected the use of technology; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Make predictions about future social, political, economic, cultural, and environmental impacts that may result from future scientific discoveries and technological innovations.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired through established research methodologies from a variety of valid sources, including electronic technology. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Differentiate between, locate, and use valid primary and secondary sources such as computer software; interviews; biographies; oral, print, and visual material; and artifacts to acquire information about various world cultures;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing, contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations and predictions, and drawing inferences and conclusions;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Organize and interpret information from outlines, reports, databases, and visuals, including graphs, charts, timelines, and maps;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify different points of view about an issue or current topic;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the elements of frame of reference that influenced participants in an event; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use appropriate mathematical skills to interpret social studies information such as maps and graphs.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use social studies terminology correctly;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Incorporate main and supporting ideas in verbal and written communication based on research;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Express ideas orally based on research and experiences;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Create written and visual material such as journal entries, reports, graphic organizers, outlines, and bibliographies based on research;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use standard grammar, spelling, sentence structure, and punctuation; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use proper citations to avoid plagiarism.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Social studies skills. The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others, in a variety of settings. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the major eras in Texas history, describe their defining characteristics, and explain why historians divide the past into eras, including Natural Texas and its People; Age of Contact; Spanish Colonial; Mexican National; Revolution and Republic; Early Statehood; Texas in the Civil War and Reconstruction; Cotton, Cattle, and Railroads; Age of Oil; Texas in the Great Depression and World War II; Civil Rights and Conservatism; and Contemporary Texas;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Apply absolute and relative chronology through the sequencing of significant individuals, events, and time periods; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the significance of the following dates: 1519, mapping of the Texas coast and first mainland Spanish settlement; 1718, founding of San Antonio; 1821, independence from Spain; 1836, Texas independence; 1845, annexation; 1861, Civil War begins; 1876, adoption of current state constitution; and 1901, discovery of oil at Spindletop.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how individuals, events, and issues through the Mexican National Era shaped the history of Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Compare the cultures of American Indians in Texas prior to European colonization such as Gulf, Plains, Puebloan, and Southeastern;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify important individuals, events, and issues related to European exploration of Texas such as Alonso lvarez de Pineda, lvar NÏÐez Cabeza de Vaca and his writings, the search for gold, and the conflicting territorial claims between France and Spain;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify important events and issues related to European colonization of Texas, including the establishment of Catholic missions, towns, and ranches, and individuals such as Fray Damiàn Massanet, Jos_ de EscandÑn, Antonio Margil de JesÏs, and Francisco Hidalgo;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the individuals, issues, and events related to Mexico becoming an independent nation and its impact on Texas, including Texas involvement in the fight for independence, Jos_ Guti_rrez de Lara, the Battle of Medina, the Mexican federal Constitution of 1824, the merger of Texas and Coahuila as a state, the State Colonization Law of 1825, and slavery;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify the contributions of significant individuals, including Moses Austin, Stephen F. Austin, Erasmo SeguÕn, MartÕn De LeÑn, and Green DeWitt, during the Mexican settlement of Texas; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Contrast Spanish, Mexican, and Anglo purposes for and methods of settlement in Texas.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how individuals, events, and issues related to the Texas Revolution shaped the history of Texas. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Trace the development of events that led to the Texas Revolution, including the Fredonian Rebellion, the Mier y Teràn Report, the Law of April 6, 1830, the Turtle Bayou Resolutions, and the arrest of Stephen F. Austin;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the roles played by significant individuals during the Texas Revolution, including George Childress, Lorenzo de Zavala, James Fannin, Sam Houston, Antonio LÑpez de Santa Anna, Juan N. SeguÕn, and William B. Travis;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the issues surrounding significant events of the Texas Revolution, including the Battle of Gonzales, William B. Travis's letter To the People of Texas and All Americans in the World, the siege of the Alamo and all the heroic defenders who gave their lives there, the Constitutional Convention of 1836, Fannin's surrender at Goliad, and the Battle of San Jacinto; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain how the establishment of the Republic of Texas brought civil, political, and religious freedom to Texas.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how individuals, events, and issues shaped the history of the Republic of Texas and early Texas statehood. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify individuals, events, and issues during the administrations of Republic of Texas Presidents Houston, Lamar, and Jones, including the Texas Navy, the Texas Rangers, Edwin W. Moore, Jack Coffee Hays, Chief Bowles, William Goyens, Mary Maverick, Jos_ Antonio Navarro, the CÑrdova Rebellion, the Council House Fight, the Santa Fe Expedition, public debt, and the roles of racial and ethnic groups;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the causes of and events leading to Texas annexation; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify individuals, events, and issues during early Texas statehood, including the U.S.-Mexican War, the Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo, population growth, and the Compromise of 1850.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how events and issues shaped the history of Texas during the Civil War and Reconstruction. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain reasons for the involvement of Texas in the Civil War such as states' rights, slavery, sectionalism, and tariffs;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the political, economic, and social effects of the Civil War and Reconstruction in Texas; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant individuals and events concerning Texas and the Civil War such as John Bell Hood, John Reagan, Francis Lubbock, Thomas Green, John Magruder and the Battle of Galveston, the Battle of Sabine Pass, and the Battle of Palmito Ranch.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how individuals, events, and issues shaped the history of Texas from Reconstruction through the beginning of the 20th century. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant individuals, events, and issues from Reconstruction through the beginning of the 20th century, including the factors leading to the expansion of the Texas frontier, the effects of westward expansion on American Indians, the buffalo soldiers, and Quanah Parker;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant individuals, events, and issues from Reconstruction through the beginning of the 20th century, including the development of the cattle industry from its Spanish beginnings and the myths and realities of the cowboy way of life;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Identify significant individuals, events, and issues from Reconstruction through the beginning of the 20th century, including the effects of the growth of railroads and the contributions of James Hogg; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the political, economic, and social impact of the agricultural industry and the development of West Texas resulting from the close of the frontier.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: History. The student understands how individuals, events, and issues shaped the history of Texas during the 20th and early 21st centuries. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Explain the political, economic, and social impact of the oil industry on the industrialization of Texas;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Define and trace the impact of boom-and-bust cycles of leading Texas industries throughout the 20th and early 21st centuries such as farming, oil and gas production, cotton, ranching, real estate, banking, and computer technology;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe and compare the impact of the Progressive and other reform movements in Texas in the 19th and 20th centuries such as the Populists, women's suffrage, agrarian groups, labor unions, and the evangelical movement of the late 20th century;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Describe and compare the civil rights and equal rights movements of various groups in Texas in the 20th century and identify key leaders in these movements, including James L. Farmer Jr., Hector P. Garcia, Oveta Culp Hobby, Lyndon B. Johnson, the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC), Jane McCallum, and Lulu Belle Madison White;

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the political, economic, and social impact of major events, including World War I, the Great Depression, and World War II, on the history of Texas; and

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Analyze the political, economic, and social impact of major events in the latter half of the 20th and early 21st centuries such as major conflicts, the emergence of a two-party system, political and economic controversies, immigration, and migration.

Subject: Social Studies
Text: Geography. The student uses geographic tools to collect, analyze, and interpret data. The student is expected to:

Subject: Social Studies
